subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That the following bill be introduced: a bill for an act to amend the War Crimes Act 1945.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table the explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

This bill repeals section 22 of the War Crimes Act 1945. The act was amended in 1989 prior to the fall of the "iron curtain" to enable trial in Australia with respect of conduct engaged in during World War II in Europe. Although the usual practice would have been to extradite persons accused of such crimes to the country where the crimes occurred, at the time it was considered politically unacceptable to extradite persons to countries behind the so called `iron curtain'.

The `iron curtain' has fallen and many of the republics, including Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania are now independent states and have been accepted as members of the Council of Europe. Australia has, in the past, been prepared to enter into extradition arrangements with any country that is a member of the Council.

The Government is actively pursuing the possibility of establishing modern extradition arrangements with many of these newly independent States. However, even if a modern extradition relationship was in place, it would still be impossible for those countries to comply with an extradition request while section 22 of the War Crimes Act remains in force.

Section 22 of the act provides that where a person's extradition is sought for conduct covered by the act no surrender for extradition is possible unless there is a prima facie case. Thus, notwithstanding a modern extradition relationship with these countries, if the offence for which extradition is sought is a `war crime' then the requesting state must provide a prima facie case. Because of the differences between civil code and common law countries the practical effect is that a civil code jurisdiction could never successfully seek the extradition of a person suspected of a war crime.

The concept of a prima facie case in determining sufficiency of evidence is one to which most common law countries are accustomed. However, those countries which operate under a civil code system (e.g., Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania) do not use this test in criminal proceedings, and experience has shown that use of this standard in extradition arrangements with civil code countries is almost impossible in practice. The practical issue is that the laws of evidence in common law systems are such as to make it impossible for a civil code jurisdiction to supply evidence in an admissible form. In essence, because of the fundamental differences between common law and civil code jurisdictions, particularly
evidentiary requirements, the practical effect is that it is currently impossible for a civil code jurisdiction to successfully seek the extradition of a suspected war criminal from Australia.
The repeal of section 22 will remove the fundamental barrier to Australia's cooperation with the international community in relation to suspected war criminals.

This is not to say that extradition of a suspected war criminal would be automatic. Any request for the extradition of a suspected war criminal would be subject to the general extradition arrangement with the requesting country. Such arrangement must include all the usual safeguards spelt out in the Extradition Act 1988. All that the amendment will do is to remove an additional onerous requirement that relates only to the extradition of war criminals This Government sees no reason in principle why this practical impediment to the extradition of war criminals should be retained.
The amendment to the act will not have any financial impact
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Ordered that the further consideration of the second reading of this bill be adjourned to the first day of sitting in the Spring sittings 1998 in accordance with standing order 111.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 23 June, on motion by Senator Ian Campbell:
That this bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak on the Company Law Review Bill 1998 and welcome the government's following through on this process. Senator Ian Campbell and others have worked on this bill. There are a number of key areas, though, that I believe were identified in the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities which I would like to speak to. They revolved around the issues of corporate governance—
—Oh no!

—I am afraid so, Senator McGauran—corporate governance. Your side would not know a lot about that. There may be a few familiar names, friends of yours, who get a mention, so I am hoping that you are going to stay with me for this one.

speech.para: This government prides itself on wanting to introduce world best practice everywhere—world best practice in the Public Service, world best practice on the waterfront, world best practice in our tax system. Today we have an opportunity to debate world best practice for corporate governance. Where does the government stand on this issue? It is refusing to accept all of our amendments. There is an opportunity to put world best practice in corporate governance into this legislation today. This really shows how hollow and how selective this government is when it wants to talk about world best practice. It is world best practice for unions and world best practice for the Public Service, but when it comes to world best practice for the conduct of corporate behaviour in this country, the government is missing in action. There is no show from this government. It straight away caves in to its mates in business. It is not prepared to discuss some quite trivial issues—and they are quite trivial issues, as I will demonstrate in this debate.

Unfortunately, the ASX has been complicit in trying to avoid facing up to some of these issues. It does not want to include or support corporate governance. In fact, one official told me they thought corporate governance was just a current fad—that transparency in corporate behaviour was just a current fad. It would be gone in a few years, we were told. Unfortunately, issues like the disclosure of directors' fees and executive salaries are regarded as a current fads. Maybe it is something to do with the demutualisation of the ASX and the sudden massive increases in the remuneration packages that senior people at the ASX are going to receive now that it has been demutualised. Maybe this has been guiding their views on this current fad.

The adoption of shortened company annual reports and the 21-day notice of shareholders meetings are the sorts of issues which we have an opportunity today to insert into this bill. I would like to quote from the report, which makes reference to the views of the ASX. It says:

It is not possible to identify meaningful corporate governance practices and disclosure that can usefully be applied across the diversity of different company circumstances, and views of world best practice and international standards change over time. Proscription would restrict Australian companies ability to follow world best practice as it continues to evolve. And, at a more basic level, many of the measures proposed are of questionable relevance and value in the Australian context, especially when the costs that they impose are considered.

Humbug. Here is the ASX leading the charge to oppose transparency in corporate behaviour in its own markets. It is very disappointing to find that view coming from the ASX, with its key role in monitoring a lot of the shonky behaviour that goes on in the corporate world. It is usually the first port of call to detect fraudulent white-collar behaviour. But when it comes to some simple issues, it is standing in the way of genuine transparency and reform.
The committee was presented with IFSA's view. It said:

IFSA, in common with its predecessor body, AIMA, is firmly of the view that monitoring practices alone are insufficient to promote improvements in Australia's corporate governance environment or to bring Australia into line with the growing international consensus on what constitutes best practice in this important area. Government has a critical role to play in promoting the principle of disclosure as the key mechanism for ensuring accountability by companies and in equipping shareholders with the practical tools they need to fulfil their monitoring and review functions. IFSA is of the view that the Company Law Review Bill 1997 does not adequately address these important corporate governance matters and asks that the PJC recommend that the bill be amended to include the above requirements.

The key here is not what is in the best interests of the directors of companies; it is what is in the best interests of shareholders, so that shareholders are adequately informed to make judgments about the performance of its directors. The directors are the employees; the shareholders are the owners. These amendments are about empowering shareholders. It may be that it is empowering them at the expense of directors, but is that such a bad thing? I say no. This is a chance to empower shareholders.

The first of the amendments to be moved by the Labor Party, and which are supported by the Democrats and, I believe, the Greens and, hopefully, Senator Harradine, are to do with a general management discussion and analysis. It is a one page document to be included in information which gives a general overview of how the directors see the future strategy of the company. One page in regular reports is not a really onerous requirement. We have seen opposition. This is a provision that simply requires narrative information on financial statements. That is all. It is not hard to prepare. If you were in America, it would be a requirement. You have to provide that sort of information. But, disappointingly, this government is choosing to oppose this. I understand, following pressure from the opposition, that the ASX is moving, hopefully, to implement this in its listing rules.

talk.start.para: —It has moved.

—The ASX has only moved because of the pressure of these potential amendments. It has only moved because there is pressure on in the parliament to gain this information for shareholders. It should be welcomed that the ASX is moving, but what should not be welcomed is its opposition to having this included in legislation. But it is a positive development by the ASX.

speech.para: Let me refer to a quote that was given to the committee by the government:

While the government believes that proper reporting to members is an important responsibility for companies, it considers that the approach proposed by the committee is not appropriate at the present time. In particular, it considers that the provision of a management discussion analysis to members should be a matter for companies to decide.

Directors should be able to decide the information given to their shareholders, not the other way around. Yet the shareholders are the ones who should make these decisions. The shareholders should be given this information so they can judge the performance of the directors, not the other way around. Directors should not be able to not provide information or decide whether to give information or not; it should be given so that the shareholders are in a position to make the judgments. The Securities Institute had a say on this issue as well. They said it was `contrary to international trends set by major capital markets such as the United States, Canada and the United Kingdom, and leaves Australian users of annual company reporting at a disadvantage.' That is the Securities Institute—another bolshie organisation, another pack of `Trots' running loose on the corporate scene.

talk.start.para: —Unequivocally backed the ASX doing it.

—We support the ASX moving in that direction, but we are not trying to pretend that this only happened all of a sudden because of the ASX, which has opposed corporate governance—you missed my earlier remarks, Senator Campbell. Corporate governance is a fad, according to the ASX. I have been told that personally. They oppose corporate governance as just a fad.

speech.para: The ASX have been under pressure to move in this direction: pressure not generated by the government but pressure generated at the grassroots by shareholders, by institutions and by this opposition. They have not caved in because they thought it was a good idea that you suggested it to them; they have been forced to move by the pressure in the business community from institutional investors and from this opposition and minor parties.

The second amendment which the government is opposing is to do with the notice of meetings. This is a small issue and we are only talking about the difference between 21 days and 28 days. What we have seen is the institutional investors in this country, who are managing the majority of the funds nowadays, saying, `We have a situation where we require a bit more information and a bit more time to make a judgment when we are notified about the issues that are up before us.' In particular, that applies to overseas investors. Despite technology, overseas investors and institutional investors are saying, `We would like 28 days.' That is the position. This government have been prepared to do the bidding on MIB of institutions in the big end of town, but when the institutional investors turn around and say, `We really would appreciate a bit more time to make our judgments about the issues that are going to be up,' and it is only 28 days—or seven days more than proposed—what do the government say? No. That is disappointing.

Probably the most important, in my view, of the amendments we are proposing is the question of disclosure of director and senior executive salaries. Again, the ASX get trotted out. Again, they oppose. Here is what Mr Crosby, who made a submission, said:

The question is: what is the benefit? Is it information that is actually of use to investors and creditors of companies, which is what annual reports are about? We really question at the margin from what we have now, which is banded disclosure, detailed disclosure of allotments of securities and other incentive arrangements to directors, whether there is value being added for investors in requiring detailed disclosure. We just do not think the case is made, so we do not support a requirement to have line by line disclosure of directors' remuneration.

What a travesty from the ASX. As I said earlier, maybe it is just because they are about to get an increase for senior officials at the ASX in their own remuneration and their own packages. Maybe that is what is driving this. It is very disappointing to see the ASX taking this view. IFSA stated:

Disclosure of the quantum and components of the remuneration of each director of the company and each of its five highest paid executives, including the existence and length of any service contract for the CEO, is necessary.

The Institution of Investors are saying, `We want to know,' and this government are saying, `No, it is no-one's business.' ASX are saying, `We do not believe there is any need. There is no value in knowing that.' What have you got overseas? You have requirements along these lines overseas. The Australian markets are going to be less informed. Australian shareholders are going to be less informed than are their international counterparts. This government has a chance to say, `Let us make Australian shareholders equally as well informed as overseas shareholders.'
Mr Matheson, who is the Governor of the International Corporate Governance Network, said before the committee:

The last point is in relation to remuneration disclosure. I know that the committee recommended positively in this regard in its report on the bill and that the government did not accept that recommendation. Many members of the International Corporate Governance Network have expressed dismay both to me and to the government that this particular proposal was not picked up. I would like to remind the committee that, from an investor's point of view, the disclosure of remuneration details is not a voyeuristic sort of exercise. It is purely that in this country shareholders are required to vote on resolutions for the granting of options and also to approve the increases in the aggregate level of remuneration to non-executive directors.
Shareholders in this country are being asked to vote on these two remuneration related matters in the absence of complete information.
They are being asked to vote without knowing all the facts. And who is withholding these facts? The directors who are asking for the extra remuneration. Mr Matheson further says:

I would also say to the committee that, perhaps, what parliamentarians—dare I say it—company executives and directors are being paid in many forms these days, not just in salary but in other ways like options, bonuses, long-term incentive schemes, et cetera. The reality is that some of these option schemes can add, for example, between five and 150 per cent onto the reported value of remuneration as reported in the bands in the annual report.
The current system does not give full information to shareholders. Mr Matheson goes on:

I believe that the remuneration disclosure and the failure of the bill to pick up on the committee's recommendation has led to much dismay in the investment community. I think it would relieve a lot of companies of a lot of agro that occurs at their annual general meetings particularly by small investors who take exception to the granting of hundreds of thousands of options, in some cases, where they are being asked to do so on the basis of incomplete information. If shareholders are being asked to make an informed determination about whether they should approve a scheme or not, then I would suggest that they are being asked to do so currently on the basis of very incomplete information.

This is damning of this government. This is damning because it is seeking to assist in withholding from shareholders information about their directors' remuneration packages. This is an embarrassment internationally. `Dismay' was the word used—not by the Labor Party, not by the wharfies, not by the Democrats but by the International Corporate Governance Network. These are institutional shareholders. These are people all around the world who believe that what is most important is transparency, accountability and disclosure within corporations, so that you do not get the shonky behaviours of the Bonds and the Skases and so that people would know how much Alan Bond was getting paid and how much Chris Skase was getting paid and whether or not they were fair returns for the values that were being added.

We have seen some enormous remuneration packages recently. The boss of AMP has picked up a motser in the float of AMP, yet shareholders in the new AMP are not going to be able to find out exactly how much he has made out of the float compared with themselves. They are not going to be able to find out about this.

In my remaining few minutes I would like to finish off by quoting another socialist organisation that has been calling for the sort of amendments that we have been talking about. It is a well known, clearly Labor orientated organisation. I refer to a editorial in the Australian Financial Review under the heading `Corporate oligarchy'. The editorial states:

But in reality the corporate market-place will not work efficiently until the shareholder class becomes better organised to discipline the clubby world of Australian boardrooms. Unfortunately, the boards too often act to disempower shareholders.

This is the Australian Financial Review 's editorial. This is not a meeting of the International Socialists. This is not the Labor Party talking. This is the editorial of the Australian Financial Review talking about the `clubby world of Australian boardrooms'—and it would know. It goes on:

For instance, evidence presented to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities shows that about half the companies approached recently to reveal their proxy voting results at annual meetings refused to supply the information.
This is another issue that I will speak about a little later in the committee stage. On the proxy voting situation, it says:

Proxy votes are merely those cast, in advance, by shareholders who do not attend the annual meeting. The disclosure sought was not an individual breakdown of which shareholders voted on which measures (although that information is available to the companies)—
so the directors know how individual shareholders vote, but that is not what the requirement is; we just want to know the total outcome of those votes—
simply the total proxy vote "for", "against", or "open" to the chairman's discretion.
The Australian Financial Review goes on a little later in its editorial to say:
It is known that the secretaries of certain Melbourne companies, not necessarily including BHP, meet on a regular basis to discuss how they will deal with this type of issue.

Shareholders should know when some directors are re-elected by a whopping margin of support, and also if other bits of deadwood float in a tide of proxy votes, some of which have been sent in blank to be cast as the chairman decides.
The Australian Financial Review goes on to say:
If a trade union—say, the Maritime Union of Australia—tried to run an election like this, its officials could face—
gaol. That is exactly right. If a trade union tried to conduct itself—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The Company Law Review Bill 1997 is a bill central to the way in which we run our society, and I think that has to be remembered. As the parliamentary secretary said during the debate on the last bill, the Managed Investments Bill 1997 , the issue of corporations and the way that we run the financial affairs of the nation is based on issues of philosophy, not simply matters of economy. No doubt, Mr Acting Deputy President Watson, given your many years of experience in this area, you would agree with that.

speech.para: The central factor about corporate life is this: you have a vast amount of money contributed by shareholders which is in the charge of a confined number of people, the directors and the managers, who may not own much of the company at all. In other words, you have vast resources in the charge of people who do not, in fact, own those resources. It is that concept that lies behind the laws that are made in this area because those who are managers of the company and those who are directors of the company—those people who have control of the company—are not people who own most of the company. That, of course, creates the need to arrange proper rules and regulations so that the people who own the assets have a fair deal from those who control them.

It has been said somewhere that corporate life is very much like a communist state in that an oligarchy, a small group of people, controls the assets of a vast number of other people. Corporation law is about trying to adjust that on a fair basis. You have had—as you no doubt could speak eloquently on, Mr Acting Deputy President—this struggle between the black letter law and the fuzzy law when disasters happen, as they did during the 1980s and 1890s in Australia. When you have terrible collapses and people stripped of their wealth, you have a rush to black letter law. As time goes by and people feel the particular crisis has been met, you have the tendency to go off to the fuzzy law situation. That is what has happened in this particular situation and it is manifest in the bill we are discussing.

I would like to quote from the second reading speech and show some concern about the basis of the bill or, as the parliamentary secretary says, the different philosophies in the debate on this bill. I listened carefully to the debate on the last bill, and the parliamentary secretary was very conscious of this conflicting philosophy—properly so because that is what it is all about. In that part of the second reading speech dealing with the history of the bill, this is said:

While accurate and informative reporting to shareholders is essential to maintaining investor confidence, the detail of reporting requirements should usually be left to best practice in corporate governance, rather than through detailed black-letter law. The government considers that companies should be free to decide for themselves whether they should be preparing management discussion and analysis for shareholders, instead of being compelled to do so by law.

That shows confidence in the ability of market forces—the forces for efficiency and competition—to make managers and directors act as they should. History has shown that that confidence has often been betrayed.

We should look at this whole area in terms of the social and political effect that Corporation Law has. One of the great classic cases in the history of the development of company law is Foss v Harbottle. The corporation dealt with in that case was not a big company by today's standards but a private company where the actual shareholders were very much in charge of the management of the company. The court had this to say:

Corporations like this, of a private nature, are in truth little more than private partnerships; and in cases which may easily be suggested it would be too much to hold that a society of private persons associated together in undertakings, which though certainly beneficial to the public, are nevertheless matters of private property, are to be deprived of their civil rights, inter se , because, in order to make their common objects more attainable, the Crown or the Legislature may have conferred upon them the benefit of a corporate character.

The phrase I want to take from that is `of their civil rights'. This is a case that was decided in March of 1843, so it has a long history. Even at that time the courts were talking in terms of the civil rights of the shareholders—those in the company. So that concept has always been there: companies and corporations are more than a vehicle for economic activity; they have at their base other consequences which we should look at.
In the Foss and Harbottle case the court also said:

But, on the other hand, it must not be without reasons of a very urgent character that established rules of law and practice are to be departed from, rules which, though in a sense technical, are founded on general principles of justice and convenience; and the question is whether a case is stated in this bill entitling the Plaintiffs to sue in their private characters.

Again this concept of justice and convenience comes through, and that has been carried through up to modern times. Indeed, the development of the law in Australia has, as elsewhere, been very much affected by whether or not there has been a crisis in company law and people have lost money and companies have collapsed, or whether things have gone reasonably well.

My own state of Victoria has had a very significant part to play in the history of company law. It was in Victoria that the no liability company was developed in 1871 to accommodate the mining industry. That was when things were going well, but Victoria was the place where, during the 1890s, provisions were brought in requiring annual general reporting and proper accounting to look after the shareholders and those who had an interest in the company. During the 1890s when that was brought in there was terrible crisis and a collapse in the corporate world.

The United States of America is the classic example of where corporate life is fundamental to the way society runs. Corporations in America have a very powerful impact. It was in that context that Berle and Means in 1932—well before anybody in this room was born; not by much, if you look at me—produced the classic work on corporations called The modern corporation and private property. They had this to say, and it is interesting following on from my remarks about Foss and Harbottle:

The typical business unit of the 19th century was owned by individuals or small groups; was managed by them or their appointees; and was, in the main, limited in size by the personal wealth of the individuals in control.
So you had the ownership and the control of the companies in the one hand—the point I was making before. They go on to say later in the book:
Then, the modern corporation, equally revolutionary in its effect, placed the wealth of innumerable individuals under the same central control.

It was in that context where you had division between ownership and control that he wrote this great work. There are two other quotes I want to read from Berle and Means, then I want to come to something closer to the present day. They said:

The corporation has, in fact, become both a method of property tenure and a means of organizing economic life. Grown to tremendous proportions, there may be said to have evolved a "corporate system"—as there was once a feudal system—which has attracted to itself a combination of attributes and powers, and has attained a degree of prominence entitling it to be dealt with as a major social institution.
They made some additions to the 1932 version and published them in 1967. In the updated thoughts in December 1967 they had this to say:

We are well underway toward recognition that property used in production must conform to conceptions of civilization worked out through democratic processes of American constitutional government. Few American enterprises, and no large corporations, can take the view that their plants, tools and organizations are their own, and that they can do what they please with their own. There is increasing recognition of the fact that collective operations, and those predominantly conducted by large corporations, are like operations carried on by the state itself. Corporations are essentially political constructs.
They go on to say later:

Philosophical preoccupation will become more important than economic. What is this personal life, this individuality, this search for personal development and fulfilment intended to achieve? Mere wallowing in consumption would leave great numbers of people unsatisfied; their demand will be for participation. This means, in substance, a growing demand that significant jobs be available for everyone, at a time when automation may diminish the number of all commercially created jobs as we presently know them. It may well mean that the state would be expected to create jobs wherever a social need is recognized, irrespective of the classic requirement for a commercial base.

What is being said about this strand through the history of company law is that corporations like individual people have obligations to the state and cannot be seen simply as economic vehicles; they have a communal responsibility to everybody within society. The amendments that we are dealing with today recognise that in proposed chapter 2B, basic features of a company. We will come to this in the committee stage of the bill, but proposed subsection 124(1) says:
A company has the legal capacity and powers of an individual both in and outside this jurisdiction.
Then it goes on to talk about company powers. Proposed subsection 124(2) says:
A company's legal capacity to do something is not affected by the fact that the company's interests are not, or would not be, served by doing it.

I think that is a very important part of this bill. I think it is a bill that is in line with the sorts of things I have been talking about so far. It does realise that it is not just simply economic advancement that counts but that there are other obligations that companies have.

I would like to mention some of the people who need to be remembered in this context. No doubt senators would remember the former member for Hawker in South Australia Ralph Jacobi, who made some great speeches about company law before the history of the 1980s and 1990s had occurred. I recommend to people interested in this area that they read two of his speeches—one on 12 May 1981, which is in the House of Representatives Hansard at page 2271; and another one on 27 October 1982 at page 2632—where he anticipated the disasters of the 1980s—and I think he was a lonely voice in doing so.

I would also like to mention in this context that Mr Michael Duffy, the Attorney-General as he then was, did a lot of work in this area. His was to a large extent the black-letter law approach. I think myself that that is probably the proper approach still. It was the work that he did, together with others, of course, that led to the Corporations Law as we now know it.

May I also mention another work, the directors' duties paper No. 395 of 1989, which goes into the issue of directors' duties. That was a product of the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and, declaring an interest, I was then chair of that committee. I want to finish on this topic, but in the end it said that what you need in corporate life is to create a climate, a culture, where honesty and where dedication to others are the norm.

It would be a tragedy if the bill which is before us now was presented in such a way that it dealt only with the concept that corporations are an economic vehicle to increase wealth. Of course corporations are economic vehicles to create wealth. Of course we need a decent standard of living for everyone in Australia, and corporations are a central means of doing that. But they can do a lot more than that. They must be seen as groups, as bodies, as institutions that have an obligation at not only an economic level but also a social and, indeed, political level. They are citizens, like the rest of us are citizens. They have the rights of citizens, but they also have the obligations of citizens. There has to be a climate created so that corporations see that, understand that and act accordingly. If they do not, then we must have black-letter law, which is a shame. Nevertheless, people should understand where corporations should come from and we ought to make sure that they do.

talk.start.para: —In summing up this second reading debate on the Company Law Review Bill 1997, I first want to thank those senators who took a close interest in the development of the bill and those senators who contributed to the debate in the chamber over the past couple of hours.

speech.para: I particularly thank Senator Barney Cooney, who has had a very close interest in corpora tions issues both before his time as Chairman of the Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee and of course throughout that time. Senator Cooney will be very pleased to see the next Corporations Law economic reform bill, the Corporations Law Amendment (ASX) Bill 1997, which we expect will come into this place in the next couple of days, because it picks up one of the recommendations of that 1989 report in relation to the business judgment rule which he has been a champion of for many years.

Senator Cooney, we note your reference to that seminal work, judicial work, in Foss and Harbottle. The bill also picks up a policy idea which, for the first time in Australian law—if it passes the Senate and passes the parliament—places the entrenchment of a statutory right of action for shareholders, known in the trade as a statutory derivative right of action. In many respects, it supplants Foss and Harbottle.

I might say that the Attorney-General of Western Australia, who feels he has an umbilical relationship or at least a sibling relationship, in some respects, with Foss and Harbottle, is a little bit upset that Foss and Harbottle will become less important in Australian law once the statutory derivative right of action that this government seeks to give to shareholders to enforce their rights against directors who do not take action on behalf of companies is enacted for the first time in Australian history.

Senator Cooney, your contribution to debate on the Corporations Law over the decades has been a very positive and constructive one. Of course, your speech here today is just another chapter in that contribution. I want to respond to some of the key points that have been made during the debate but, prior to doing that, I suggest that Senator Cooney's speech was very similar to the other speeches in this debate in that they did not talk about the bill; they talked about one or two submissions to the first joint parliamentary inquiry—`first' because this one has been to the committee twice—to do with corporate governance issues.

As I said in opening my remarks, Senator Cooney, your comments on corporate govern ance and directors' duties and your contribution to that debate through the Senate Legal and Constitutional Affairs Committee are well known. Out of the consultations that you did in 1989, out of the consultations that were done by the joint parliamentary committee in the early 1990s when I was the deputy chair of that committee, and out of the consultations I have done on corporate law economic law reform, the government has actually picked and put into the statute a business judgment rule. Senator Cooney knows better than anyone else in this place how hard it is to frame a business judgment rule that people are happy with. I have crossed my fingers and crossed my arms behind my back and think we have actually got a set of words and the construction of a business judgment rule in Australia that, for the first time, has support—dare I use the old Bob Hawkeism: a consensus.

That highlights the point that I have been making in private correspondence and in public comments about dealing with corporate governance issues in the way that the opposition and the Democrats—both very well-intentioned—supported, by tagging them on and making this an omnibus corporations bill. This bill was a piece of work created by the simplification task force under then Attorney-General Lavarch. It sought to look at the core company provisions. Its intention was to streamline the application process to establish a company. It does that by putting together into one form, a single form, the requirements for registering a company. There are massive savings in paperwork to companies across Australia. It massively reduces the cost of registering a company, for the approximately 80,000 new companies a year registered in Australia.

It also facilitates the use of electronic means of transmission for meetings and for communications with shareholders. It reduces the need for formal company meetings. It says that, where there is unanimity amongst directors and they have signed off on a bit of paper to say that they are unanimous, they do not need to go through the procedure of calling a meeting; something that those of us who have been company directors know will save a lot of time and headache. When there is a matter that is unanimous, why is it necessary to get everyone to put down what they are doing, come together to pass a resolution and then go away again?

It abolishes the par value of shares. It reduces the need for shareholder approval in relation to financial assistance transactions. It reduces the costs in relation to annual reports. It extends from 14 days to 21 days the notice period for shareholder meetings. There is a range of other mechanical improvements to the way companies in Australia operate.

A number of people have tried to use this as an omnibus bill to put all these directors' duties and corporate governance matters into a bill that was not designed to do so. The government recognises the importance of the consideration of directors' duties and corporate governance. It picked up the work of Senator Cooney's committee on these issues in the late 1980s and the work of the joint parliamentary committee in the early 1990s on the same issues, and picked up a public demand for focusing on directors' duties and corporate governance. We have dealt with that as one of the largest and biggest chapters in the corporate law economic reform program which is recognised by people such as Bob Baxt and Bill Beerworth, and most commentators on corporate law reform, as the single most thorough reform of company law policy in the history of companies in Australia.

Within the six chapters of the corporate law economic reform program we have significant reforms encompassed in a specific piece of legislation designed to deal with directors' duties and corporate governance. That legislation has been referred to the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Corporations and Securities. All of the proposals that the government has in regard to directors' duties and corporate governance have been referred to that committee.

I have said to the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats that if they want organisations to make submissions in relation to the issues that are the bulk of the amendments we will be faced with shortly in the committee stage, then the appropriate legislative process is to allow industry, share holder groups, consumer groups, directors, institutions, corporate lawyers, accountants and other advisers to make submissions on these proposals and have any of these amendments dealt with after that public consultation.

Within the proposals on corporate governance that have been tacked onto this bill there are a number of matters that have been given that consideration. The MD&A proposal has been given that consideration by the joint committee and has been discussed at length amongst experts in this field.

The issue of the notice periods for meetings has again had long discussion and it is really just a decision between 14, 21 or 28 days, and a couple of the other proposals. Many of them have not been given that sort of rigorous analysis, which all of the corporate law proposals that this government has dealt with have been put through. They have been brought in here and clearly have not been given the opportunity for detailed consideration.

That is not to say that no-one has the right to do that. They do, but I am suggesting that, when we have a bill that specifically deals with corporate governance issues, we should seek to amend that bill rather than tacking them on and making this into an omnibus bill. You would obviously have to wait a few weeks to do that.

Those calls have gone unheeded. We had a speech from Senator Conroy saying that the government does not care about corporate governance and management discussion analysis; that we are opposed to it and that we are opposed to directors' remuneration disclosure. That is patently absurd and patently incorrect and significantly misleading.

talk.start.para: —Let's vote to mandate them.

—Senator Conroy interjects and says, `Let's vote to mandate them.' This draws the distinction of the approach of the Australian Labor Party and the Australian Democrats. That is, if you want to prove that you are serious about something, you come to Canberra, pass a law and impose it on every single person in Australia. That proves you are serious about it. Regardless of the fact that that has proved in jurisdictions around the world to be an ineffective way to create an improvement in corporate governance, that is the Labor Party way—Canberra knows best on corporate governance.
—And the Fin Review's view!

—Allow me to be partisan in these matters for a minute, Mr Acting Deputy President, because Senator Conroy wants to make this a politically partisan debate. This is the Australian Labor Party that produced Joan Kirner; this is the Australian Labor Party that produced Brian Burke; this is the Australian Labor Party that produced the Bank of South Australia; this is the Australian Labor Party that produced the famous gold tax lunch; and they are saying that the Australian Labor Party knows best on corporate governance!

speech.para: This is the Australian Labor Party that sunk $12.2 billion worth of Australian taxpayers' money down the drain every year, year after year for 10 years; and this is the Australian Labor Party whose concept of corporate governance and financial management was to run interest rates up to 30 per cent. When the Australian Labor Party talks about corporate governance and says, `Canberra knows best,' I say to the shareholders of Australia, `Beware when the Australian Labor Party says Canberra knows best.' There are far better experts on matters of corporate governance than the Australian Labor Party, which is saying, `You govern companies well when you do it the way Canberra tells you to do it; when you do it the way the Australian Labor Party tells you to do it.'

There are experts, and I refer to an article by Paul Murnane in the Business Review Weekly of 27 April last. Mr Murnane is from Russell Reynolds in Australia and he has done a comparative analysis of corporate governance in Great Britain, the United States, Europe and France. I will quote from that article because it is instructive:
The Australian Labor Party says Australian corporate governance is in tatters and that Canberra has to come in and tell us how to govern our companies.

He is saying it is a mess and we have to step in, even though all of the people who support MD&A, including the government, say the best way to do it is through a flexible, market oriented approach promoting best practice through the existing rules. The Labor Party says, `No, that is not good enough. We are going to tell you how to do it. We are going to put it in black letter law, write a few more pages of law and tell every reporting entity that they must do an MD&A because the Labor Party in Canberra knows best.' If you tick that box, it will be good corporate governance, according to the ALP.

Russell Reynolds in Australia put it slightly differently. They say that the standard of corporate governance in Australia compares well with other countries. Mr Murnane goes on to say it is a fact that:
. . . most companies have complied with high standards. All around the world you are seeing a strong push towards the Anglo-American style of governance.

Australia has a more aggressive stance on governance than other countries. Australia has had non-executive chairmen forever, whereas the US is only just discovering it. We have got a fairly smallish market so you don't get the chance to do the `Wall Street walk' . . . Institutional investors in Australia have set high standards for corporate governance.
He makes another point about corporate governance. He further states:
Corporate governance initiatives are distinct from legislation in that they are designed to assure investors that the necessary conditions of trust are in place.

In other words, the debate on corporate governance should be about promoting best practice, not imposing it from the cold hand of Canberra and central governments. Senator Conroy interjected by saying, `Let's do what the US does.' What does the US do in relation to remuneration, management discussion and analysis? Senator Conroy is a bit like the Leader of the Opposition in the other place; he knows everything. He is omni-intelligent. He is the font of almost all wisdom on every issue. So what happens with MD&A in America? He wants to impose it by a law through Canberra saying, `Everyone is going to have an MD&A, regardless of whether it makes you a better corporate governor or not.' According to the Australian Labor Party, through the wise mouth of Senator Conroy opposite, that is going to make you a good corporate governor.

What happens in the United States is that it is done through the listing rules of the SEC. What do we want in Australia? We want to do it through the listing rules of the Australian Stock Exchange? Who wants to do it through the listing rules of the Australian Stock Exchange? Senator Conroy mentioned the Securities Institute of Australia, which he says is opposed to the coalition's stance on management discussion and analysis. This is indicative of the entire debate. Labor wants to put it in black-letter law, impose it from Canberra and not allow a dynamic corporate governance culture to develop in Australia. They want to do it from Canberra. In fact, you have to do it from Canberra, not because we, the industry, shareholders or consumers think it is a good idea but because a fund manager from Florida says that it is a good idea—corporate governance international. We are going to be told what to do not by Australians and Australian shareholders but by people in Europe and New York.

One of the amendments states that we have to force companies to do what the SEC or Brussels tells us to do, not what we decide in Sydney or Melbourne or Brisbane or Perth or Adelaide or Hobart. We have to do what Brussels or New York tell us to do. Talk about throwing away sovereignty! Let us not go down to see the ASX or the SFE; let us go to New York and do what Arthur Leavitt tells us to do. I would like to keep control of what companies in Australia are required to report. The Securities Institute of Australia agree with this. Let me quote from a letter dated 29 May signed by John Jarrett, the National Policy Manager of the SIA:

The Securities Institute of Australia has long been in support of the requirement for listed companies to report to their shareholders, an MD&A requirement. We are satisfied that the introduction of this requirement into the listing rules with your agreement will be an advance on current reporting requirements. With this in mind, if the listing rules provide for MD&A, we do not believe it is neces sary at this stage to include it in a legislative requirement.

Who else agrees with us? Who was the person who proposed MD&A going into the law? It was AIMA. The people responsible at AIMA have endorsed the approach of the ASX—that is, do what they are doing in the United States: make it part of the listing rules. The Investment and Financial Services Association, which represents the big fund managers whom Senator Conroy quotes, says that it would be better if it were in the listing rules than in the black-letter law.

Finally, who else says that it should be in the listing rules and not the black-letter law? The Australian Shareholders Association says that it would be wrong to put it in the black-letter law if it can be done through listing rules. So you have every single organisation saying that it is better to do it through the ASX listing rules, but the ALP and the Democrats know better. They say, no, if you want good corporate governance, you have to do all these things in the black-letter law. That is what this debate has come down to. The government believes that almost every single organisation is saying, `No, do not put it in the black-letter law,' and most organisations are saying, `Let's have a debate about corporate governance under the corporate governance bill. Let's not slow up the progress of sound reforms in CLRB by having the debate today, let's do it after proper consultation.' But the Australian Labor Party know better. They say we have to do all these things because we want to beat up about directors' remuneration.

There is nothing wrong with a legal requirement to report directors' remuneration. There is one in the law already. What we are talking about is increasing it. It may well be that that is a very good idea, but we want to allow the interested parties—the stakeholders—to have a say in how you do it. Labor and the Democrats will not allow it to go to the committee. They will not even allow Australian shareholders to have a say on it. They know best; Canberra knows best. Impose it on everyone else.

I turn to the final support. As mentioned by Senator Margetts yesterday in another debate, the OECD did a report on corporate governance in Australia and absolutely, uncategorically endorsed the government's approach, saying that it is better to encourage a dynamic corporate governance culture than to impose prescription. I commend the bill to the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

subdebate.1.para: The bill.

talk.start.para: —I want to return to some of the issues I was discussing briefly earlier and also address a couple of other issues that I believe this committee and this bill should be addressing. Senator Campbell has given a spirited defence of the government's inaction on these issues. I welcome a lecture from the creature of Noel Crichton-Browne and the organisation that never forgave the current Prime Minister for introducing bottom-of-the-harbour schemes, that had a party president who belongs in gaol for defrauding shareholders in Elders. But if Senator Campbell feels that he can give us a lecture about corporate governance and the need for this country to have watered down corporate governance, then time and history will judge him.

speech.para: In particular, I want to talk about mandatory electronic lodgment. As I have said, some of these issues are very, very insignificant, one being whether or not a company has the option to use electronic lodgment, for instance, of proxy votes, or whether or not there should be a requirement for shareholders to have access to electronic lodgment. This would not seem to be a substantial issue of difference, you would think. Apparently, what the Labor Party and the institutional shareholders of this country think is a matter of some philosophical note and should be a matter of significant debate in the parliament.

It is the Labor Party's position that electronic lodgment should be mandatory so that, when shareholders would like to lodge a proxy form by fax with a company not having provided the required details, it is mandatory for the company to do so—not that the company has an option. It would not seem to be much to expect a company to have some form of access to electronic lodgment—a fax machine, e-mail—but apparently the government is saying that it should be an option of management. I say that it should be mandatory for shareholders to have access to electronic lodgment.

I would hope that at the end of the day the government will be willing to be flexible on this issue or at least give some argument as to why it should not be. That argument should not comprise the sorts of answers that the departmental officials and the government have given twice when appearing before the corporations and securities committee—`It's not time; it's not appropriate; we don't want to force these things from Canberra on companies.'

This is not Canberra forcing anything on anyone. This is what is in the editorial of the Financial Review—these are the investment houses, these are the institutional shareholders, the very people that the parliamentary secretary has spent the last six months doing the bidding of. They wanted MIB. They wanted it passed. They have been desperate. Watching the behaviour of the parliamentary secretary, you will have noticed that he has been desperate to accommodate them.

We have those people turning around and saying, `We would like; we believe it is necessary for good corporate governance'—institutional shareholders, not the Labor Party, not Canberra imposing. We are moving these amendments with the support of IFSA, with the support of institutional shareholders, with the support of international corporate governance bodies. This is not Canberra imposing. These are shareholders' institutions saying, `This is what we would like. We would like you to do this because companies aren't doing these things at the moment. They're not giving us the required information for us to make judgments about directors' behaviour.' This is not a Canberra driven thing. This is coming from shareholders, from their representatives.

I mentioned earlier today the issue of proxy voting and the disclosure question. If we have a situation—and I think Senator Murray has covered this very well in his minority report—where only one person in a shareholders' meeting knows how the proxies have been cast but does not have to reveal it, we have to ask ourselves `Why aren't the other shareholders entitled to know how proxy shareholders have voted?'—not individually, just the totals. The chair is allowed to know how people voted individually, but only the chair. Why is this the case?

If the president of a trade union sat at the front of a meeting and said, `I've got all these proxies and I'm not going to tell you how they have voted,' what would be the government's response? It would be outraged. It would say that it was undemocratic. That is what is at the nub of this: the democratic processes inside corporations. You have a situation where a shareholder goes to the trouble of turning up at a meeting of their company. Mind you, there is no point if you are at the Essendon Football Club. They will just tell you, `We're not going to answer any questions on a significant issue'—but it is a company.

talk.start.para: —Who is the No. 1 ticket holder at Essendon?

—Who is the No. 1 ticket holder at Essendon? It is the Treasurer. You can see why the government is beginning to take some of its positions. It supports corporate entities—and that is what footy clubs are nowadays—saying, `We're not going to answer any questions on whether or not the information that was posted out to you was accurate or right, or on any other issues.' So you can see where the government has come from on these issues. It does not want a better corporate democracy suddenly running around, that is right.

speech.para: But if a trade union has to reveal this information, why not a corporation? Why don't we say that you have to declare what the totals are, just so that shareholders can be confident there has not been a mistake? Why the need for secrecy? If you are able to say, `This many shareholders voted this way, and this many voted that way,' you have transparency. There cannot be a mistake because everybody will know; everybody can check.

But an honest mistake could happen, and here is an opportunity to ensure that an honest mistake cannot happen. There is always the possibility for a dishonest mistake to occur—though `mistake' is probably the wrong word. But why is the chair the only person entitled to know?

One of the issues that is fundamental to shareholders is how the votes are cast at a meeting. You have a situation where a shareholder may want to have more than just a decision on voices or a show of hands. They may want a poll. The poll may give a different outcome from the voices or the show of hands. But the shareholder cannot know whether or not the proxy votes have been cast in a particular direction.

This goes to the heart of democratic process in a corporation. A shareholder is entitled to call for a poll if he believes that a poll would give a different outcome from the vote on the floor. But how can a shareholder actually know? The directors and chair sitting up the front holding the proxies know that, if the vote goes a particular way that they are not happy with, they have the proxies that can actually change that and they can say, `Let's have a poll,' because they know what is in the chair's hand. But the ordinary individual small shareholder does not know what the proxies show, so how can they make an informed judgment about whether or not to call for a poll? This is a ludicrous situation. If a shareholder is unhappy with the decision on the show of hands or the voices, they are entitled to call for a poll if they think the result would be changed by the poll including the proxies, but they are not to know how the proxies voted. This is an absurdity. This is undemocratic, and it is information that should be available to individual small shareholders.

Another substantial issue is the question of the role of independent directors. We had a very recent example where an independent director blew the whistle on what the independent director believed was poor corporate governance: the incapacity of the major shareholders to act in accordance with the laws about whether all shareholders' interests were being taken into account by the direc tors, who were the majority shareholders, or major shareholders; I should not say `majority shareholders' because they would not necessarily make up a majority of the shareholders. At the end of the day the independent director had no recourse, despite believing that agreements had been made on governance issues, that separations of interests were taking place, other than to resign and issue an oblique letter on his resignation saying that he believed corporate governance issues were at stake.

What was the company? It will come as no shock to anybody listening today, anyone in the gallery or members of the chamber that I am talking about Crown Casino. Crown Casino is one of the worst examples of major shareholders mistreating the minor shareholders. You have seen Lloyd Williams and Ron Walker—we had a lecture from Senator Campbell, when Ron Walker, the bagman from the Victorian Liberal Party and the national Liberal Party, has the whistle blown on him about the lack of corporate governance. This is the man who tramps around the country saying, `We saw you gave $10,000 to the New South Wales Labor Party. We expect a similar amount in Victoria.'

talk.start.para: —$10 million.
—Plus a bit.
—Or else.

—Absolutely. He is explicit about his behaviour when it comes to raising funds. The bagman for the Victorian and federal Liberal Party had the whistle blown on him not just by any independent director but by a current staffer of the Prime Minister. This is not a Labor Party plot here; this is an employee of John Howard, the Prime Minister of this country, an independent director of Crown Casino, resigning over corporate governance issues. He believed that Ron Walker and Lloyd Williams were incapable of understanding corporate governance. What were his options: resign and issue a letter. That was it. One of these amendments today allows an independent director to requisition a meeting. How quickly do you think Ron Walker and Lloyd Williams would have been at the bargaining table in the directors' meeting if they thought Brian Powers as an independent director could have called a meeting of shareholders to discuss the issues of the directors.
—This is irrelevant.

—It is not irrelevant. This is about whether an independent director has the right to call a meeting of shareholders when they are unhappy. That is the whole role of an independent director: not to act on behalf of the major shareholders but to try to ensure that minor, small shareholders get their say.
—And that the public interest is represented.

—And to ensure that the public interest is represented. Here is a perfect opportunity for situations like this to be eradicated. The bargaining power of an independent director is substantially enhanced. They are given some teeth. They are not just put on the board for show. You have got a whole bunch of show independent directives. Nick Greiner: wasn't he a Liberal Premier? Nick Greiner is one of the most appointed show pony independent directors, and I say that because of what happened at Coles Myer. He is a show pony of an independent director. Corporate governance was nonexistent at Coles Myer. Nick Greiner was a supposed independent director. This amendment gives power and teeth to genuine independent directors. That is what this amendment is about. I will return to those issues a little later in the day.
—Oh, good.

—Thank you, Senator. Another issue on which an amendment is being moved today is the disclosure of information available to overseas markets. You would have thought that, if a company is required to supply information to an overseas market, they would have been willing to make the same information available to the Australian market. It may be that there are different requirements, but this is hardly an onerous, costly exercise. I think it would probably amount to an envelope and a stamp. `Here is this information we gave the US markets. We do not have to give it here.' But, if they did, they would just have to make a photocopy, put it in envelope, put a stamp on it and send it to the Australian market. (Time expired)

—These amendments which are to be considered today really need to be addressed in totality to begin with, in view of the quite surprising remarks of the parliamentary secretary. In his address to the Senate, he indicated everything which is wrong with the coalition attitude to government and to the people of Australia. He was exhibiting an arrogance and an elitism which, quite frankly, the entire community is sick of. They do not want to believe that a government which is a minority in the House of Representatives, with 53 per cent of the population voting against the coalition, and a minority in the Senate, with 56 per cent of the people voting against the coalition in the Senate, does not want those 53 per cent and those 56 per cent to be heard.

speech.para: Their view is that this matter requires representatives of the government to sit down with the representatives of the managerial class or the directors' class—with particular elites—and come to a conclusion; and then we should all accept that as the decision which we must abide by. Frankly, there are other members of the managerial class and the directors' class of ordinary shareholders and ordinary Australians who do not agree, and that is why this debate is not non-controversial. That is why it is before the representatives of the people to debate appropriately. The fact that you approach it with a different philosophy is entirely correct.

talk.start.para: —I am asking you to go out and consult like I have.

—I will come to that. You will have your opportunity to reply. The fact is that the government has gone out there to consult with many people who sit them down to nice boardroom lunches and say, with a nod and a wink, `Once you have got this through, chaps, don't forget we will be donating to you, as we did last time. You know we are on your side.' I think the worst thing the coalition can be pinned with is that it is business's lap-dog or toy boy.
—Toy boy?
—Sometimes. I hope that is an unfair allegation, but the problem is: when you state that you want your bill to go through, indisputably—

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I raise a point of order. I regard it as an inference and a reflection on me to suggest that I would sit down in a boardroom and say, `You put this bill through and we will donate to your party,' and then to imply that I am a toy boy. I regard that as contrary to standing orders. Not only is it a reflection but it is reflection that is based on no fact. I can say on the parliamentary record that I have never been made an offer of that kind by anybody in my life, and I would ask Senator Murray to withdraw that immediately. It is totally beneath him.

—I am pleased to hear that, Madam Temporary Chairman, and I withdraw the inference. The problem for us all is that if you attack the very credibility and grounds on which those who oppose your views present themselves, the inclination is to ask, `Why would somebody want this to be presented as a non-controversial bill? Why would somebody want to avoid debate in the people's house?' The purpose of a parliament is to consider all issues.
—I have never said that. You should retract that as well. You know that.

—That was my understanding of your earlier address. You were saying that the Labor Party, the Democrats and whoever else has put up points of view on this bill are wrong and that they should not have brought it before you.
—I said you should refer your amendments to a committee and allow people to discuss them.
—Let us respond to that again.

speech.para: Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! We are going to have a long debate if there is all this interjecting.

interjection.para: Senator Ian Campbell interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I do not think the parliamentary secretary is assisting in continuing this debate. We would all be assisted if Senator Murray were allowed to continue but Senator Murray should, where possible, avoid making statements that are going to aggravate the debate in the chamber at this time.

—Madam Temporary Chairman, I accept your admonition but members of this Senate know that it is very seldom that I am drawn to intemperate language; very seldom indeed. I was drawn to this intemperate language—and the inferences which I have withdrawn—by an extraordinary outburst, as I saw it, from the parliamentary secretary. It is appropriate that this bill is controversial, it is appropriate that amendments are before the House and it is appropriate that they are discussed. The fact that the parliamentary secretary has an alternative point of view does not entitle him, in my view, to lash out at the credibility, the motives or the consultative processes of those who do not agree with him.

speech.para: The parliamentary secretary must surely recognise that he, his advisers and the government will not be right on every single thing every single time. The fact is that these bills and this process have been through two parliamentary committees and we have had a number of hearings on them. As a result of those hearings an alternative point of view was expressed by substantial numbers of professional and able organisations and individuals, and some of those positions have been adopted by both ourselves and the Labor Party.

The other point is that the persons participating in this debate are not lacking in experience. I, for one, have worked and lived as an executive in four countries on three continents. I have been a director of many boards and I understand business life. I have been involved in business life for over 25 years, including on my own account as an entrepreneur. We do not enter this debate from a position of ignorance.

The other point I want to make clear to you is that the problem, for both the Labor Party and for us, is that we have to deal with the fact of the law as it is at present and the fact of the bill that is before us. Because we have to deal with the fact of the law and the bill we cannot deal with any future promises the government is making as to how it will deal with things. Because the electoral cycle is such, there is going to be an election shortly. The government may change. If the government stays the same, we are advised that its main priority will be tax reform. We do not know what will overtake the priorities of this Senate and this parliament and this government. In that case, the corporate governance and accountability changes and reforms, which we regard as absolutely critical to the health of our corporations, to the health of our society and to the fabric of our economy, may well be delayed until late 1999. That is what happens with government—other priorities and other matters overtake them.

The parliamentary secretary has an endearing characteristic—he is often over-optimistic about when bills will come through and how quickly they will be resolved. We all think that is a commendable characteristic, but it is not rooted in reality or in history. The history of his predictions as to the length of time taken in debates or whether bills will come up is, generally speaking, overtaken by events. That is not his fault, but it is a fact. This bill was rapidly and urgently considered by the parliamentary committee in March. Senator Conroy is aware of that because he attended those hearings—he sat with me at them. We worked posthaste to get out that committee report. I think it was only two weeks from the beginning of the reference to the very substantial report being tabled. That was in March. Here we are in late June and the bill is finally before us. That is a fact of life.

I accept, Parliamentary Secretary, that the government is attending to the issues of corporate governance and accountability. I have read your government's proposals on it. There are many good issues within it. But I firmly believe that the only chance we are going to have to deal with corporate governance and accountability matters is now. I expect that the next chance will be in late 1999. We think, on our side of the House—and hopefully other senators will agree with us—that these matters are urgent enough to be dealt with at once. It is your right to disagree. It is your right to have an alternative philosophy. It is not your right, in my view, to impugn the very real and genuine concerns that we have. Before I close, I again indicate that the extravagance of Senator Campbell's earlier remarks has occasioned me to respond in kind, which is unusual for me. I did withdraw, and I particularly withdraw any personal inference to Senator Campbell himself.

talk.start.para: —What we heard from Senator Campbell in the concluding remarks he made on the Company Law Review Bill 1997 reflected a significant double standard by this government in its approach to two critical areas. My colleague Senator Conroy quite rightly drew the attention of the Senate chamber to the issue relating to the accountability mechanisms that shareholders should be able to exercise.

speech.para: Senator Campbell represents a government which regularly rails against trade unions and makes various allegations, firstly about the way they operate and, secondly, about pay and conditions outcomes. The government regularly calls for intervention and improvement in practices and accountability. My colleague Senator Conroy quite rightly drew attention to the claims that are continually made by government members, by Liberal-National Party members, about behaviour in trade unions. Senator Campbell's contribution endorsed all sorts of potential and practised misbehaviour that goes on in some companies in this country.

Shareholders own companies. They have a right to know. There will always be occasions where some shareholders are on the losing end of the debate and they vote. But they do have a fundamental right to know how votes are being cast. It is a fundamental tenet. They do own the company, after all. They do have a right to know. That sort of principle is very important to the Australian Labor Party and, I would have thought, very important to this Liberal-National Party government, which is continually, and I think unfairly, railing against what it regards as a lack of accountability in the trade union movement.

The second area is the area of executive remuneration. Again, we have a double standard. I recall the contribution of Minister Reith when criticising the remuneration of waterside workers. Minister Reith made it very clear that the average pay of waterside workers was too high and should be reduced to the community norm. I said at the time that that was an interesting principle for a government to be adopting. If the average remuneration of waterside workers is $70,000, $80,000 or $90,000—the government members seem to vary that level according to particular circumstances—at least we know what they earn.

Here we have a government today saying, `Shareholders do not have a right to know as a matter of course what the executives in a company are earning.' It is a clear case of double standards by Senator Campbell. It may well be that executives are entitled to a substantial remuneration and, at the end of the day, shareholders can determine that through a vote at annual general meetings and other occasions. Shareholders have a right to know what the information is.

We have a number of celebrated cases of executive pay that are not linked in any way, shape or form to the performance of the company. In 1989-90, Elders IXL managed to increase its executive remuneration package by 23 per cent.

talk.start.para: —What about the AIDC?
—I hear some noise from the other side. We have had an appeal from the government to be cooperative and to get this legislation through.
—Why are you filibustering?

—I am not filibustering. We had a rant and rave from you, Senator Campbell, for 15 or 20 minutes. I am not going to take anywhere near that time. I am just pointing out to the chamber the double standard that you adopted.

speech.para: I was saying that, in 1989-90, Elders IXL managed to increase its executive remuneration package by 23 per cent. That was a pretty big wage increase. It certainly made the wharfies look like they were in the poor house. Interestingly, at the same time as that remuneration package went up by 23 per cent, what happened to operating profit? It dropped by 80 per cent. There may or may not have been good reasons for that sort of executive remuneration outcome, but shareholders have a right to know what executives are paid and they have a right to make judgment. If you do not know what an executive is paid, it is very difficult for shareholders to make a judgment.

The Age—and I will say this because it was a sad reflection on my home state of Tasmania—described the salary package of a chief executive of Tabcorp as roughly twice the gross domestic product of Tasmania. I think that was a bit of an exaggeration and somewhat flippant but, in 1997, his salary was over $1 million and his shares had increased in value to such an extent that he was adding an additional $10 million to his salary. The simple point, and the simple principle which is very important to Labor, is that people may or may not be entitled to these sums of money, but shareholders are entitled to know it is being paid so they can examine whether that level of remuneration is appropriate. There are numerous other examples, but I am not going to take the time of the Senate.

I will conclude by saying that that was a very poor contribution from Senator Campbell. Senator Campbell continues to appeal for cooperation in passing legislation. We got a rant and rave from him which we have to respond to. It was an amazing set of double standards from him with respect to the rights of shareholders and executive pay. I notice we are broadcasting today. We were left wondering whether it was a last ditch appeal to the preselectors in WA to boost him up the Senate ticket.

talk.start.para: —I have already been preselected.
—Have you? You have been preselected. Noel Crichton-Browne has given you the nod. We would like to know what position you have on the ticket.

speech.para: On no less than 12 or 13 occasions, we had the allegation that Canberra is imposing. That was just an excuse for attempting to rebut Labor's and the Democrats' quite legitimate criticisms of your legislation. On another occasion—a last gasp after Canberra is imposing—we had an allegation that we were doing the bidding of advisers from the United States. That is not the sort of contribution that is going to assist in the passage of this legislation. We have taken advice from a range of Australian organisations, companies and shareholders on this matter.
Senator Campbell quoted a letter from the Securities Institute of Australia. He read out part of it, but I think he quite deliberately left out the last sentence of the last paragraph.

talk.start.para: —Incorporate the entire letter.
—I will read the last paragraph in full. If you would just calm down over there, we would get somewhere with this legislation. You quoted from the letter. The last sentence says:

speech.para: However, we believe the record of compliance by listed companies with the requirement should be reviewed within two years of its introduction. Of course, if the review shows a poor record of compliance, the need for a legislative requirement would need to be revisited.
