I think you quite deliberately missed that section of the letter from the Securities Institute of Australia.

Let us move on to this legislation. By all means, let us get it passed as expeditiously as possible. Let us examine the legislation in the necessary detail. Let us have the appropriate level of accountability with respect to shareholders, executive remuneration and a number of other issues that Labor regards as being very fundamental. Let us avoid the overblown rhetoric and the poor excuse for the hypocrisy and double standards of this government. Let us get into this legislation.

Senator Campbell, we saw Senator Kemp come in and instruct you to stop wasting time. Labor just asked for cooperation. We want to cooperate. We want to get the government program through. Being unnecessarily provocative and, at times, irrelevant—with the poor level of excuse for the double standards you have adopted in this legislation—does not help the cause of getting legislation through the Senate. When the Prime Minister complains and alleges that the Senate is being obstructionist, we will remind him of your role in wasting the Senate's time.

talk.start.para: —This is a very important debate. People have been accused of listening to others and of being in board rooms. I do not think there is any truth in that and there is probably little merit in making those allegations. The reality is that this is important legislation and we ought to look at it in terms of that importance. This sort of debate has taken place again and again over the years and will take place again in the future. There is one thing you can be certain of: there will be debates about the issues we are talking about again and again in the future in the Senate because company law is a living organism. It goes on and on and requires debate just as the life of companies goes on an on in an organic way.

speech.para: I would like to quote something here from the speech I referred to before from the former member for Hawker, Ralph Jacobi, on 12 May 1981. That was before the excesses of the 1980s. He said:

Company law must establish a solid framework which defines a company's responsibility to its shareholders, creditors and the society. Beyond question, the coming decade will bring ever-increasing pressure to bear; it will test these laws to the limit. Regrettably, these Bills fail to meet the test. They will be inadequate and, as a consequence, ineffective. Once can only describe them as completely outmoded. Even worse, they serve as nothing more than a charter for the unscrupulous. This so-called revamped companies law is almost the same as that in the laissez-faire Britain of the nineteenth century. Where are the profound and meaningful changes? Members of companies, particularly large companies, take little part in company affairs. Those members are poorly placed, and the provisions in these bills make sure that shareholders do not receive the information about their companies that would enable them to act as watchdogs on management. A classic example of that is the collapse of Associated Securities Ltd. Nothing in this legislation will remedy that situation.
That quote is now over 17 years old, but it has resonance for the present.

It is important that we remember a few things. Firstly, the sorts of issues that we are talking about today do not arise because people have talked to particular interest groups; they arise because they are endemic to company life and to company law. Secondly, they do need proper and deep consideration because the sort of quote I have just given will be pertinent in future debates. Thirdly, society itself, company law and those in company life, including shareholders and directors, deserve to have us get it as right as we can. If that takes a bit of time in debate, then so be it.

talk.start.para: —I want to return to the issue that I was speaking on briefly before my time ran out. That was to do with the disclosure of information available to overseas markets. I am still to hear a credible reason from the government and from any of their officials for their problem with information that is required by overseas markets also being made available to Australian markets and Australian shareholders. It seems to me that this is really a case of a government just digging in and refusing to introduce a reform that is not being requested by the Labor Party but by the investment community. It seems absurd that information about a company in which you are a shareholder is more freely available in America or in Europe than it is in Australia. This is an extraordinary state of affairs. If you can get on the Internet and access information on the US markets and you can find out more about your company through the Internet on US markets than you can on Australian markets, it says something about transparency and disclosure in this country.

speech.para: Senator Campbell, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, has talked about how we are trying to impose this. I draw his attention again to the Financial Review on Wednesday, 1 April, and to an article entitled `Corporate Oligarchy'. I have already read some of the points in but I would like to finish off with the last couple of paragraphs in this editorial. It says:

Essentially, the CLRB style of approach aims to be investor-friendly—for instance, by more clearly mandating how companies should keep their shareholders properly informed. By contrast, the CLERP legislation being pushed by the Treasurer, Mr Peter Costello, aims to make life easier for companies on the basis that, in a competitive corporate market, what's good for the companies is good for their shareholders.
The last thing this newspaper—this is the Financial Review , not `Labor Herald' and not the Age —wants is more black-letter law mandating how boards should run their companies.

talk.start.para: —Hear, hear!
—Hear, hear! The Labor Party is supporting the thrust of what the government has been doing. The last sentence reads:

speech.para: But if Australia's company directors won't even reveal how many votes they were elected by, they will only have themselves to blame if they find that a new law has landed squarely on their heads.

The Financial Review is arguing that the reforms and the amendments that the opposition and the Democrats are putting forward are necessary for accountability and transparency. That is what the Labor Party and the Democrats and, hopefully, the Greens and other senators, will be saying to the investment community and to investment houses: `We support your call for these amendments. We support the call for greater scrutiny by shareholders of their corporate behaviour and of directors' behaviour.' As the Financial Review has clearly stated, there is a difference between what is in a company's and the directors' best interests and what is in the shareholders' best interests.

Hopefully, in all cases they do not diverge but there are too many examples otherwise. Senator Sherry quoted a perfect example where Elders' remuneration packages were substantially increased at the same time as its very executives were defrauding their shareholders to the tune of over $100 million with bogus foreign exchange transactions and hiding the beneficial ownership of bonds which bought themselves shares in Elders. This was all at the same time as they were increasing substantially by 23 per cent their own remuneration. Maybe at the time Mr Elliott, Mr Scanlon and the rest of the management team at Elders deserved the 23 per cent increase. It may be that that is the case. What is relevant is whether the shareholders of Elders had a chance to pass judgment on that and had a chance to actually know that was happening.

talk.start.para: —They only own the company!

—That is right, Senator Sherry: they do only own the company and it seems a little impertinent of them to want to know what they are paying the chief executive. But there are a number of other organisations and people also displaying double standards in today's debates about these issues. Firstly, the parliamentary secretary is critical, saying that Senator Murray and others—me perhaps—have not done enough consultation. This is a process that has been alive for three or four years. As Senator Murray has indicated, we did our utmost at the government's request to speed through the inquiry. We were not happy; we believed that more time was needed. We were urged—in fact, implored—by the government to hold a hasty inquiry, to limit the time in which the submissions on these bills could be put in, and to quickly have them ready before Easter.
—It is now the winter solstice.

—That is exactly right. We are near the end of the financial year. We are nearing an election. If there is criticism for a lack of consultation, it is because we were too cooperative with the government in working to your timetable, Parliamentary Secretary, to try to assist your legislative program. For you to come into the chamber to accuse us of not consulting is the height of a double standard, because we sacrificed some consultation, some of the open process, to assist you. We were not happy about it but we did it. We recognised the need.

speech.para: This government is continuing to try to hide the remuneration packages from public shareholder scrutiny. This is at the same time as it wants to run a publicity campaign about hidden taxes. It wants to say it is terrible to have all these hidden taxes, yet it is going to introduce a GST, which in most cases is a hidden tax unless it is actually stapled onto one's price docket when it comes out of a register. Everyone will have to change their registers if they are going to be able to actual ly state what the GST is, and not everyone is going to be able to do that.

So on one hand the government says hidden taxes are terrible but at the same time it wants to hide the remuneration of people like Stan Wallis who is in the papers this week championing the case against hidden taxes and charges.

talk.start.para: —Not the Burnie workers who were sacked.

—Not the Burnie workers whom he sacked, but I am sure he has told them the GST is going to get them their jobs back. I am sure, thanks to Stan Wallis—the head of Amcor who has just sacked those workers in Burnie—they are absolutely sure they are going to get their jobs back once a GST is introduced; there is no question about that. But Stan Wallis wants to walk around this country promoting the case against hidden taxes, yet his organisation and others, including this government, do not want to have to provide information to their own shareholders—their owners—about what their remuneration packages are.

speech.para: Senator Campbell also chose to make something of the fact that only one or two individuals had made submissions and had ever really discussed these issues. I say to the parliamentary secretary that, in the case of the MIB debate, only one or two individuals put in supporting submissions for MIB. There were many submissions—over 50 to the parliamentary committee—opposing MIB. But the parliamentary committee process does not weigh its deliberations on the basis of who can organise the most amount of submissions to be put into a committee. I think individual senators are smart enough to work out that, just because—

talk.start.para: —Remember Brighton?

—That is exactly right—the battlers of Brighton. Thank you, Senator Murray. The battlers of Brighton were up in arms about the trafficking in trust losses and the government certainly did not want to take any notice of them, thank goodness!

speech.para: Because only one or two people put in submissions on the corporate governance regime does not mean that their views are not valid. It does not mean that, just because they represent all the investment houses in the country through IFSA, their views are not relevant or should be discounted. If institutional shareholders are saying, `We want corporate governance,' they can choose to make one combined submission through IFSA—rather than 30 individual submissions—to prove that there is broad based support. I think the senators on that committee and in this chamber are just smart enough to understand that there is a broad push in the business community, evidenced by the Australian Financial Review's editorial and evidenced by debate that has been in the newspapers over these sorts of issues.

It is not that there has been no discussion, no consultation and no debate. Newspapers have been carrying articles with opinions one way and opinions the other way—just like with the MIB debate—for the last six months on this issue. We have had submissions and we have had parliamentary inquiries and the government says, `We are interested in corporate governance but you are doing it at the wrong time and the wrong place.'

I, like Senator Murray, am concerned that if we do not support these amendments today, which are about disclosure and transparency and democracy in corporations, we will not likely see them, if we are lucky, before 1999. Because of that, we will see less confidence in Australian markets and companies from investors around the world and in Australia. We have an opportunity to send a loud signal and to get world's best practice in corporate governance. Today provides the opportunity for government and senators to vote on whether we do want world's best practice, on whether we are going to allow the behaviour of some of our corporate executives in this country, which is now well documented, to continue, or whether we are going to see genuine reform.

The government could say to us, `This is the wrong bill. If you were to move some of these amendments to this other bill that we are looking at bringing in, we will give them favourable consideration or may even be willing to support them—it is possible.' But, Senator Campbell, the government has indi cated that it is not interested in the majority of these amendments—black letter law is what you were stressing before. You are saying, `Don't introduce them today; we will look at them next time. We are going to oppose them next time, but let's not debate them today.' No, today is the time to debate them. Today is the time to introduce world's best practice in corporate governance and to support what is being asked for by shareholders, not what is being opposed by company directors.

talk.start.para: —I take the point that has been made by Senator Conroy: this parliament should not decide issues on the basis of who can drum up the most faxes, letters, submissions to committees and so forth—all of those should be considered on their merits. I am hugely assisted by the work of the Senate committees on these matters. Each of those reports—both the majority and the minority reports—that deal especially with legislation are very important in my assessment of legislation such as this.

speech.para: I believe that there is goodwill around the chamber and that everyone would be very supportive of the measures that come before us in this company law area which do assist in ensuring that the shareholders are able to understand what is going on in the company and that there is complete transparency. I thought we were going to start with government amendment No. 1 and work through. I would like to congratulate the parliamentary secretary on the work that he has done, but I do feel, as do other senators, obviously, that it would be remiss of us if we did not put before the chamber matters which we feel would assist in providing shareholders with the necessary transparency provisions to enable them to keep a check of the company and become involved in the company.

For example, take some of the amendments proposed by Senator Murray. I do not support some of them; on others I need further clarification. His amendments 39 and 40 on the question of remuneration packages for directors—amendments on which discussion ranged in this debate—insert new paragraphs requiring the director's annual report to include details of remuneration packages for directors, senior directors and the five most highly remunerated officers of the company and related matters. Surely that is a measure which requires disclosures of matters which mean that the books and activities of the company are more transparent and that directors are more accountable to the shareholders. What is wrong with that? I would have thought that that would have received unanimous support around the chamber.

Another example is Senator Murray's amendment 17, which inserts a new provision which would require the chair of a meeting to inform the meeting about proxy votes received and how they are to be cast. This provision adds transparency to the treatment of proxy votes and forces disclosure when it may be in the chair's interest not to have disclosure. It surely would be appropriate to support this amendment. It seems logical and reasonable given the parameters within which we are working.

Senator Murray's amendment No. 34 again inserts a new paragraph which requires the directors' declaration in the annual financial report to include a declaration that the financial statement and notes comply with the accounting standards of section 296 and that they present a true and fair view as required by section 297. I am of the view that that new provision would be consistent with sections 296 and 297 of the Corporations Law and make the directors accountable in respect of the law. Again I see no real hassle about that. It improves the situation.

But some of the amendments I do not support. For example, amendment No. 14 which deletes subsection 250C(4). That subsection currently prohibits the sending of proxies by fax and email. Given that voting is often controversial and that many persons prefer the entire process, including proxies, to be kept as confidential and as closed as possible and given that it is also more difficult to verify signatures on faxes and it is not at all possible on emails, I am wondering whether Senator Murray thinks that that might not be a practical proposition. I would be interested to hear what he has to say about that when given the opportunity.

But overall I believe the amendments that are being proposed, including a key amendment proposed by the opposition, are worthy of consideration during this debate. I feel that we should deal with them as this is the opportunity to do so. Who knows when we will get another opportunity. I think Senator Sherry queried when we will get another opportunity to make these sorts of improvements. That is what this Senate is all about. We are a house of review. We seek not to harass the government and simply block its legislation; we attempt to exercise our review function in a responsible way. I believe we have the opportunity to do that to improve the company law and to do it in a manner that will be for the good of companies and their structures and for the benefit of the shareholders.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 1, page 15 (lines 17 to 24), omit subsection 5.2, substitute:
It is a replaceable rule (see 1.6) that shareholders may appoint directors by resolution at a general meeting.
[section 224C]
(4) Schedule 1, item 1, page 47 (table item 2), omit the table item.

If I may commence with a declaration—and this declaration will cover all the deliberations today and on this bill—I am a trustee of a trust which has company shares and those companies obviously would be affected by this bill. So I accordingly make a declaration.

talk.start.para: —For ease of handling and, hopefully, speed and not haste, I indicate the government will not oppose these Democrat amendments.
—Then I do not need to ask the questions. If the government is going to support this, there is no point in my asking questions about them.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 1 page 31 (after line 7), after paragraph (k), insert:
(ka) for a company limited by shares or an unlimited company, a statement that the written agreement referred to in subparagraph (k)(i)
(i) includes a summary of the rights and conditions attaching to the shares agreed to be taken up
(ii) sets out the total number of persons who have consented to be members and the information referred to in sub-paragraphs (k)(i) and (k)(ii)

(iii) contains a statement that, if a constitution has not been adopted, the Replaceable Rules will apply and that they create a contract between the members the terms of which may alter if the Replaceable Rules change after the company is registered

Parliamentary Secretary, I have, as you know, both with the bill yesterday, the Managed Investments Bill 1997 , and with this bill attempted to keep you, other senators and the official opposition in touch with my amendments. I think I circulated them five or six weeks ago. This one, however, is a late arrival. It was circulated yesterday. You would, therefore, I think need to hear my motivation for this amendment.

This amendment refers to new section 117, which deals with the application for registration of companies. New subparagraph (ka)(i) is intended to ensure that people who are proposing to take up shares in a new company are aware of the rights and conditions attached to those shares. One of the problems we face is that people are often not aware. At present when a company is formed, the new members sign the memorandum of association, which will now be referred to as a constitution, which sets out the rights attaching to each class of share.

New subparagraph (ka)(ii) is intended to make the members of a new company aware of who else will be members of their company and how many shares of each class of shares they will hold. This will allow the prospective members to confirm that the relative ownership of the company on its registration will be as they expect or have been led to believe. This requirement will reduce the chance that the promoter of a company may bring more members into the company than he or she has represented to the members and so dilute the ownership of those members. I will give you an example if I may. The reason I have brought it forward is that I think the example is almost trying to avoid a situation of fraud and misrepresentation and, therefore, deserves to be dealt with with some haste.

The example is this. The owner of a business whose goodwill is attached to a business name may be induced to relinquish the business name—and apparently this has happened—to allow a company to be formed in that name on the basis that he is to take up one share of $1 in return for assignment of his business to the company and on the basis that the applicant would also take up one share of $1 at a premium of $100,000 in cash. A former business owner who does this believes that he is taking on a single partner who is going to contribute $100,000—and that sounds terrific—to the business in return for half the equity, and that sounds perfectly reasonable.

The person entering into that agreement thinks that he or she understands exactly how that is happening. However, without his knowledge the applicant may also then bring in three more partners who take up a $1 share but with no premium payable. The former business owner may thus end up with four partners and only 20 per cent of the equity in the company on registration. It is a situation where, because the particular person has not foreseen the dangers, they become a minority in their own company simply because they have entered into a particular arrangement.

The purpose of this amendment is to fix that problem. At present, the memorandum of association, now to be called a constitution, which is signed by all members on formation of the company, sets out who the other subscribers are and what shares they are taking out. New paragraph (ka)(iii) is intended to ensure that members of the proposed company are aware of the existence and effect of the replaceable rules. In summary, the rationale for the proposed amendments is to provide essential information to prospective members of a new company so that those members can make an informed decision as to whether or not they wish to be involved in the formation of the company. The additional information which must be provided will result in relatively minor additions to the agreement to take up shares. The information will be in the hands of the promoter of the company and it will be merely a case of adding that information to the document.
Parliamentary Secretary, I have taken advice on this because this is an area where I am trying to deal with a fraudulent matter. I would appreciate your response.

talk.start.para: —I will have to take advice on this. It is the first time this matter has been brought to my attention. I cannot provide you with a response to that particular matter at the moment.

speech.para: The government's response is that this amendment would add a new piece of paper which would be required in the registration of a company. It is contrary to the thrust of the original Lavarch bill in that we are trying to ensure that company registration can be done on one sheet and lodged electronically with the ASC. In fact, the Financial Review estimated that, if there is a $1,000 saving per company, there potentially would be about a $1 billion saving to the companies of Australia by achieving this paperwork reduction.

Currently, companies have to lodge a range of different things—memorandum of association, registration forms and so forth. The approach that the previous government and Attorney-General took was to try to put the information onto one sheet and allow it to be lodged. This would conflict with that approach. I suspect, from the advice I have been given, that it may well be that to solve the problem Senator Murray raised—which I am sure is a serious concern—would mean using a sledgehammer to crack a nut. However, the advice I have got is that if this was done the philosophy of the Lavarch bill would be breached. In other words, single member companies and small business people would have to get professional assistance with their lodgments.

Under this bill, as it was formed by the previous government and the simplification task force, that professional assistance would not be needed. People would be able to register a company without legal and specialist advice. There is no doubt that this would significantly increase the cost of forming a company. I do not intend to call a division on this, but the government will be opposing it.

talk.start.para: —Parliamentary Secretary, if it is the will of the Senate not to pass this amendment, because it deals with an apparently potentially fraudulent practice, would you be agreeable, if I request you to do so, to refer that particular matter to the committee considering these issues so that they can examine both the problem and the remedy and conclude what is appropriate?
—I undertake to do so.
—I think that is an eminently desirable suggestion. I feel that the government would see it as such and will take it forward.
—Yes, the opposition agrees.

speech.para: Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: (2) Schedule 1, item 1, page 45 (line 8), omit "public".
(3) Schedule 1, item 1 page 45 (lines 16 to 18), omit all words after paragraph (b).
Thank you, Parliamentary Secretary, for that undertaking in relation to the previous amendment.

These amendments are very briefly construed. The effect of these two amendments is that changes to constitutions would be lodged by all companies, not just public companies, with the ASIC. The reason that we have moved this amendment is that many suppliers, when a company goes to them for a credit rating or an agreement to supply, will like to access the constitutions of companies to establish just what sort of corporate animal they are dealing with. Frequently they do so through appropriate agencies such Dun and Bradstreet. So, generally speaking, creditors would, in our opinion, need access to both private and public constitutions as registered with the ASIC. That is the motive for these amendments.

talk.start.para: —I might pose a question. Senator Campbell or Senator Murray might be able to inform us. We are concerned about the possible cost implications of this. I anticipate Senator Campbell might have some information. For quite small companies it may be totally unnecessary to be involved in the amount of paperwork and obviously the consequent cost. That is of concern to us. I am sure Senator Campbell has a view and Senator Murray can outline what he thinks the impact of his proposal will be.

—This is another classic example of the benefit of allowing exposure drafts of these laws. Probably I did not explain it as well as I should have in summing up the second reading debate. It is a real principle not to reduce the Senate's role in reviewing this legislation, or any company's legislation, but the corporations agreement, which sets up the national scheme, requires that company law reforms for most chapters of the law are exposed for three months before being introduced here in the first place. This exposure allows all interested parties and stakeholders—particularly shareholders and their representatives—to look at the impact of these laws.

speech.para: I do not want to set off another one-hour debate about this, but this is one of the reasons why significant amendments to the law, I humbly suggest, should be exposed for the same reasons as the law itself is exposed.

The original draft of the bill did require just this, but we had very strong representations from small business interests out of concern at the unnecessary nature and extent of the compliance costs for lodging these constitutions. Members of a company will be able to ask the company to give them a copy of its constitution within seven days. I refer Senator Murray to section 139 of the bill where that is a requirement. The ASC will also be able to require a company to lodge with the ASC a consolidated copy of its constitution, and that is picked up in section 138. The government believes this will be sufficient to address the exceptional case where it would be desirable for a copy of the constitution to be made available to the public.

Senator Sherry asked about the costs. One of the other reasons it was dropped was that the Australian Securities Commission told us that the requirement to hold the constitution would involve in excess of one million companies. We have not got a figure, but the cost of even storing that electronically would be horrendous. I am sure that the people at the information processing centre in Walwa would think it would be a great new line of business for them. It would certainly require a significant increase.

talk.start.para: —You could locate it in Tasmania.

—In Burnie; good idea. That is the concern. The constitution will be required to be available. The ASC can demand it. So, to answer Senator Murray's proposition, if a creditor came forward, asked to see the constitution and was able to say to the ASC that there was a breach, the ASC could demand a copy of the constitution. A member of the company can demand a copy of the constitution. They are available; they have to be available. But it is a matter of practicalities and costs for the regulator—and, therefore, the taxpayer—and again a cost to the small business interests who have been strongly opposed to this.

—To a certain extent some of the themes from last night's managed investment funds debate are re-emerging. The Greens (WA) opinion is that near enough is certainly not good enough when we are dealing with issues of accountability.

speech.para: The Democrats amendments Nos. 2 and 3 would make corporations, and not just public corporations, lodge special resolutions that adopted, changed or repealed the constitution—as well as the constitution and modified constitution—with the ASIC. We think it is a worthy amendment because it is based on the principles of transparency, accountability and investor protection.

Perhaps the Parliamentary Secretary could advise us: when incorporated bodies or corporations form their constitutions, what happens to the constitution of incorporated bodies and how many are there throughout Australia? Does the minister know?

talk.start.para: —I am informed that is regulated by the states. I understand it might vary from state to state. It is a matter for those regimes.

—The point I am trying to make is that some of these incorporated bodies have almost no money. The reality is that lodging a change in the constitution costs almost nothing for the actual corporation or the incorporated body and it is expected. As I say, teeny-weeny incorporated bodies and community based organisations lodge constitutions. Whether they do it with the states or the Commonwealth, the reality is that this is happening on a daily basis. It is part of accountability and people can take incorporated bodies to court based on changes or them not abiding by their constitutions.

speech.para: Why would we think it would be less important that the constitutions of bodies who are handling other people's money should not be dealt with at least as carefully, if not more carefully, than teeny-weeny, not-for-profit corporations, many of whom know that these kinds of rules exist on a daily basis? It is very hard to believe the government's logic here.

talk.start.para: —I just wanted to indicate that the concerns I raised about costs are valid. I do not want to hold us up too long. Senator Murray mentioned creditors in his contribution, and creditors needing to access information. Could you either repeat or clarify your comment in that regard?

—Senator Sherry, I think that those who have the greatest interest in corporate constitutions are those who have contractual relationships with them or who are potentially exposed to a liability—for example, groups such as banks, employees and suppliers. Obviously not every small employ ee is going to do it, but the union might want to know that a particular company is structured in a particular way. In my experience, generally speaking, those inquiries are conducted by professional organisations—your accountant or Dun and Bradstreet or somebody who does such things. Seldom do creditors, in my experience, go to the ASIC on their own and ask for those documents.

speech.para: Quite often those inquiries are made not secretly but not to the company concerned because the creditor—for reasons of discretion and to avoid embarrassment—will not necessarily tell the company that they are doing that sort of a check. In my experience that is how memorandum and articles have in the past been checked out and how constitutions will in future be checked out. The law, as I understand it, is that that process still applies for public companies. The question is whether it should apply to private companies as well.
Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (5) Schedule 1, item 4, page 69 (after line 3), before Chapter 2F, insert:

para.inline: 245A When is a corporate governance board required?

speech.para: (1) All listed corporations, which become listed after the commencement of this section, must establish a corporate governance board.
(2) All other listed corporations must:

(a) at least 2 weeks but not more than 4 weeks before the next annual general meeting held after the commencement of this section, or at the second annual general meeting after commencement if there is insufficient time between commencement and the next annual general meeting, circulate a summary of the operation of a corporate governance board to all members of the company, together with the opinion of its directors on matters relevant to the operation of such a board; and
(b) propose a resolution, at the next or second annual general meeting held after the commencement of this section (as the case may be), that the company establish a corporate governance board.
(3) Any resolution of a listed corporation which has the effect of abolishing the corporate governance board is invalid.

(4) Nothing in this Division requires a company which was a listed corporation at the commencement of this section to propose a resolution at any annual general meeting, other than the next annual general meeting held after the commencement of this section, that a corporate governance board be established, if the resolution under paragraph (2)(b) is defeated.

para.inline: 245B Membership of the corporate governance board

speech.para: (1) A corporate governance board must have at least 3 members, and a majority of them must be external members.
(2) A member of the corporate governance board is an external member if he or she:
(a) is not, and has not been in the previous 2 years, a director, an executive officer or an employee of the company or a related body corporate; and
(b) is not, and has not been in the previous 2 years, substantially involved in business dealings, or in a professional capacity, with the company or a related body corporate; and

(c) is not a member of a partnership that is, or has been in the previous 2 years, substantially involved in business dealings, or in a professional capacity, with the company or a related body corporate.

para.inline: 245C Election of members of the corporate governance board

speech.para: (1) The membership of the corporate governance board will be vacated at each annual general meeting and the meeting must elect a new corporate governance board.
(2) A person who has previously served as a member of the corporate governance board of a company may nominate for re-election.
(3) Members of the corporate governance board must be elected on the basis that each member of the company is entitled to cast one vote.

para.inline: 245D Functions of the corporate governance board

speech.para: (1) The functions of a corporate governance board are:
(a) to determine the remuneration of company directors; and
(b) to appoint auditors and determine the remuneration of auditors; and
(c) to review the appointment, remuneration and functioning of independent agents, such as valuers, who provide material information to shareholders; and
(d) to appoint persons to fill casual vacancies of directors; and
(e) to determine whether amendments should be made to the company's constitution, whether on the request of the company's directors or on the board's own initiative; and
(f) to decide issues of conflict of interest on the part of the company's directors and determine how those conflicts will be managed; and
(g) to control the conduct of general meetings and determine voting procedures.
(2) The corporate governance board must report to the members of the company at each annual general meeting in respect of the performance of its functions.
(3) The directors of a company must not purport to perform any of the functions mentioned in subsection (1) following the establishment of the corporate governance board.
(1) A member of a corporate governance board must:
(a) act honestly; and
(b) exercise the degree of care and diligence that a reasonable person would exercise if he or she were in the member's position; and
(c) not make use of information acquired through being a member of the corporate governance board in order to:
(i) gain an improper advantage for the member or another person; or
(ii) cause detriment to the members of the company; and

(d) not make improper use of his or her position as a member of the corporate governance board to gain, directly or indirectly, an advantage for himself or herself or for any other person, or to cause detriment to the members of the company.
Remuneration of members of the corporate governance board is to be determined by directors who are not members of the corpo rate governance board, with the agreement of the members of the company.

This is the first of the major governance issues. I bring this to the attention of the Senate because it is my belief that this amendment, which is on revised sheet 951, attends to a key problem which presently exists in terms of the relationship of shareholders to their companies and of the public at large to their companies.

Corporate governance boards are not new ideas. Some companies do have such boards. Members of the Senate who are not familiar with the Corporations Law might be surprised to know that the Corporations Law does not refer to boards; it only ever refers to directors. The board structure, although we know it very widely, is not a feature of Corporations Law. The concept of a corporate governance board is between a body that conducts the normal operational and managerial functions of a board—which we should call for the purposes of this debate the main board—and another board which deals with accountability issues.

Company directors have extensive powers regarding the management of a company's business and internal organisation. Some of those internal management powers which may be termed corporate governance powers include the following. For the purposes of this debate, envisage the average board as having a majority of executive directors and a minority of non-executive directors. This is what those people with a material interest in the matters at hand can determine. They can decide their own remuneration. So those members of the managerial class and directors' class sit around that board and decide their own remuneration. They can appoint and remunerate auditors and other experts. Auditors and other experts are the people who come back to the company and say, `You are running your company well, and the investing public can be assured that what you are doing is acceptable, all above board and is to the good of the company.' What happens if that is not the case? What happens if the auditors fail, as they so frequently did with all the collapses at the end of the eighties? So there is a direct conflict of interest there.

They can adopt any accounting practices they see fit within accepted accounting standards. Those directors can nominate themselves for re-election. They can appoint casual vacancies for directors. They can initiate changes in the corporate constitution, and they can control the conduct of shareholders' meetings and voting procedures. In instances where the interests of the shareholders do not coincide with the directors and the management of the company, the directors of the main board having those powers can lead to some very serious conflicts of interest and some very serious matters of misjudgment, misbehaviour and at times corrupt behaviour. Directors also possess the power to manage conflicts of interest with related parties. There is a barrister in Sydney who is famous for his attacks on conflicts of interest with related parties. His name slips my mind for the moment. He is a fellow who flies an aeroplane and is getting on in years a bit.

talk.start.para: —Gunzman.

—That is the man. He has really made a career out of campaigning against these sorts of things. Shann Turnbull, in the Australian Financial Review on 14 November 1996 in an article entitled `Dictatorship of the boardroom', stated:

speech.para: Many of our largest companies have directors who represent shareholders with related party trading interests. Examples are Arnotts, Cadbury Schweppes, Caltex, Coca-Cola Amatil, Coles-Myer and Qantas to name a few.
That is a fairly respectable list of senior companies. The number and extent of these powers has led such commentators to argue:
Existing practices concentrate powers with directors and provide them with absolute power to manage their own conflicts of self-interest to allow corruption of themselves and economic performance.

His words in a public newspaper. Mr Turnbull made the further point that as these `governance powers are quite different from the duty of the directors to manage a company, they can and should, be separated'. I agree with that. This may be leading edge governance practice, but the fact is that we have to see a situation where conflicts of interest and related party concerns have to be addressed.

A sure way to increase the independence and accountability of a company is to have two boards: one concerned with managerial and operational issues; and one solely concerned with governance issues. The former should quite properly continue to have directors elected relative to shareholdings. But to protect minorities, minimise conflict of interest issues, avoid board capture and ensure accountability, the latter needs to be elected by shareholders.

So I am talking here of two classes of directors: one having the main power and comprising the directors who are elected relative to shareholdings, so there would be a few very large shareholders controlling the board, as they do at present; and the other, the governance board, the accountability board, being elected by shareholders—in other words, the mass being able to elect them. We believe that that creation—which is being developed in other countries and is already in practice in a number of companies in this country and world wide—will result in creative tension within the company and will enable boards to resolve very, very difficult issues of conflict of interest.

In listed companies a separate board should exercise these internal governance powers, leaving the main board directors to concentrate on the management of the company's business operations, while the second board would provide the valuable introduction of a system of checks and balances into corporate governance procedures—a separation of powers, in other words. This proposal has the added virtue of introducing a greater measure of self-regulation, which I know is dear to the parliamentary secretary's heart. MAI Services Pty Ltd told the committee:
This is a much cheaper and effective way of protecting minorities than relying solely on the legal system, ASX listing rules or the ASC.
It is a much less costly method of arriving at a remedy for conflict of interest or malfeasance issues.

The proposal that we are putting here is a pro-active one; it is designed to prevent problems. To those who answer that the stock market will police companies with poorly performing boards and corporate governance, that involves a reactive attitude. Most importantly, that market based view of how a company should be run is a prejudicial one to shareholders because, if corporate governance fails and the shares fall—never mind all your suits with the law courts thereafter—the value of your shares has fallen.

Independent directors, as presently constituted, are often anything but. If not recommended in the first place by the other directors in the control group they are supposed to be independent of, they can be subject to board capture anyway, unless, as is fortunately sometimes the case, they are exceptional individuals. Australia does have some exceptional and outstanding individuals who are directors of both public and private companies—and we thank everyone that that is so. The Shann Turnbull article in the JASSA autumn 1998 publication said:
The centralisation of corporate power in a single board is the biggest governance problem for minority shareholders and other stakeholders.

I think it is the biggest problem which faces us all when dealing with companies. It is a question of how you can get them to operate with full accountability, whilst still remaining efficient and highly motivated economic and commercial entities.

The corporate governance board proposal would both simplify and reduce the role, responsibilities and workload of the main board directors as well as increase their credibility by removing the powers which permit the perception or actuality of a conflict of interest. This should thereby improve the accountability of directors and the internal governance of companies and lead to better business management decisions by directors. Ultimately, this is about re-establishing the balance of company governance in favour of shareholders rather than management.

Some of the powers and functions of the corporate governance board I have itemised at 245D on page 2 of revised sheet 951. There, the functions of the corporate governance board would be to determine the remuneration of company directors; appoint auditors and determine their remuneration; review the appointment, remuneration and functioning of independent agents, such as valuers— and we all remember the role valuers played in the late 1980s—who provide material information to shareholders; to appoint persons to fill casual vacancies of directors; to determine whether amendments should be made to the company's constitution, whether at the request of the company's directors or on the board's own initiative; to decide issues of conflict of interest on the part of the company's directors and determine how those conflicts will be managed; and to control the conduct of general meetings and determine voting procedures. I think that list of functions really does resolve the major accountability issue that we face.

It is essential, in our view, that the separate governance board be elected on the democratic basis of one vote per shareholder rather than one vote per share. Although the Australian Democrats believe that this system is desirable for all listed companies—and this is an important point in view of the parliamentary secretary's existing law and how the corporate sector is managed at present—we appreciate that it may not be appropriate to require existing companies to change their constitutions. Accordingly, this proposal is recommended only for newly listed companies. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I have closely studied Shann Turnbull's ideas in this area. Whilst I think there is a lot of merit in many of Shann Turnbull's ideas, there is no doubt that the concept contained in this amendment would be a radical restructuring of the law in relation to the governance of companies. It would, as Senator Murray clearly agrees, duplicate some board structures. It may well be an appropriate structure for some very large companies but may be entirely inappropriate for smaller companies. I think this fits very strongly into the category of a matter that deserves debate and discussion. This is not to stall consideration of it, but it is a very sweeping change to the structure that is required in Australia for boards.

speech.para: Under the guidelines in the current ASX listing rules—it is not a strict requirement, but many companies do it—companies in Austral ia are encouraged to have corporate governance committees. It is regarded as best practice. As I said in the second reading speech, the international comparisons of corporate governance on this particular point put Australia ahead of the rest of the world and certainly ahead of the United States, where there are no such requirements.

I genuinely believe that having a good debate about corporate governance in Australia will improve corporate governance. I believe that the debate that takes place on corporate governance in Australia is certainly not, as Senator Conroy quoted someone from the ASX as saying, some sort of fad. I do not think it is at all. I think it is an important thing. If you followed the financial journals and press in Australia, you would rarely these days see a day go by without having some discussion of corporate governance. If anything, the risk is that it becomes a cliche and that everyone starts mouthing it and they do not see the importance of corporate governance. People might say, `If you do this, you are going to be a good corporate governor.' The clarion call I am developing, which I hope is not a cliche, is that we do need a dynamic corporate governance culture in Australia and that developing that culture is assisted by a good public debate on these issues. To that extent, the more these matters are discussed, the more that interesting, informed characters like Shann Turnbull come in and say, `This is the way you should do it,' and the more that challenges our thinking on corporate governance, the better it is for Australia.

To that end, I believe that this would be a very good proposal and amendment for the joint committee to look at in its considerations of the corporate governance and directors' duties legislation that is before it at the moment and will be introduced into the parliament in the next day or two. It could have a discussion and promote discussion about it and deal with it, if it is seen fit by the committee and the parliament when that legislation comes before us.

If that is what is required of the government to have this matter dealt with by the committee, if that is the way it needs to be done, I will ensure that this issue is referred to the joint parliamentary committee on behalf of the government—that is, if it is not appropriate for Senator Murray or someone else just to raise it in the normal course of events. If that cannot or should not occur, I will undertake to formally refer it as part of that current inquiry.

talk.start.para: —We have had some discussions with Senator Campbell. The position of the Labor Party is that it does believe that the concept of a corporate governance board has some merit. We have seen some very poor actions taken by some large corporations in recent times. Crown Casino and Patrick's are examples of what can only be described as atrocious behaviour and highly dubious corporate governance practice in the corporate world. The Democrats' proposal is a very significant change. We would like to have this issue of corporate governance examined in principle and then in terms of what the likely practical outcomes will be. To a significant extent, these outcomes are unknown at the present time. We would certainly hope that this approach would at least minimise some of the more recent examples of shonky corporate behaviour that have occurred. I doubt it would totally eliminate it. We are concerned that it may be using a sledgehammer to smash a walnut, which is a phrase that has been a little bit overworked in this debate.
—It is a big walnut.

—It is a big walnut. We are interested in pursuing the issue. We are also concerned that, as with the Managed Investments Bill 1997 yesterday, the corporate governance board may detract from the responsibility which the single legal entity, the company, and its directors have to shareholders.

speech.para: We do see merit in this proposal. As I have said, it is a radical change, and we believe it deserves further investigation. We have had, in the relatively brief conversation with Senator Campbell, a good discussion about corporate governance. On that basis and on the basis of his assurances that it will be referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Corporations and Securities, we think it should be examined very thoroughly. There is substantial merit in the idea. We think it is pre-emptive to deal with the matter via an amendment today, and we would like to see it examined in the context of the CLERP reforms. We put the government on notice that, if it is not examined in a reasonable and thorough way, there will certainly be opportunities to support an amendment, of the type that Senator Murray has proposed here today, to future legislation. As of today, we will not be supporting the amendment you are moving, but we do put the government on notice about the need to thoroughly examine this proposal.

talk.start.para: —I would just like to make a couple of remarks. I think this is a good idea, as the parliamentary secretary and Senator Sherry have said. I do not think the corporate governance board is there simply to ensure that there are not misdeeds and mismanagement by the directors. I think this is an idea which will have success because it removes from the directors issues which must in some way trouble them and which we, as parliamentarians, have experienced. That is why we set up the Remuneration Tribunal, for example, as a body that sits apart from the parliamentarians to give them guidance on matters that politicians feel uncomfortable with. Certainly it is there to protect the company against misdeeds and mismanagement by the directors, but I think its overall task is to ensure that directors in the company are able to go about their true business of making the company a success without being hampered—and I use that word advisedly—by all these other considerations which go off to the corporate governance board. I am glad it is going to be discussed and I predict that it will ultimately be made part of our Corporations Law.

—I welcome Senator Murray's amendments. I think they are coming through at an appropriate time, and I am very pleased to see that not only is Senator Murray interested in pursuing them but it appears that the government is happy to have them before the parliamentary committee, where there will be a good chance to discuss them at some length. Without pre-empting any of the discussion that will take place, Senator Murray, the Labor Party views your move in this area very favourably and I hope that the committee will have a good look at them and take plenty of time to discuss them.

speech.para: I think they are particularly relevant because of an article that appeared recently in the Australian. It is an article that demonstrates the need for a corporate governance board, and I would like to quote quite extensively from the article. It is an article by Ken Jarrett, who not unknown to some in this chamber and to many people in the broader business community in Melbourne. Ken Jarrett was employed by John Elliott at Elders for a lengthy period. In the article he is talking about his experiences there, what it was like at the time and how things got really out of control. He said:
Back in the `80s, it was almost a sport to try and go as close to the edge as possible without going over, and I think that attitude has changed . . .

Generally, people are now more inclined to focus on running their business and making a profit rather than being clever legally or financially. People talk about the `80s as if they were a special period, characterised by a few prominent and dominant individuals, but it was also characterised by a very compliant community and boards.
A lot of company directors in the `80s felt that what they didn't know wasn't of concern to them. That attitude has changed.
Executives in Elders were completely absorbed in the company and everything else was secondary . . .
You were part of a team going in a certain direction and your views about what was going on outside that group were largely dependent on what the group said was going on.
The propaganda said that the authorities were attacking John and that created the feeling that they were the enemy and we were on some sort of campaign that was right, however it looked.
On top of that, there was this view that, if lawyers advised you that something was okay then the assumption was that it was within the rules of the game that you were playing.
That situation became increasingly ridiculous as various disasters at Elders showed that they perhaps weren't right all the time.

Holmes a Court looked like getting control of BHP, which would have given him control of Elders. He then controls John Elliott and he would have made Elliott kneel down in front of him or something. It became very personal.
John believed he was the hero of the business community in Melbourne and he had to do something about it.

I think the basic things that Elders were doing were healthy, but then I think it did become a personal thing to him. If you saw a photo of Elders it was a photo of him—part of Elders was part of John. Everyone knew him around the world as Elders.

He flew around the world in a big 737 that was owned by Elders, at Elders expense, but it was his personal plane. So he became Mr Elders and he started to believe that it was all true—that he was Mr Elders.

It was clear to everyone how John was becoming all powerful and Elders was becoming his personal plaything . . . He would fly back to Australia just to watch his football team play. It would cost $50,000 so he could watch a football game.
I don't think shareholders would vote for that if they had the chance. But at the time no one said `this is ridiculous.' Today, I think perhaps they would.
The Elders corporate entity began to be merged with the character of John Elliott.
Elders changed from being a powerful single-purpose machine to being his appendage. At that stage, Elders' original focus disappeared and the board did not know what they were trying to achieve.
He goes on to say:
It is not a question of reining in but giving support and, at the same time, some control—measuring the chief executive against the company objectives and standards . . .

The board needs to be able to provide leadership rather than be led by the chief executive . . . You need people with stronger wills and more questioning minds, not just people who will blindly follow.
A second factor in the Elders case was John Elliott's ability to divide the board and deal with one member at a time.

In the end, I don't think dissenting directors had much chance. There was no independent chairman to override the politics and, to some extent, John picked his directors. People like Jerry Nyall who did question matters at board meetings were hastily retired.

A third factor is that it is very difficult to agree on issues, particularly ethical issues, when under pressure. When Elders saw itself under attack, the board tended to agree to proposals without much serious questioning.
So how do you get around situations where CEOs have stacked a board in their favour?
This is a question that this corporate governance board is central to. Jarrett goes on to say:

Don't let them . . . Shareholders should play a more active role. A lot of these things are transparent, but people don't take action on them. I think shareholders are stronger now and institutions are playing a more active role but they should insist on disclosures.
A company should be capable of writing down what its objectives are and set out its standards, responsibilities, etc.
If you can't write it down, it probably hasn't been thought through properly.

This is from one of the insiders at the time, when the cult of personality took over a publicly owned company and bent it to its own will. A corporate governance board, duly constituted in the way that Senator Murray's amendments are suggesting, would go a long way to stopping the hijacking that took place in Elders in the 1980s. We have heard already from Senator Sherry today about the potentially excessive remuneration increases, particularly when you balance them against the performance. But the sorts of things that Ken Jarrett has described can be dealt with by Senator Murray's amendments and can be dealt with by companies if the right people, independent people, are put onto the corporate governance boards so that the sorts of shenanigans that Ken Jarrett is describing in this article cannot take place. That is important.

So the Labor Party, as Senator Sherry has indicated, will not support you today, Senator Murray, but I am pretty certain we will be going shoulder-to-shoulder with you in that inquiry looking at corporate governance and some of the issues we have already discussed today—the sorts of issues that you and Ken Jarrett have drawn attention to. That is a very worthwhile inquiry. I welcome the government's decision. There is a lot that the corporate community will support in what you are saying.

It will be interesting to see who opposes these moves. It will be disappointing if the business community are not prepared to acknowledge the mistakes of the past and to acknowledge how individual corporations have become personal playthings of individuals because they do not have a strong enough board, because the boards been stacked by directors. This is a way we can introduce into parliament, after consultation and discussion, ways to make sure that some of the problems do not happen. It would mean, in situations like that of Patrick, that if you had an independent corporate government board it would be able to look at a shonky financial structure and it would be able to say: `Just a minute. Have we got legal advice? Is the corporate strategy that has just been determined actually legal?'

You would have a situation where Lloyd Williams and Ron Walker could not continue to behave as they have done for a couple of years in Crown Casino. That is a situation where we have seen a director resign because of the corporate governance questions, the interrelated transactions, the interrelation of the entities of Hudson Conway, owned by Walker and Lloyd Williams, which merge with Crown itself and which make it the major shareholder—not the majority shareholder. A whole range of institutions and small shareholders have taken a bath in Crown, and a large part of Crown minority shareholders' bath is because of a disgraceful management agreement, agreed to by the board of Crown that is dominated by Lloyd Williams, which saw a $200 million fee for the management services. This is the management that has taken the share price of Crown and devastated it. This is management that had no idea what it was doing in the construction—

talk.start.para: —The fees did not move.

—No, the fees didn't move. That's exactly right, Senator Sherry. They continued to plummet Crown into the red. How do you lose money and run a casino? That is the question that, if I were a Crown shareholder, I would be asking. `How on earth have you lost money?' The Asian crisis had not even hit and they had already gone into the red.
—That was his excuse.

—That was his excuse—exactly. The Asian crisis had not hit and Crown were losing money. And was there any comeback for the minor shareholders in Crown? No, they have had to cop a bath. I think in the last couple of weeks Crown shares have been trading below 60c, and that is only after the positive announcement that Crown were buying back their management rights and giving up on the fees. An analysis of that buyback was that the institutional shareholders and the minor shareholders actually voted to buy back those rights, but at an excessively generous price. But they were faced with Hobson's choice: you stick with the management structure and the management fees that you have got, and it is clearly outrageous, but if you reject the deal you will send your share price tumbling even further. That was the choice the poor small shareholder in Crown had to put up with, all because Ron Walker, the bagman for the Liberal Party, and Lloyd Williams were unable to separate out what was good for Hudson Conway from what was good for Crown shareholders. They had no concept of it.

speech.para: Brian Powers' resignation is a clear alarm bell, a clear signal regarding the sorts of corporate governance boards which they have now set up—two years too late for the majority of small shareholders in Crown, but they finally set one up. They brought in somebody with some credibility outside to try to appease the markets, to run their corporate governance board. That is what this amendment and the proposed inquiry will be able to talk about. It will be able to thrash out the sorts of independent directors, policies and powers that corporate governance boards need to keep major shareholders honest.
Amendment not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I thank both major parties for their supportive remarks relevant to the previous amendment. I look forward to their taking up these issues further under the government's guidance under the CLER program. I ask leave of the Senate to move amendments 6 and 10, on sheet 951 revised, together.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (6) Schedule 1, item 1, page 47 (table item 17), omit the table item.
(10) Schedule 1, item 4, page 81 (lines 22 and 23), omit "(replaceable rule—see section 135) ".

talk.start.para: —It might speed things up if I indicate our position. The government is not opposed in principle to what Senator Murray is trying to do here, but we believe that the Labor amendment—which had similar wording, but slightly better wording from the point of view of the draftsmen in business law division—better achieves the result.
—Could you refer me to the Labor amendment?

—It is opposition amendment No. 1. It is a part of their amendment No. 1, but I think that is a fairly omnibus sort of amendment. Labor have agreed to redraft it in a form of words that, I understand, achieves the same result. We would prefer to see the Labor amendment, with some slight redrafting, go ahead, and we will not oppose that.

—The parliamentary secretary has not said whether he will be supporting Labor amendment No. 1 which, as he has rightly pointed out, is a comprehensive one. It is 2½ pages. I assume from what he said that the Labor Party—and I will ask you to comment, Senator Sherry—may be prepared to extract that section from that amendment so that it can be put separately in case the government does not support your entire amendment No. 1 on sheet 958.

speech.para: I should point out briefly, if I may, a motivation for our amendment. The Investment and Financial Services Association, who yesterday were on the opposite side to us, are today on the same side as us. That is how it goes with lobbying groups. They were concerned that the bill did not include a key recommendation from the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities' report on the Draft Second Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1996. Recommendation No. 2 states:
The committee recommends that the right of an individual director to call a meeting of members should be a mandatory rule for listed companies.
That committee said:

The committee accepts that recent events in relation to some companies have demonstrated a need for individual directors of listed companies to be able to act independently in the interests of all shareholders. The right to call a member's meeting gives some substance to this independence and it should not be a right that can be withdrawn through the constitution of a listed company.
The Australian Democrats continue to support the joint committee's view. Therefore, I think the position of the Labor Party is seminal with respect to this amendment.

talk.start.para: —Today I want to outline how, through a national network of second ministerial media officers and support staff, the Howard government has established a nationwide media monitoring network.

speech.para: From the outset I wish to make it clear that we have always taken the view that the discretion for allocating personal staff and their responsibilities lies with the government of the day. Provided the agreed ratio of government to opposition staff is maintained, we accept that government staffers can be tasked for a wide variety of responsibilities. What we object to in relation to the government's second media offices is the dishonest, shady and secretive manner in which the government established and maintained them. What we object to is the cant and hypocrisy of coalition frontbenchers who had so much to say about the National Media Liaison Service and the Ministerial Media Group when we were in government but who now sit silently at the table during Senate estimates, refusing to admit what the rest of the country now knows: that the Howard government, from the moment it was elected to office, established a nationwide media monitoring unit; that this unit was established in secrecy, in many cases funded unknowingly by the home departments of junior ministers allocated second media officers; that this unit, although the government denies its existence, reports directly to the office of the Prime Minister and has recently been doubled in size, presumably in anticipation of an impending federal election; and that this unit monitors opposition spokespersons and state premiers around Australia and provides material directly to ministers and also directly to the Liberal Party in Menzies House—all at taxpayers' expense, without so much as an announcement or an appropriation that can be scrutinised by the parliament.

This government came to power promising leaner government. They boasted of reducing ministerial staff levels by 30 per cent. As an opposition, we copped the corresponding decrease in our own numbers sweet. As long as the ratio of government to opposition personal staff at 21 per cent was maintained, we would not have complained. However, what has really happened to government staffing levels is that they have risen from 292 to 326.5—an increase of 34.5. Departmental liaison officers are now at a record level of 67. Consultants working directly for, chosen by and reporting to ministers have been charged to departments. The cases of Mr Mansfield, Dr Webster and Dr Davies are classic examples of this occurring.

Neither departmental liaison officers nor consultants are part of the government-opposition ratio, allowing the government to ratchet up their personal staffs without providing additional resources to the opposition. As well, the classification levels of many MOPS staff have been increased. The spirit of the agreement, which was supposed to maintain a nexus between government and opposition staff, has been broken by a government which promised loudly in opposition that things would be different. There is no better example of this sneaky, Nixonian sort of operation of the government than the establishment of their secret, nationwide media monitoring unit.

Labor abolished the government information unit when we came to office in 1983 because of concerns about the appropriateness of many of the roles that it attempted to simultaneously perform. Instead, we established the National Media Liaison Service and the Ministerial Media Group, with separate functions—aNiMaLS to disseminate information about government programs and policies, and the MMG to carry out more overtly political media tasks for ministers.

Whatever criticisms the then opposition may have had of our arrangements, they cannot deny that our media activities were established quite openly, with clear appropriations. They had published guidelines to govern their conduct. Indeed, senators Kemp and Abetz spent many hours in estimates questioning officials and ministers to satisfy themselves that these units functioned according to these guidelines. Nevertheless, this did not prevent the coalition promising that, when they came to power, things would be different. Total staff numbers would fall, government would be leaner and there would be no media monitoring or, as Senator Kemp labelled them `political hit squads financed by the taxpayer'. Indeed, Senator O'Chee stood in this chamber, during a debate on the National Media Liaison Service, on 7 June 1995 and said:

. . . we would cut back on some of the government's taxpayer-funded self-promotion, because this money—and this is typical of Labor bureaucracies—which is detailed here, does not go to delivering a service; it goes to making the government look good.

Imagine our surprise when, upon the coalition coming to government, we chanced upon the appointment of the so-called `second media officers'. All coalition ministers—cabinet and outer ministry alike—were allocated one press secretary. And then six ministers, apparently randomly, were allocated a second—and most of them were junior ministers. In no instance could we establish what particular circumstances warranted a second media officer for Senator Vanstone, Mr Reith, Mr Williams, Mr Smith, Mr Ruddock and Mr Jull.

What about Mr Williams, for example? His duties were considered so light that he earns the dubious distinction of being one of the first attorneys since Federation not to sit in the cabinet. Yet the Prime Minister felt it necessary to approve a second media officer for him—and Mr Ruddock, Mr Smith and Mr Jull, all junior ministers at the time. Why? The opposition could well understand perhaps Senator Vanstone and Mr Reith requiring all of the extra media assistance that they could obtain, given their performance, but why, of all ministers, were these six allocated second media advisers?

It became obvious: one was in New South Wales, one in Victoria, one in Queensland, one in South Australia, one in Western Australia and one in Tasmania, each with a designated home base in the respective state capital city—no public announcement, no appropriation and no line item budget entry. Indeed, the only public announcement by any of the ministers of the appointment of any of these second media staff was a press release by Senator Vanstone. There was no suggestion that this staffer was to perform any role other than that ordinarily carried out by a minister's press officer acting at their direction as a member of the minister's personal staff.

In fact, when the opposition first raised the issue, we were met with a wall of dishonesty. Senator Kemp, in fact, denied that these activities could in any way be equated with aNiMaLS. We know now that in the case of Senator Hill he actually misled the estimates committee on 22 October 1996 when he said quite specifically that the role of the second media officer in Mr Ruddock's office was `To work to, in that instance, Mr Ruddock, to carry on the usual functions of a media officer . . . ' Someone should have told Mark Elliot, Karim Barbara or Sarah Baxter of those facts about that position before Mr Ruddock employed them.

Gradually the truth began to dribble out. On the same day that Senator Hill gave his dishonest assurances that Mr Jull's second media adviser was `to enable Mr Jull to meet a broader requirement of communication within Queensland', Mr Jull was already beginning to fess up to the reality. He qualified Senator Hill's answer by stating:
. . . the entitlement of a second media officer is part of a strategy to provide additional media resources in each state to promote coordination of media relations.

Senator Parer went further during his memorable performance before the estimates committee. We were able to question him directly on 4 June on the circumstances surrounding the transfer of Mr Jull's second media officer to Senator Parer's office. Senator Parer's revelations clearly established that the role of the second media officers was related to the whole of government media monitoring on a state by state basis. But he insisted that the staffer involved—in this case a Mr Ryan—reported to and worked directly to him as a responsible minister.

We asked why. Senator Parer explained that Wik and Century Zinc were issues of particular concern to the people of Queensland and that they fell within his portfolio responsibilities. We know Senator Parer has always his partywide responsibilities extremely seriously. Not only was he able to provide a statewide media monitoring resource for the federal government financed by DAS and his home department, we have since learnt that he apparently provided the stationery resources for the Queensland branch of the Liberal Party.

The opposition is not alone in its sense of paranoia about what this media monitoring unit might be up to. Apparently its activities extend to monitoring the statements of the troublesome and recalcitrant state premiers. In fact, we know that Mr Hanke, the second media adviser on Minister Reith's staff, got a cheerio from Mr Kennett on Neil Mitchell's radio program on 6 November 1997. But when raised in estimates on 12 November 1997, Senator Hill assured us:
We are not running a media monitoring operation of the type with which we are very familiar.
