This brings us to Mr Mark Elliot and Miss Sarah Baxter. The memorandum prepared under the signature of Mark Elliot and obtained by the opposition contained absolute proof that the government is maintaining a taxpayer-funded, secret media monitoring unit in every state despite Senator Hill's denials.

The memorandum tells us that Senator Hill's explicit assurance that Mr Ruddock's second media officer works directly for his minister was not true, and that he misled the committee. The memorandum tells us that the baby aNiMaLS staff, in fact, report to the Prime Minister's office and the Liberal Party directly. The memorandum tells us that baby aNiMaLS staff are instructed to ignore requests to carry out work for their employing minister unless they have time. I have outlined in a media release some of the other aspects of this particular operation.

Where did the information go? To the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, who employed these people? Of course not. The transcript went directly to the Prime Minister's office to Mr Tony O'Leary. A copy was sent to Mr Lynton Crosby at the Liberal Party federal secretariat.

Senator Kemp, when in opposition, called aNiMaLS a Labor Party rort and a political hit squad. Perhaps some of the people who made these statements will come into the chamber now and explain how Mr Elliot's role is consistent with the outrage that was expressed then. Perhaps Senator Abetz and Senator Hill will also explain their attitude to this situation now that they are in govern ment—a very different attitude to the one they expressed in opposition.

We do not consider media monitoring outrageous but, like all taxpayer funded activity, it should be transparent and accountable. Baby aNiMaLS is not accountable; it has no guidelines; it is shrouded in secrecy and the costs are concealed dishonestly in home departments arbitrarily chosen for their geographical spread. This is something the coalition said it would not do in government. I intend at a later stage to speak at some length about the costs of the six media advisers, the six personal secretaries, that have now been engaged to double the unit resources of this secret media monitoring unit and about a range of other costs that are being borne by taxpayers in this.

We know now, of course, that the operations of the government members secretariat employ 11 full-time staffers. In the media monitoring unit there are an awful lot—24 full-time hacks in total—being employed to support the Liberal Party. These are taxpayer funded political operatives working on media monitoring and campaigning. They got a bagging in the Liberal Party party room yesterday and at the joint party meeting that Mr Howard had to front up to.
I seek leave to table some of the transcripts that give examples of the sort of material that is being provided by these units, one of which highlights John Laws's comment:

Incidentally, it's lucky one of John Howard's `S' words isn't sincerity. . . cause we all remember and it is going to remain around to haunt him. . . in 1995 he said the GST would never, never be part of Liberal Policy.

These are good examples of what is being done by this sleazy, slimy, secret operation on behalf of the Liberal Party. I seek leave to table the material which I have shown to Senator Ian Campbell, for the government.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —This is the second of two speeches that I will make on the e-commerce, or electronic commerce, revolution. Previously, I looked at the international dimensions of this phenomenon which will change forever the way we do business in Australia. I reported on Australia's recent e-commerce summit and a speech by Mr Ira Magaziner, the senior adviser on policy development on e-commerce to the President of the United States. As I have previously indicated, Mr Magaziner outlined the five principles on which the information economy is being developed in the United States: firstly, the private sector should lead Internet growth; secondly, it should be market driven, not regulated; thirdly, government intervention should be minimal; fourthly, the need to take heed of the medium that we are dealing with and its technologies; and, finally, e-commerce, or electronic commerce, is global.

speech.para: Magaziner's five principles actually leave a lot of questions to be answered: firstly, how will Australian business fare in such a globally deregulated world; secondly, how will consumers and others who are disempowered fare in such a deregulated world; thirdly, what is the legitimate role of a national government in such a worldwide market; fourthly, who will need protection and from what; and, finally, what structures and regulatory frameworks are appropriate in this new era of worldwide electronic commerce?

On such issues we do `look through a glass darkly' as we head at a very rapid pace into this new world of e-commerce. As with any new technology, questions of how it should be regulated on a national basis are important. The Internet is internationally market driven, but there is a role for national government in terms of consumer protection, community standards of content, privacy, encryption and national security.

The Howard government has recognised the electronic commerce potential and the challenge of developing an appropriate role for government. This is in stark contrast to the previous Labor government which let years be wasted in putting together, in a proper way, frameworks to regulate this new world of commerce that was coming with the information revolution. At the time, I referred to then minister Michael Lee as the `Rip Van Winkle' of communications policy.

It is my estimate that this country has actually lost two years, but this has now been rapidly made up under the leadership of our Minister for Communications, the Information Economy and the Arts (Senator Alston), who has put in place a number of measures which help place a framework under this whole electronic commerce revolution. He has established a ministerial council to develop a whole of government action agenda because, obviously, something like e-commerce has a very wide ranging effect across the responsibilities of many government departments. Within his own department there has been established the National Office of the Information Economy, which has a private sector driven advisory board. Last month, Senator Alston announced the National Information-Economy Day, to be held on 5 September, which will link government, business, community and consumer groups to discuss the key issues and to make them more aware of the potential of the information economy.

The National Office of the Information Economy has also conducted a large corporations awareness program which targets CEOs and peak industry bodies. Around Australia 15 regional summits have been held in key areas so that the spread of this new electronic commerce revolution will also go beyond the cities and out into regional Australia. The government has also launched a plan aimed at getting business on-line. The Department of Industry, Science and Tourism is implementing a framework to assist companies to adopt on-line technology.

In April, the government moved to better protect consumer rights in the electronic commerce world. The Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss) has released a new set of principles developed by the National Advisory Council on Consumer Affairs. It underlines the point that, for electronic commerce to take off, we need consumers to be totally confident on the protocols and procedures and that, when they do undertake transactions, the money and the goods that are involved will move in proper ways, under proper protections. This set of principles for e-commerce which the minister has released complements the very extensive consumer protection laws that are in place in the country already—things such as the Trade Practices Act and fair trading laws. The set of principles asserts that e-commerce should be protected to the same degree as other forms of commerce, and, if we get that in place very quickly, it will mean that there will be a very sound legislative base underlying this new way of trading.

In addition, at the end of April, the Attorney-General (Mr Williams) and Senator Alston announced copyright reforms which do have a very big impact on the world of e-commerce. The reforms include a new broad based technology neutral right of communication to the public, and, also, new measures for enforcement of commercial law in cyberspace. Clearly, these protective measures by the government are necessary as the information economy that is now developing will transform not only the way we do business but also the way that we work, live and play. Because of this, Australia really needs to be a leader in this information revolution—if you are not a leader, your economy will be left far behind. No business can ignore e-commerce and its potential. A leading venture capitalist in Silicon Valley summed it up this way:
In this new age every business is an IT business. The Internet is touching and transforming all industries.

Small and medium businesses are examining the Internet's potential. The Yellow Pages Small Business Index survey of e-commerce in Australian small and medium businesses found universal awareness that some businesses are now using the Internet for promoting or selling their products or services. One-third of small businesses and two-thirds of all medium businesses are connected to the Internet. Thirty-seven per cent of small businesses believe they have the potential to sell on the Internet and 54 per cent of medium businesses believe the same. The potential to use e-commerce is highest among businesses seeking significant growth. The Internet is perfect for small to medium enterprises because, for the first time, no matter whether they are city based or regionally based, it will give them access to international markets. The Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) tells the story of the stockwhip manufacturer in remote Australia who sells his product on the Internet, internationally, to California—it is that sort of revolutionary change that we can now bring about in this new world of electronic commerce.

A report was released last month called Statistics on E-commerce in Australia. It shows that business related Internet sites have more than doubled in the last five years. There are now at least 54,800 business sites. In 1997, there were 1½ billion electronic transactions. The e-commerce market that people are now linking into is not just Australian but worldwide. Five per cent of small businesses already have e-commerce, as do 12 per cent of medium businesses. Despite this rapid movement towards e-commerce in Australia, the minister for the information economy, Senator Alston, warns:

Those businesses which capitalise on new opportunities are more likely to be internationally competitive in the 21st century, while those who wait and see what happens are likely to take a back seat in the information economy and may not even survive.

That is why the government is moving so rapidly and setting up the right structures, the right laws—setting up strategies for businesses to gain a greater awareness of what is available in this new world of electronic commerce so Australia can better link internationally and extend its already quite considerable growth. In Australia alone, the on-line market is quite massive. The ABS found that the number of Australians using the Internet from the home has doubled every year since 1996. By the year 2002, it is forecast that 30 per cent of all retail transactions will be conducted on the Internet.

Australia is joining the information revolution and the possibilities of e-commerce are vast. Apart from the business benefits, it will help, particularly in regional and rural Australia, to overcome the `tyranny of distance'. Industry and business can establish anywhere. The need in previous markets for rail and road out to where the product was being produced will become redundant for many of these new industries if they are on the Internet and linked with optic fibre. Regional and rural communities can shop and bank in this way, and, already, many farmers are finding with this new technology that they can do business from the farm without travelling great distances.

It is benefiting areas in regional Australia like my own area of the Hunter, where the regional tourism organisation has just received a $200,000 grant from the Howard government to trial e-commerce in tourism and businesses. They have already developed very successful strategies overseas of letting people in other markets know that they exist and what the Hunter has to offer, but this is being done by traditional means such as brochures and videotapes. What is now available, what is now possible, is to promote the Hunter worldwide on the Internet, and this grant from the government will give this sort of move a great boost.

So it is not only distance in Australia that is being overcome by this new technology but distance from the world. It has great potential for the development of our Australian economy. This government has set up the right policies and is moving at a considerably greater speed than the last government to put all this in place. With the support of business and with the support of consumers, we will move into a totally new era which will improve the way we live in Australia.

talk.start.para: —Many people avidly read letters to the editor in the various newspapers and periodicals that are published around this country, and someone was good enough to send to me a copy of a very interesting letter that appeared in the rural newspaper the Stock Journal recently. It was written by a Mr Bill Hunt of Bordertown in South Australia. He told the editor of that particular paper:

speech.para: It came as quite a surprise to wake up a few weeks ago to find that we, the farming population of Australia, had declared war on the wharfies.

Mr Hunt had some very interesting views in this article, which I would like to share with the Senate now. He did say that he found it very interesting that farmers, through the NFF, apparently were seeking to condemn collective bargaining while seeking to justify the collective bargaining the rural sector calls `orderly marketing' and the compulsory nature of single desk commodity exports. Mr Hunt asked the editor how farmers could condemn as `rorts and perks' the conditions won by the unions for their members, when farmers sought to maintain the special conditions that they had won—things such as tax averaging, sales tax exemptions, registration concessions and family trusts. Mr Hunt told the editor that it was the view of many people in the bush that the NFF action on the docks had compromised its political neutrality. He asked:
. . . is this really a business venture of the NFF, or a venture by a handful of politically ambitious "gung-ho" squatters, some of whom happen to be on the executive of the NFF?
Bill said one thing was for sure: they did not ask the farmers when they took this action. He told the editor:

If they had, they may have been surprised to find that, in comparison to all the other stuff that's going down here: like the collapse of the wool, beef and pigmeat industries; the wholesale closing down of country towns and infrastructure like banks, schools, railways and the like; the tenuous hold on services that we have in the bush; like the soon to be privatised Telstra, post and power; and like our alleged Minister for Agriculture who just sits Nero-like and watches rural Australia burn, that the few hundred lousy dollars saved per farm shifting containers is NFF all.

They are very interesting words from Bill Hunt because Bill Hunt certainly was right when he questioned the motives behind the National Farmers Federation waterfront campaign. It was not a campaign about economic reform or improved productivity; it was really a campaign against an industrial union. It was a campaign that was conceived and implemented by a small group consisting of past and present officers of the NFF who were about to draw on the authority of the organisation and the resources of government to try to get the MUA.

Bill was right when he said the NFF had lost its political neutrality. In fact that was gone the minute the NFF became an active player in the Reith-Howard waterfront plan. That occurred when the NFF signed up to the plan in Melbourne on 18 September last year. The organisation claimed that it was acting on behalf of rural Australia. But Bill Hunt was right again when he said that the NFF was not acting on behalf of the 100,000 farm families—it was acting on behalf of its president, Mr McGauchie, its former president, Mr McLachlan, its two former executive directors, Mr Trebeck and Mr Robb, a former industrial officer, Mr Houlihan, and its current industrial director, Mr Ferguson. What did Bill Hunt say about consultation? He said there had not been any. How do we know that?

The Western Australian Farmers Federation were asking why the NFF was attacking the MUA. The Western Australian Farmers Federation asked: `Why do we want a fight on the docks?' That federation said it had a good working relationship with the MUA. So, naturally, why were they being involved in a fight with the Maritime Union with whom they had a good working relationship? Mr Ian McFarlane, who is a senior agri-politician and an NFF councillor—indeed, part of the NFF, I might say, and now the Liberal party candidate for Groom—complained publicly that he found out about the NFF move from an ABC journalist. Yet he is an NFF councillor. Obviously, you had to be in the club to know what was going on.

The NFF initially tried to separate itself out from the plan and the P&C Stevedores operation. Executive director Dr Wendy Craik claimed that the only link between P&C and the National Farmers Federation was that they shared common directors. Unfortunately, her claim was somewhat weakened when it was discovered that the registered office of P&C was NFF House in Canberra. The NFF president, however, was far more up front. He said the NFF was going into the stevedoring business; this is a going concern. He was reported by AAP as saying that the stevedoring business was child's play. He said it would be easy to make money.

However, the reality was that the National Farmers Federation was part of the wider plan—this conspiracy—to generate a dispute, to sack a whole work force, and to quickly replace it with another. In fact, on 3 April, Mr McGauchie, Mr Houlihan and Mr Ferguson sat down with Chris Corrigan from Patrick to discuss how best to manage the mass sacking of the whole Patrick work force and, of course, the P&C workers were ready to go.
The plan was revealed in some detail by the senior counsel for the National Farmers Federation, Mr Jeffrey Meralls QC, in his submission to the High Court of Australia.

He told the court that P&C had no other contracts and that if they lost their contract with Patrick P&C would be destroyed. He said that P&C would either have to sack its workers or incur enormous costs. He said, `Either alternative will seriously threaten its continued viability or destroy it as a commercial enterprise.' That is Mr Jeffrey Meralls QC, the senior advocate for the National Farmers Federation in a submission to the High Court.

Mr Meralls was saying that, if P&C had to meet labour costs, the NFF company would have to find $8,700 a day—a big bill for Australian farmers for a political campaign, wouldn't you say? But farmers had no say in this campaign. It cost $8,700 a day and farmers around the country had no say in this matter, particularly when there were big bills that ought to have been run up on the issues that were of real concern for the bush. So Bill Hunt—

talk.start.para: —Who's that—Bill Hunt?

—Yes, Bill Hunt was right. After all the economic and social damage that the waterfront fiasco created, and the promises to Australian farmers that they would receive massive gains from the P&C exercise, and having promised nearly 400 workers—many boys from the bush, as we hear, and girls—that they had a bright future in the stevedoring business, where has it all finished up? Further waterfront reform is being negotiated by the parties and an agreement satisfactory to all parties has, in fact, been reached—just as it could have been and should have been in the first place. It is interesting to note that, in our recent inquiry, the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee was told that there was basically an understanding that 217 waterfront positions could have gone if there had been funding from the government last December.

speech.para: What about the P&C workers? Unfortunately, they have gone as quickly as they came. Many of them feel exactly the same as Bill Hunt and many of his colleagues do—that the NFF has let them down. Interviewed on the ABC PM program, one P&C worker, David Garrett, said he had given up a good, well-paid job to work for the farmers. He said he understood that he was offered three years work, and then some, by the NFF. He was asked whether he thought all the risks in the P&C exercise were on his side and he said:

Definitely, I don't blame the MUA for acting the way they did but I do blame our company for the way they acted. We never knew. None of us were ever told that this was going to happen. We thought we were only going to get a dock to ourselves, start working in competition, not actually take over the whole lot.

He was wrong, of course, as we now know. Although the NFF had led Mr Garrett and his colleague to that view, the plan was quite different. In fact, James Ferguson told the Business Review Weekly that the commercial success of the operation was not the NFF's main objective; the aim was to change the culture on the docks. Mr Ferguson also said that if productivity increased then the NFF would probably pack up its tent and go home.

Mr McGauchie's explanation for the failure of the P&C plan and the sacking of 400 workers was simple enough. He said it was the fault of the Federal Court, and I suppose the High Court. In other words, P&C would be okay if the 2,000 sacked workers had not pursued their legal rights through the court—P&C would have got away with it. If the courts had not found that there was an arguable case that the NFF, Mr Reith, Mr Howard and Chris Corrigan were parties to an unlawful conspiracy, perhaps they would have got away with it. Therefore, if there had not been an order to reinstate the whole work force maybe they would have got away with it and they would have been able to honour their commitment to the workers. But the court did not take that view and the NFF showed those 400 workers the door.

Not only is Bill Hunt being let down by the NFF; he and the rest of rural Australia are being badly let down by the National Party generally, and by the minister, Mr Anderson, in particular. The rise of One Nation in the bush has not been the result of a sudden failing on the part of the National Party or the Liberal Party. Both have been letting people in rural Australia down for years and simply taking their vote for granted.

While there has been recent speculation about how safe Mr Anderson might be in his seat of Gwydir, he has in fact been in trouble for some considerable time. While people in the bush quite reasonably expect Mr Anderson to work hard for them within government, the record shows they were sadly mistaken. In fact, he was in trouble from the beginning. Page 1 of the Northern Daily Leader of Wednesday, 8 May 1996, just two months after the Howard government term commenced, carried the headline, quoting Mr Anderson, `I won't quit.' It was a story about the minister being in breach of the Prime Minister's guidelines for ministerial conduct. Those guidelines, however, have now been abandoned by the Prime Minister.

But a few months later that same paper carried a headline `No time for complacency', with a subheading `National Party has forgotten country people'. The Manilla Shire President and National Party Branch President, Mr Jim Maxwell, was quoted as saying `the National Party has completely forgotten country people', that `he is angry and disillusioned', and that he is `particularly angry with John Anderson, the local federal member for Gwydir'. He is also quoted as saying:
John Anderson has completely deserted the people who put him there.
There's a lot of anger coming from people who believe John Anderson doesn't care about them, that he's ignoring the grass roots.
I am not the only one.
People out here are convinced the Nationals have forgotten anyone who lives across the range.
Mr Maxwell also said that the Nationals had become complacent, believing that `once a National voter, always a National voter'. He continues:
Unless the Nationals speak up now, on behalf of the rural people who are struggling to survive, it'll be the end of the Nationals.

This is July 1996. He was dead right, of course. Last year the Queensland grain growers called on the Prime Minister to replace Mr Anderson as minister just one day after they postponed a vote of no confidence in him. Mr McFarlane, the President of the Queensland Grain Growers Association, was also in that vein. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —At the urging of some of my colleagues in the coalition, I wish to place on record in this place today some comments I made yesterday. They relate to a phone call I received last week from a 78-year-old woman. She rang me up to tell me that I was not an Australian because I looked Asian. She rang me up to tell me that she voted for One Nation because she grew up in the days of the White Australia policy and she believed that it was immoral that people who looked like me should be allowed in this country.

speech.para: So I said to her, `What do I have to do to be Australian? Because my family has been in this country for 110 years.' She said, `It doesn't matter.' I said, `I have got to look English, have I?' And she said, `Yes.' I said, `But what about the Aborigines?' She said, `They're Australian too.' I said, `Let me just get this down for the record: you can look Aboriginal and be an Australian, or you can look English and be an Australian, but you can't look Asian and be an Australian.' And she said, `That's right.'

I make these comments today not as a plea for me, because comments like that are like water off a duck's back for me, but for people who are not as articulate as I am or as articulate as other senators in this place. I make this plea for the many decent Australians for whom views like this are an affront to their fundamental right as Australians to live with dignity within the shores of this country.

It is a fact that most of the people who voted for One Nation in Queensland on 13 June probably do not share those views and would probably be horrified by those views. But it is also a fact that they must understand that the people who do hold those views have made their home in the heart of the One Nation Party. They must also understand that these people, emboldened by what happened in Queensland, are now sallying forth with new vigour to spread again the politics of hatred and division. Rather than create one nation, they will tear this nation asunder in the pursuit of their prejudice.
Of course, Mrs Hanson would say that this is not true. But let her own words be the test of whether this is so. She told Paul Lyneham on 60 Minutes quite recently:
I am afraid that we might be swamped by Asians by the number we have coming in. All I ask for is a balance restored to the number of Asians coming into Australia . . .

It sounds pretty innocuous, but the fact is the only way you can implement policies like that is to have quotas on the number of people coming to this country from particular parts of the world. That is, quotas imposed with no reference to what people may have to offer to Australia, but based solely upon the colour of a person's skin. Implicit in the suggestion that we should have quotas is the assumption that some people are morally superior solely on basis of the colour of their skin. Implicit in that is the assumption that some people are more deserving of a place in the sun than others.

How would this be put in place? Are we to have an annual spectacle where we debate how many Lebanese and how many Indians and how many Japanese we are going to allow into the country? Would we have a formula that says, `Three Indonesians equal one Indian, two Indians equal one Chinese, but on no occasion should two Wongs make a white'?

Views such as these are an affront to the fundamental right of each and every Australian to live their life in dignity. More importantly, in marginalising some Australians, in excluding them from the full participation in Australian society, we not only deprive them but we deprive ourselves of what they have to offer to us and the common good. This is a betrayal of all that Australia is, and all that Australia means and all that Australia can be. It is a betrayal of the principles of decency and a fair go on which this nation was built and to which we all subscribe. Importantly, it is a betrayal of all that we have done to be a beacon of hope and democracy to people less fortunate than ourselves.

These views cannot be the views of a party that believes in creating one nation, for this is the politics of exclusion. And the politics of exclusion is also to be seen in the attitude that this One Nation party has towards trade because One Nation would create a fortress Australia, a fortress Australia which would lock us away behind tariff walls to prevent imports. And as we close our doors to the world, the rest of the world will close their doors to us.

Their stated belief is that we do not need the rest of the world, but that is not true. Without the rest of the world, then who will buy the things that we produce? I make these comments not as a plea to reduce Australia's sovereignty, but a plea not to cut off our collective nose to spite our collective face.

If One Nation had its way, then we would be forced to consume everything that we produce. For the record, that would mean that each and every Australian, in a One Nation world, would be forced every year to eat 98 kilos of beef, 297 kilos of sugar and 1,286 kilos of wheat, to buy 36 kilos of wool and 33 kilos of cotton. But then I suppose after drinking 30.8 litres of wine we may not know about it. But that is what their politics would do.

The truth is this: we need those export dollars to maintain our standard of living. If One Nation has its way, we as a nation will be poorer because we will earn less but the cost of everything we produce will go up. And the people who will really be hurt are the working men and women of Australia and the poor and the elderly for whom cars, television sets, computers and clothes will cost more, but with less money to pay for them.

The people who will be hurt will be the people who work in the tourism industry. In 1996, tourism from Asia alone was worth $8 billion. The waiters, the cooks, the cleaners, the taxi drivers and the bus drivers who depend on that money will be the ones who lose their jobs. Our software industry, a world-class industry, will be shackled by the politics of these people—a world-class indus try destroyed because they believe we can live without the rest of the world.

They say that they are defending Australia. That is nonsense. This is not a defence of Australia. This is not going to create a strong Australia. What this is—let me make it very clear—is an admission by Mrs Hanson and her supporters that they do not believe that we can take on the rest of the world and win, that they do not believe that Australia can be competitive in the world marketplace, and an admission that they do not believe we can stride with greatness the world stage.

I am not one of those people. I believe in the greatness of Australia. I will not stand by and allow these people to create for us a second-best future. I will not stand by and allow these people to destroy the jobs and opportunities of young Australians because they no longer have the faith that we can be great.
Unlike Mrs Hanson, I believe that the greatness of our nation should not be hidden behind walls of fear and self-doubt.

I believe that the working men and women of this country, freed from the shackles of an inefficient tax system and the excessive burdens of red tape, can produce the export dollars to keep our country rich.
You only have to look at the success of our mining companies and our software developers and our construction companies to see that this is so.

I believe in an Australia restricted only by the breadth of our imagination and the depth of our belief. Most importantly I believe the greatness that is Australia demands a world stage on which to showcase its glory. The world should know that Australia still aspires to be great and the world should know what Australia's citizens, all of them, can achieve together.

Mr Acting Deputy President, ring out the bells and tell the world that there are still Australians with heart enough and courage enough to believe that we can be great. There are still Australians who will fight for the future of our country and there are still Australians who believe that the greatness of Australia does not lie in the past but in what we will achieve together in the future.

talk.start.para: —I want to speak briefly on the retirement today of the Hon. Elisabeth Kirkby as a member of the New South Wales Legislative Council. It is unusual for valedictories to be given in this chamber for members of another House of Parliament, but it is important to me, both personally and on behalf of the current team of Democrat senators, to formally record my very sincere thanks to Lis.

speech.para: Lis Kirkby has been an inspirational role model to the current generation of Democrat women and men alike. She joined the Australian Democrats in 1977 and first stood for election in that year. Later she was elected to the New South Wales Legislative Council, first taking up her seat in 1981.

I also joined the Democrats in 1977 and throughout the 1980s, when I was working my way through a myriad of internal positions from branch secretary, lower house candidate, state president et cetera, Lis provided a powerful role model for me as a strong woman in politics.

At the time of her election, Lis was one of only two female Democrats in parliament. The other, of course, was Janine Haines. At the end of her parliamentary career women MPs in the Democrats are almost the norm rather than the exception, with representation in all four parliaments. I know that this is a great source of pride to Lis as it is to me.

It is not Lis's gender alone which makes her a great role model. It is the qualities that Lis has brought to the job that have set her apart, qualities that are not always evident in public life. They include a true compassion for those who are in need; a fierce loyalty to her friends and to her staff, most of whom have gone on to be good friends; a strong belief in the value of parliament as an institution; an intellectual rigour which has been evident over all of her 17 years in parliament and a commitment to real debate over public policy; an enduring commitment to progressive public policy and values such as toler ance; and a charm, grace and courtesy which is both part of the woman herself and part of her success.

Lis is also a superb political campaigner. To observe her working a room of constituents, dealing with lobbyists, handling hostile media interviews, chairing a conference or handling internal party friction, all of which I have done over the years, is to watch a true professional at work. This has been reflected in our election results in that our best ever state election results in New South Wales have been when she has been leading the team.

In this place it is unusual for an MP to last 17 years in office. This in itself is worthy of comment. It is a hard life that we all lead no matter which party or which parliament we are in. Lis has not only put up with all of this but the experience has not disillusioned her or made her cynical as it does so many who share the experiences.

Lis was first elected when Don Chipp stood in my place and has outlasted six federal leaders and many more senators. At the beginning and at the end of her political career, Lis remains an optimist. I know that she believes in the power of persuasion, that most people are inherently good and that politics can be an honourable profession. I only hope that at the end of my career I can still share these views.

I have no need to chronicle Lis's many achievements in the New South Wales parliament. My colleague Senator Vicki Bourne will do some of that in a moment. Nor do I need to be grave and serious in my remarks. After all, anyone who knows Lis will understand that she is not retiring but simply changing careers. I know that she leaves the parliament with friends on all sides of politics and we all expect to continue to see a great deal of her.

I only wanted to place on the public record my own thanks to a successful politician who, through her own example, has been an inspiration to many in the Australian Democrats and also an inspiration to many others in public life, not only to Democrat senators and MLCs but also to party officers such as the national secretary, Sam Hudson and longtime campaign director, Stephen Swift, himself a former staffer. From all of us, I want to say to Lis, thanks for everything.

talk.start.para: —I am very pleased to join my colleague Senator Lees in paying tribute to our New South Wales colleague, the Hon. Elisabeth Kirkby, who as Meg has said, is intending to retire today from the New South Wales parliament.

speech.para: `The Honourable' is not always a title that fits comfortably with those who are entitled to use it, but it does with Lis. Lis is a very honourable person. I first met her as a fellow Democrat in 1977 and she was already very well-known by then for her acting, particularly in Number 96. I was struck at that stage by her very friendly manner, particularly to me and, I must admit, being young and rather naive at the time, I did not expect that from someone as famous as Lis was. That part in Number 96 followed Lis through the rest of her life. I know she formed very firm friendships with other cast members which exist to this day.

I well remember the time when the two of us we were travelling through rural New South Wales together and taking calls on open-line radio. One listener rang to say she was pleased Lis had recovered from her temporary blindness. Lis politely pointed out that it was in fact her character in Number 96 who had been temporarily blinded, but she thanked the caller for her concern anyway.

Lis is comfortable and happy in any company at all. She lives in the country near Temora. I have seen her out on her farm in wellingtons and jeans doing very farmer-like things and I have seen her in the city looking incredibly elegant. She is just comfortable wherever she is. She is comfortable in whatever company she finds herself. It is an enormous gift and a terrific talent and something that I wish I had more of. Unfortunately, I do not.

She has been the longest serving Democrat in office, I think I can say. She has seen three Democrat senators leave and she is still there. Now that she leaves the New South Wales parliament, she leaves many friends in the parliament. I was fortunate enough to be there last Wednesday for her last budget speech and I was really pleased to see that New South Wales parliamentarians turned up and listened. Max Willis, the President of the New South Wales Legislative Council, was in the chair for the first half of her speech and the Deputy President, Johno Johnson was in the chair for the second half. I thought that was a lovely tribute to Lis and something that you do not always expect to see. It was very good of them to do it. It was really nice too that her grandson Hugh was in the gallery for that speech. He is only about 10 now. He will have that memory for the rest of his life.

I see Lis not only as a colleague and a role model, although she is both of those, but certainly as a friend and somebody that I intend not to lose track of and not to lose touch with. I wish her well in everything she now decides to do and I am sure she will do it superbly, whatever it is, because that is what she has always done. I look forward to finding out what the next chapter is in this really quite extraordinary life.

talk.start.para: —This afternoon, in the short time available, I wish to comment on some media stories that appeared in Tasmania in recent days. These media stories related to the now very well run and profitable Tasrail operation. For the first time in its 130-year history, Tasrail is finally running at a profit. It is not coincidental that, for the first time in its 130-year history, it is in fact in private ownership. And that, of course, is a matter that ought be considered by all Australians when they consider the privatisation of certain of our public instrumentalities around this country.

speech.para: The history of Tasrail was that for a long time it was run by the state government at a considerable loss. Thereafter, in the 1970s, Gough Whitlam's Labor government took it over and ran it as a federal enterprise—once again, continually losing money to the tune of millions of dollars per year. Under the excellent guidance of the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, a program was undertaken whereby Tasrail would be privatised. I was very pleased to have been nominated by the minister to look after the Tasmanian aspect of that privatisation process.

It would be fair to say that when it was first announced there were all the merchants of doom and gloom, including Labor senators saying that they would want a Senate inquiry into this proposal. They sought to do everything to destroy what was clearly a positive move on behalf of Tasrail and the people of Tasmania.

After a while, even the unions came on side, because when you tracked the history of Tasrail, in my home state, you saw a railway in decline: job losses, continuous; rail closures, continuous—it was going in a downward spiral, faster and faster all the time. Yet in the media in Tasmania on Saturday, 20 June we were getting some very good stories, such as:
Tasrail's new owner, Australian Transport Network, has underpinned its optimism in Tasmania's future with a two-year $12.5 million investment in a new fleet of locomotives.

And the company announced that the fortunes of Tasrail had been turned around dramatically since they took over in November 1997, with a 20 per cent increase in business putting the rail network in the black for the first time in its 130-year history.

Whilst governments continued to try to play trains and fiddled around, Tasrail continually lost. As soon as private enterprise took over, we have seen already a 20 per cent increase in the cartage of the goods that they are undertaking. Also, as part of the ongoing growth in rail under private ownership, there is now under construction at Burnie, in my home state of Tasmania, new cement trucks that will increase capacity from Railton's Goliath cement works to the wharf at Devonport. The article goes on to say:

Other improvement programmes identified include upgrading lines through sleeper replacement, development of the Don River Railway workshops and installation of railway crossing signals along the North-West line.
There is also talk of upgrading a number of the tracks.

So instead of having a railway in government ownership under constant decline, what the Tasmanian economy and the Tasmanian people are now experiencing is a well-run Tasmanian rail network, under private ownership, making a profit and putting jobs back into the railway system and, indeed, the construction of the new carriages for the Goliath cement works.

We are really seeing a boost to the Tasmanian economy and to the Tasmanian transport infrastructure. That has all been occasioned because the federal government, despite opposition from the Labor Party, the Democrats and Greens, took the decision that Tasrail ought be privatised. Jobs are now secure and, indeed, there will be growth in jobs. More cargo is now being taken by rail: there has been a 20 per cent growth.

When people consider the privatisation of some of the other government instrumentalities they ought to have a look at the experience of Tasmanian Rail and come to realise that there are many facets of government enterprise at the moment which can clearly be undertaken more efficiently by the private sector and, what is more, create jobs, create investment and create infrastructure at no cost to the long-suffering taxpayer.

In Tasmania's situation with the Tasrail network, the losses were about $8 million per annum which, because it was in effect the federal subsidy, was taken off the state government's grants each year and, as a result, the Tasmanian government had approximately $8 million less in its budget allocations. As a result of this, there is no longer a federal subsidy to Tasrail, as a result of which, the Tasmanian government and the taxpayers of Tasmania are relieved of that $8 million subsidy. All around it has been a win-win for the people of Tasmania and for the long-suffering taxpayers of this country.

I would invite people who have a reactionary approach to the concept of privatisation to have a look at some of the achievements that can be made for the Australian people and for the benefit of industry and for the benefit of jobs growth in providing a private service where in the past governments have failed; governments of both persuasions and both state and federal have failed. Within a very short period of time private enterprise has prevailed, making a profit and providing greater investment, extending the rail network and increasing job opportunities especially, as you would know, Mr Acting Deputy President, in that depressed area of our home state of Tasmania, Burnie, which is a matter that I will seek to address later on today in relation to the delegation that is here visiting our parliament, concerned about the loss of jobs at the Burnie pulp mill.

I believe that John Sharp who has just announced his retirement from the federal parliament ought to be congratulated for his initiative and for the tremendous work he did in achieving this excellent privatisation for the people of Tasmania and relieving the taxpayers of the burdens which they so unnecessarily had to bear over 130 years because there were those who believed that governments knew how to run trains. The fact is they do not. Private enterprise knows better and everybody is better off as a result.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 1.58 p.m. to 2.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Will the minister confirm that the Japanese economy is officially in recession, with their economy having shrunk by 0.7 per cent at the end of March this year and with a forecast further contraction of 0.5 per cent in 1998? How does the minister reconcile the recession in Japan with the Howard government's forecasts for the Japanese economy—forecasts of 0.25 per cent growth this year and 1.25 per cent growth in 1999? Given that Japan accounts for 20 per cent of Australia's total exports, will the minister advise the Senate of the impact of the Japanese recession on Australian exports?

—Thank you, Senator Cook, for that important question. Many Australians are looking closely at the Japanese economy in the hope that the recovery program announced by the Japanese government will be effected and effective. Senator Cook, it is correct that economic activity in Japan remains weak. Domestic demand has been flat for the last 12 months. The contribu tion to growth from net exports is weakening. Consumer and business confidence is low in Japan and this has been exacerbated by problems, which we have noted, in the financial sector. Growth through 1997 was largely supported by net exports but, in the face of the regional problems that we are all aware of, net exports weakened in the first quarter of 1998.

answer.para: The overall outlook for the Japanese economy is for little or no growth in 1998, but activity is expected to pick up during the course of the year in response to substantial government investment spending. Let me make this clear: the Australian government supports the substantial policy measures announced on 24 April by the government of Japan, aimed at achieving a demand led growth. We also welcome the recent announcement by the Japanese government of its determination to restructure its troubled financial sector as a matter of the highest urgency. This was noted at the recent Manila framework and the G7 deputies' meeting in Tokyo.

Structural reform, particularly of the financial sector, is essential to help establish, in our view, a sound basis for a recovery and a return to sustainable economic growth in Japan. It will be important for the Japanese government to find the proper balance between the short-term measures designed to stimulate domestic demand and employment measures that help advance structural reform.

In conclusion, Senator Cook may be aware of comments the Treasurer made recently about the economy in Japan. The Treasurer said that the situation in Japan today is very serious. He indicated that we had our officials in Tokyo on the weekend and we were one of the nations that put together a meeting between Asian nations, Australia, New Zealand and the G7 and they looked at the situation in Japan. As the Treasurer said, if the Japanese cannot fix their financial system there will be a serious threat to world growth. The Treasurer went on to say that the Japanese government has announced that it wants to deal with the problem and has set aside money to do so. What is required now, as the Treasurer said, is the political will to come in and take the tough decisions. He concluded by saying:
But I must say it is very much in Australia's interests and the region's interests and the world's interests for decisive action in relation to the Japanese financial system.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, for underlying the very serious situation in the Japanese economy, which goes to my point: in view of that very serious situation and the remarks being made by the Treasurer about it being `very serious,' do you now stand by the federal government's optimistic forecasts for a Japanese economic recovery? Those forecasts were: this year, 0.25 per cent growth; next year 1.25 per cent growth. Isn't it the case that the government has misunderstood in the budget the situation in Japan, casting serious doubt on the assumptions underlying the budget brought down by you last month?
—I am not sure that you were listening to the comprehensive and detailed answer I gave you.
—Rubbish!

—We would not have had the question if Senator Cook had been listening, Senator Conroy. I said that the outlook for Japan is for little or no growth in 1998 overall, but for activity to pick up during the course of the year in response to substantial government investment spending. That is what I said and, as you are aware, I mentioned the recovery program that was announced in Japan. I indicated also the announced reforms in relation to the financial sector. It is in all our interests that those reforms are put into effect quickly and responsibly. As a result, we can look forward to a recovery. But, as I said, the situation is serious.

—My question without notice is to the Minister for Resources and Energy. The minister will be aware of a sharp fall in exploration expenditure within the gold mining industry, a major Australian export earner. Minister, what is the cause of this? What is the government doing to assist an essential industry to regional Australia?

—I would like to thank Senator Crane for that question. Senator Crane always has had a consuming interest in the gold industry, not only in regards to Australia as a whole but in regards to Western Australia in particular. Gold is our second largest export earner with exports this year valued at an estimated $5,600 million. It is the mainstay of many regional communities, both directly and indirectly. It has resulted in the establishment of a strong manufacturing base. For example—and this gives an idea of the spin-off—50 per cent of the market of Elphinstone, the major employer in Burnie, is reliant on the Western Australian gold industry.

answer.para: Producers have done well in an uncertain market caused by falling Asian demand and certainly over the extent and timing of future sales by European central banks. Production costs have come down by around seven per cent and the larger companies have been able to partially offset lower prices by forward selling and, of course, the lower valuation of the dollar.
To find one of the major reasons why exploration is falling off, as asked for in the senator's question, we need go no further than an ATSIC report dated February this year. That ATSIC report says:

There are some serious problems emerging with the use of the Right to Negotiate processes and these will require attention by us. In particular, while the passage of exploration licences through the Right to Negotiate Process has been fairly smooth, that is not the case for mining leases in Western Australia. Those mining leases are normally extensions of exploration rather than the start of a new mine but nonetheless it is on these leases where development ultimately takes place.

The fact is that mining leases are being held up in the Right to Negotiate process—some 1,913 out of the 2,094 tenements submitted to the process remain subject to negotiation. Furthermore, the rate of objections by native title parties to the grant of exploration licences is starting to increase significantly which will mean further delays.

The bottom line is that before the WA Government started using the Right to Negotiate process, about 2,800 tenements were in the system at any one time waiting for approval—after using the process the number has increased to 7,400. This must be a potent message for the electorate of WA which perceives its well being to be based on the mining industry.

That is a direct quote from an ATSIC report of February this year. Gold exploration is expected to fall about 14 per cent this year. It will be the first fall in exploration expenditure in the industry for eight years. The blame for this, as ATSIC itself confirms, lies squarely with the unworkable Native Title Act, in particular the discriminatory lose-lose right to negotiate provisions. This downturn is the result of the failure of the Labor Party, of those opposite, to pass the government's native title bill and the 10-point plan.

I held a round table with the gold industry in February this year. Senator Crane and I met last month with the gold industry working group which arose out of that round table. We were working through a number of issues with the gold industry, including taxation, infrastructure and trade barriers, but by far the greatest concern of the gold industry was native title and its inability to actually deliver. The point was made to us over and over again that of all the issues for the gold industry, including price, the one which is of greatest concern by far was the Native Title Act and the absolute necessity to pass the 10-point plan. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I understand, Minister, that in addition to the situation which exists in the mining industry, particularly the gold industry, there are currently a number of mines on-stream throughout Australia, including in New South Wales, Western Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. Could you explain the importance of getting the right to negotiate process right so that these mines may commence and create jobs?

—There are currently 12 new gold mines under construction or committed in New South Wales, Western Australia, Victoria and Tasmania. They involve a capital expenditure of $800 million and will create thousands of new jobs in regional Australia if they are allowed to proceed. This government wants to keep the growth growing. We are interested in new jobs and new opportunities in regional areas for the manufacturers, small businesses and new industries in regional Australia, but without the 10-point plan it will not happen and those opposite will have to shoulder the blame.

answer.para: I remind those opposite of the comments made by AMEC, the Association of Mining and Exploration Companies, which said recently in their publication:

The federal Labor opposition seems to have lost its way on native title and has been remarkably recalcitrant in addressing the nation's interest rather than matters of ideology and short-term political gains.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Will the minister advise the Senate how large the black economy is in Australia in terms of tax revenue forgone? Where does Australia rate in terms of its black economy compared to other OECD nations? Can the minister name an OECD nation which has a GST and a smaller black economy than Australia?

—Thank you for the question, Senator Bishop. Senator Bishop, it was a great pity that you were not—I think I am right in saying this—at the Senate estimates committee where Senator Cook asked some distinctly non-probing questions in relation to the black economy. It makes particularly interesting reading. Before you accepted that question, you should have really—
—Senator Kemp, direct your remarks to the chair.

—Before that question was accepted, it would have been very advisable for Senator Bishop to closely read the transcript of that Senate estimates committee. I think the first point made was about the variety of estimates on the size of the black economy.
—What is your estimate?
—What is your estimate!
—Well, what is it?

—Oh! Senator Jacinta Collins has come into the debate. Oh, dear! Madam President, I am under acute pressure from over there, as you can hear, now that Senator Jacinta Collins has bought into this debate. The Senate estimates showed that there are a variety of estimates on the size of the cash economy, ranging between $5 and $15 billion. I advise Senator Bishop to read it closely on the basis of those particular estimates and how they were arrived at. There is no official estimate on the size of the economy.
—So you have got no benchmark!

—I am under acute pressure from Senator Jacinta Collins, Madam President. I am really under pressure here. It might help Senator Jacinta Collins if she listened to an answer rather than chanting and calling out.

answer.para: Senator Jacinta Collins interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Here comes the chorus. The reason I urge Senator Bishop to read the Senate estimates Hansard —and I suspect, in relation to this question, that there may be some press people who wish to read it—is that what really happened was that Senator Cook made a goose of himself over this. What he was trying to establish was whether a broad based indirect tax would be more effective at tackling the cash economy than is the current system. Senator Bishop, I advise you to read very closely the evidence that was tendered to Senator Cook by the Secretary to the Treasury and others. In that you will find, I think, a pretty definitive answer to the incredibly lacklustre approach.
—Do you remember it?
—The question was: what is the official size of the black economy? I have indicated that there are a range of estimates and I have quoted figures. I said there is no official figure.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Kemp, just a moment. There have been interjections throughout this question which make it difficult for the minister to answer. The level of interjection at this stage is totally unacceptable.

interjection.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order!

—It is not actually difficult to answer the question; it is difficult to be heard because of the noise. The question was: what is the official estimate of the size of the cash economy? The answer was that there were a variety of estimates given. They are set out in detail in the Senate estimates Hansard . There is no official figure. The range that was given in the Hansard was between $5 billion and $15 billion.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That is what I said. No-one listens—that is the trouble. They are all yelling out. Senator Jacinta Collins is coming in hard and making an untelling point. That was stated, Senator. (Time expired)

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. On the basis that you have told us there are no official estimates of the size of the black economy, Minister, on what empirical evidence did the Prime Minister rely when he stated that a GST would recover $15 billion lost to the black economy? Is the minister aware that, when Canada introduced its GST, there was a huge increase in the black economy caused by bartering and by increased cash transactions?
—Again, this is such an ordinary question.
—Then why can't you answer it?
—Do you know what the answer to the question was in Senate estimates? The answer was:

answer.para: Senator Kemp —If you perhaps were less cute and read out the full quote, Senator, it might assist the committee.

The full quote was then read out. It was indicated that one estimate of the size of the cash economy was $15 billion, et cetera. That question was asked. Was it definitively answered? That is what I have to ask.

One thing we know is that the Labor Party did virtually nothing on this issue in its 13 years. Of course, there is an increasing fear in the Labor Party that the sort of tax reform we are bringing in is tackling a range of problems which the Labor Party were never prepared to tackle.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, and it relates to yesterday's exciting announcement of the $9 billion high-speed rail link between Melbourne and Darwin. Can the minister outline—
—Order! Just a moment, Senator Ferris, I cannot hear you. Order!

—I will begin my question again so that the minister can hear it. It relates to yesterday's exciting announcement of the $9 billion high-speed rail link between Melbourne and Darwin. Will the minister outline the potential benefits of this project to regional Australia? What is his response to claims that this project will endanger the viability of the Adelaide-Darwin rail link, a project to which the Howard government has already committed $100 million?
—Order! Just a moment, Senator. There are far too many interjections.

—This is an important question, and it gives me the opportunity to contrast the record of the former Labor government with that of the Howard government in relation to rail infrastructure. Everyone remembers the pitiful state in which the Labor government left Australian railways: 7,000 jobs lost in 13 years, the closure of South Australia's interstate passenger services, the closure of dozens of rail lines and broken promises to hundreds of railway workers. That is what Australians remember of Labor. It was a dismissal situation with very little hope for the future. Come the coalition government, and we inject some $2 billion to revitalise Australia's railway system.

answer.para: The Alice Springs to Darwin railway is well on track for the first time. Remember what Mr Hawke said 15 years ago. He said:
I promise that only the Labor government can be trusted to build the Alice Springs-Darwin railway.

They had 13 years in office and delivered nothing. What happened now is that the Howard government has committed $100 million of public money, complemented by two other coalition governments putting in a further $200 million and all of a sudden there is the prospect of viability. An announcement is expected about the end of October.
Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —They laugh at this. Because they failed, they have to laugh at this government's achievements. An announcement is expected about the end of October. The potential is there: 2,000 jobs for South Australians during the construction phase, hundreds of millions of dollars being invested; a new avenue for the export of South Australia's resources; and national infrastructure is being developed.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my left are making far too much noise.

—We are delivering where the Labor government failed to deliver. Yesterday's announcement is another example of that: a $9 billion rail link between Melbourne and Darwin and potential for further national infrastructure development—something that all reasonable Australians will be pleased about. But, of course, Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht thought they could win a cheap political point by saying that it undermined the South Australian project. One hundred million dollars is being put in by the Howard government.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise on my left. It is almost impossible for me to hear Senator Hill when I am only a short distance from him.

—One hundred million dollars has been put in by the Howard government for the Alice Springs-Darwin line. No public money is being put into the eastern states one, and yet Senator Bolkus said that in some way the government is favouring the eastern states. It is hard to develop any credible argument from that perspective.

answer.para: Senator Schacht interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Schacht; cease shouting.

—To see the private sector for the first time coming up with major national railway infrastructure projects is something that is exciting and not to be knocked. It is giving great hope to this country, finally, after the dismal years of Labor, to see that the rail system is starting to come on track.

answer.para: There were further good announcements yesterday. Labor would have missed them, of course, because they are not interested in these things. There was also the announcement that the Great Southern Railways—the private owners of the interstate passenger service—announced the extension of the Ghan service from Alice Springs to Melbourne. This is more jobs. Finally, after 13 years of Labor we have a government that is ensuring that we have a modern, national railway infrastructure, and that is great news for Australia.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the minister please give some examples of significant infrastructure projects which are now benefiting all South Australians as a result of the Howard government's policies?

—That is a fair question, too, because this government has invested an enormous amount of public money in the economy of South Australia and we are actually proud of that. We think it is important. It gets knocked by Senator Bolkus and Senator Schacht, but we think it is important:

answer.para: $138 million of federal money for the construction of the Mount Barker freeway only a few months ago; 1,500 jobs for the benefit of South Australia; $48 million for the Adelaide airport runway project; and $22 million from the Natural Heritage Trust to South Australia to do something for rural and regional South Australia.

Add that to $100 million for the Alice Springs to Darwin railway and you will realise that this government—the coalition government; the Howard government—is investing more money in the capital infrastructure of South Australia than ever before. What a contrast to the dismal record of Labor. At least we are establishing this vitally important nation infrastructure. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Madam President—
—Order! Senator Schacht! Senator Conroy is attempting to ask a question. You should at least have the courtesy to listen to your own questions.

—My question is addressed to the Assistant Treasurer. Does the government support the banks' call for financial services to be zero rated while they sing the virtues of imposing a GST on every Australian household? Should banks be zero rated and therefore able to claim a rebate on the costs they have borne, while at the same time they continue to close branches in rural Australia and jack up bank fees at every available opportunity? Does the government support the banks getting a tax break under zero rating, while they continue to treat rural Australia and ordinary banking consumers, such as pensioners, with such contempt?

—The only people who treat taxpayers with contempt are the Labor Party at the moment, because the Labor Party apparently opposes tax reform. I think most Australians recognise that we have a system which needs to be basically reformed. The first point is that the people who are treating the Australian taxpayer with contempt are the Labor Party and the Labor Party's unwillingness to consider and discuss—
—Have a crack at the question, waffler!

—I was asked about treating the taxpayer with contempt. What I am saying is that the only people I am aware of who are treating the Australian taxpayer with contempt are those in the Australian Labor Party. So that answers that part of question.
—The waffle machine is zero rated!
—The person I would zero rate would be Robert Ray, actually, for his contribution to informed discussion in the parliament. I will answer that part of the question.

answer.para: We are aware that there is a widespread discussion in the community on tax reform, and various groups of people are putting forward particular views. At an appropriate time the Prime Minister will announce a detailed tax reform package. That tax reform package will be in the interests of Australian taxpayers. It will be a tax package which will encourage people to save, to invest and to create jobs. We are constructively tackling yet another major problem that was left to this government by the Australian Labor Party. What is the contribution you get from the Australian Labor Party? You get a question like that from Senator Conroy. That is the Labor Party's big contribution to tax reform. I can assure Senator Conroy that we will have a detailed, comprehensive package; a fair package which addresses the serious problems in the taxation system which was left to this government by the Australian Labor Party.

What the community wants is for the Australian Labor Party to try to adopt a constructive attitude to tax reform. It expects the Labor Party, if they do not accept our tax reform proposals, to constructively address them. It is interesting to contrast the constructive attitude that ACOSS has taken in the lead-up to this debate on tax reform and the sort of attitude that the Labor Party are taking. It is quite interesting, when you contrast the two, just why the Labor Party are treating the taxpayer with contempt. I suggest that, if Senator Conroy wants to take a constructive role in tax reform, he sit down and do some hard work rather than branch stacking.

talk.start.para: —What the community wants is Senator Parer to pay tax. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the large donations made by the banks to the BCA tax campaign be tax deductible as legitimate business expenses?

—I do not give tax advice in question time to people like you. If you have a serious question, Senator, I am happy to provide you with a detailed answer. We welcome the constructive support that many groups are giving to tax reform.
—Like ACOSS.

—Like ACOSS, like the business groups. The Labor Party stands alone on this. The Labor Party alone apparently do not believe, if you can judge by their attitude rather than their words, that tax reform is necessary. That is why I repeat that I believe the Labor Party are treating Australian taxpayers with contempt.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the Republic of Poland led by the Marshal of the Senate, Mrs Alicja Grzeskowiak. On behalf of honourable senators, I have pleasure in welcoming you to the Senate, and I trust that your visit to this country will be both informative and enjoyable. With the concurrence of senators, I invite the marshal to take a place on the floor.
—Hear, hear!

interjection.para: Mrs Alicja Grzeskowiak was seated accordingly.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Resources and Energy. Minister, as action minister for the Jabiluka uranium mine, are you aware of the humiliation suffered by the Australian government at the UNESCO world heritage meeting last night in Paris? Are you aware that UNESCO member countries are sending—

—Madam President, I raise a point of order. It is one thing to ask a question seeking factual information, but it is another thing altogether to colour it with a prejudgment which, on any view of the world, is not something that is accepted. It should not be part of the premise of a question. You should rule that part of it out of order.

—There is no point of order, Madam President. The senator is entitled to ask the question she wants. It is up to the minister to say whether or not he is aware and whether or not he believes the government has been humiliated.

—On the point of order, Madam President: surely we have to listen to the question to determine whether or not the government is, or may possibly be, embarrassed. I ask that at least Senator Allison be allowed to ask the question before we turn to points of order.
—It is a matter for the minister to deal with in his answer as to whether or not he accepts the description. There is no point of order.

—Thank you, Madam President. I will start again. Minister, as action minister for the Jabiluka uranium mine, are you aware of the humiliation suffered by the Australian government at the UNESCO world heritage meeting last night in Paris? Are you aware that UNESCO member countries are sending their top level world heritage team to investigate the cultural and environmental threats to Kakadu? Are you aware that the World Heritage Bureau has requested that all activities stop immediately until the inspection team has assessed the area? Are you aware that Kakadu may be placed on the world heritage in danger list? Will you give a commitment to Australian people right now that you will stop all mining preparation activities on site to meet the request of UNESCO?

—My understanding is that the World Heritage Commission has spoken favourably about the way Australia handles its world heritage areas. I am a little surprised about the comment about humiliation because—
—You'd know all about that, Warwick!
—That is beneath you, Robert. What surprises me about the Democrats is that I thought their policy was to stop all uranium mining—the whole lot; Olympic Dam, Ranger and the development of Jabiluka.
—And to stop greenhouse at the same time.
—Yes. I think ex-senator Peter Walsh used to refer to the fairies at the bottom of the garden—and you have gone back to it.

answer.para: What we have is a process in place whereby the ERA or the previous owner back in 1982 had agreements with the traditional owners to develop Jabiluka. This was transferred in about 1991, with the support of the Northern Land Council representing the traditional owners. When this government came into power, of course, it got rid of the ridiculous three-mine uranium policy—and I know that even Robert Ray agrees with me, because he told me one day when crossing the chamber when he was in government.

talk.start.para: —What is the Labor Party's policy now?
—Good question, Senator Hill: what is the Labor Party's policy?
—You said you paid tax at the same time!

—When we removed the three-mine policy, this meant that companies were able to develop mines in accordance with strict environmental principles. The ERA company was designated by me as a proponent over two years ago, and it went through the environmental process. Agreed: there is a group up there, one of the traditional owner groups, that is opposed to the development of the mine. I might say that that was the group that supported it and agreed to it back in 1981 or 1982 and that was reinforced in 1991.

answer.para: I would also point out that I know the opposition is coming from one particular group led by Ms Jackie Katona, who with Yvonne Margarula came to see me. I made the point very clearly that, if Jackie Katona was thinking of the Aborigines, I thought it was in their best interests to maximise the environmental, the economic and the social returns to the Aborigines.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister is obviously not aware of what happened in Paris last night, and no doubt that will come through fairly shortly. I ask again: Minister, will you and Minister Hill then proclaim the surrounding Kakadu world heritage area to protect it for future generations of Australians? Also, you mentioned the conditions which apply to the Kakadu Jabiluka uranium mine, one of the most important of which was the condition that there be a cultural management plan in place before construction of any mining operations. Why was this not done, and what other conditions have you conveniently overlooked?

—Senator Allison, who belongs to a party that talked about keeping everyone honest, came into an estimates committee and made an outrageous claim about me in regard to mining the Barrier Reef. When I asked her, she said that she had it on good authority and was not going to dob anyone in.

answer.para: Opposition senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! Senators on my right will cease making so much noise.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order as to relevance. I did not ask a question about the Great Barrier Reef; it was about the Kakadu National Park and the Jabiluka uranium mine.
—I remind the senator of the supplementary question.

—Let me make the point again—and everyone knows this or should know it, although the Democrats would like to convince them otherwise: neither Jabiluka nor Ranger are within the Kakadu National Park. So let us make that very clear.

answer.para: I saw the article in the paper in regard to the heritage management plan. It was based on the failure, I might say, of the journalist to find out the actual conditions imposed on ERA by me. The environmental requirements require the carrying out of an archaeological survey on each area to be affected by the construction before construction work commences in that area. The six-monthly report advised that ERA had appointed an environmental officer as required by ER3. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is to addressed to Senator Ellison, the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister confirm that it is the government's intention not only to deny that many new job agencies are facing financial ruin, not only to deny them assistance to avert financial ruin but also to hasten their financial ruin by subjecting them to a GST? Is it true that job agencies will be hit by a GST, both by having to pay tax on inputs to the business and charge it on the outputs?
