—Order! The behaviour of senators shouting across the chamber at each other is totally unacceptable.

—That question really does relate more to Senator Kemp than me. But Senator Kemp has answered that question eloquently. In fact, I thought he succinctly described the coalition government's approach to tax reform and the benefits it would bring to Australians.

answer.para: The government has not announced that there will be any GST applicable to the jobs network system. Senator Jacinta Collins knows very well that this government is formulating its tax reform package and it has made no such announcement. That is a matter for the Treasurer to decide.

But let me deal with that part of the question which does relate to the portfolio—and that relates to the assistance that this government gave those jobs network providers. I can tell the Senate that, in 19 sites across Australia, some 2,000 staff of jobs network providers attended for briefings from the department. Not only that, but we gave them a help desk in relation to computer matters so that jobs network providers could have that assistance. We also have on the Internet a jobs network members' information site where they can get information in relation to this. So what this government has done is not only set out the contract that is available to the jobs providers but given them assistance as well.

Senator Collins has asked what we are going to do about these job providers, what assistance we are giving them and what we are going to do to help them. We have done a great deal in helping those jobs network providers. In relation to their individual success, it is up to them. It is a performance based system, and it is appropriate that it be so. We have contracted with more than 300 organisations, and more than 400 sites are involved in providing job seekers in Australia with more choice and more opportunity.

talk.start.para: —I ask a supplementary question. Did the minister really say that the GST's application to job agencies is a matter for Treasury to decide? My question was directed to whether the minister, not Senator Kemp, was standing up for job agencies in the negotiations about tax reform. How will job agencies recoup the additional expenses imposed on them by a GST? Will the government pay them higher fees for job placements, or will they be left with no option but to pass the costs on to their clients: employers and the unemployed?

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. Under standing order 73, hypothetical matters are not allowed to be asked. With due respect, in relation to a lot of questions from the opposition today, standing order 73 would be a very welcome read for them. That is clearly hypothetical. No announcement has been made in relation to a GST on anything, let alone on those job agencies, and I ask you to rule the question out of order.

—On the point of order, Madam President, I note that today you have allowed a number of questions and supplementary questions in relation to a GST. I can understand why Senator Abetz, a desperate member of the coalition government, does not want the opposition to be asking questions about the GST, but I would ask you to be consistent with the rulings you have made throughout question time today and to allow the opposition to question the government about the GST, as will the opposition right through to the election, and so will the Australian community.

—Hypothetical material is not appropriate. It can be used as a descriptive matter, but no minister would be required or asked to answer anything that related to a hypothetical matter. But there are issues within the question that the minister may well want to make comment upon.

—On the point of order, Madam President: the government, at a cost of $42 million to the Australian taxpayer, has got a task force to develop a GST for Austral ia. That is government policy. There is nothing hypothetical at all about this government and a GST.
—I have ruled on that and have indicated that. You are merely seeking to reinforce my ruling, thank you, Senator Cook.

—What I said in my answer was that the Treasurer will decide these matters; not Treasury but the Treasurer. The Hansard will prove me correct. It is obvious that Senator Collins is a great fan of Geoffrey Robertson, because this is a great deal to do with a hypothetical. The tax reform package will be for the benefit of all Australians.

—My question is directed to Senator Kemp, the Assistant Treasurer. Is the minister aware of concerns such as those raised by the Gold Coast City Council relating to the coalition's amendment of item 192 of the Sales Tax (Exemptions and Classifications) Act 1992? Is it correct that this amendment will significantly impact on the financial viability of many local councils' community based business activities? Further, is it also the case that ratepayers around the nation will be able to thank the coalition for increased fees for important community services such as public swimming pools, community halls, public sporting complexes and camping grounds that will result from this amendment? Is this an example of the government balancing its own budget by passing on additional costs to the community?

—Senator Colston, I am aware of the issue that you have raised in particular, because this is a matter that you have be concerned about on previous occasions. In fact, if I recall, you also wrote to me on this particular matter. Senator Colston referred to section 192. The exemption provided by section 192 was being used in an unintended manner, with some part of the benefits at least going to the private sector through the development and refurbishment of projects such as shopping centres, hotels, casinos and apartment blocks. The government is aware that a Senate select committee either had or is holding an inquiry into this amendment.

answer.para: Senator Colston, the specific issue which you raise, and which I think you have raised with me by correspondence before, relates to the effect on local councils. The amendment contains two tests in relation to the use of property. The property must be occupied by what is termed an always exempt person or, alternatively, principally by a person who is providing services to an always exempt person. In the latter case, the property must be used principally for the provision of those services.

The amendment referred to by Senator Colston includes a list of the types of properties which will be excluded from exemption regardless of whether they will be able to satisfy either of those two tests. In relation to Senator Colston's comments regarding local council facilities, I can advise him that local council facilities such as swimming pools, community halls and such things as entertainment venues would continue to qualify for an exemption where they are operated by a local council. Where these facilities are controlled and operated by a private agent, exemption may still apply if the arrangement is such that the private agent is providing a service to the local council. As I said, this is a matter which Senator Colston has shown some particular interest in before, and I think that he will be pleased with the answer that I have given. I certainly hope he will be.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the minister representing the Attorney-General. Is the minister aware that a GST is likely to increase the cost of legal services by almost the full amount at which it is levied? Is the minister aware that a GST levied at a rate of 10 percent on our national legal services outlays of $5.25 billion would increase the cost of legal services for Australians by a staggering $525 million a year? It would make the average will cost $10 more, conveyancing on a home $50 more expensive and an average workers compensation case would be $800 extra. Has the government made any assessment of the impact of a GST on the ability of Australians to access justice? If not, why not?

—I thank Senator McKiernan for the question and for demonstrating, as some of his colleagues already have, that they have no concept of the benefit of tax reform for Australia and no concept of the simple mechanics of a change in indirect taxes. They have no concept whatsoever, and so they confirm why it was that in 13 years they never properly reformed the tax system: they do not understand how it works. They do not understand about inputs and outputs and they look at any question of tax as being an add-on because that is what they did.

answer.para: We all remember the previous government's record in this respect. We remember the previous Prime Minister saying, `You are going to get these tax cuts.' They are now L-A-W law tax cuts—the tax cuts that were never delivered. The difference between the former government on tax and this government on tax is that we told the public what we were going to do before the last election. We told them we wanted to sell Telstra and we told them we had a family tax package, and we delivered. We will do the same before the next election and we will leave it up to the Australian people to decide.

Senator McKiernan, the short answer to your question as to whether I agree with you that there would be a necessary increase of some $525 million is `no'. The simple reason I do not agree with you is that you do not understand about tax on inputs versus outputs and the deduction between the two. You do not understand the mechanics of it, so I cannot help you.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for reminding the Senate of the Prime Minister's promise in the last election to never ever introduce a GST. That is the promise, minister, and thank you for reminding us. My question directed you to the impact of a GST on the battlers of this nation. You have very cleverly evaded that question, minister. Can I ask you to take the earlier part of the question—
—Order! Senators on my right will cease interjecting. The minister is entitled to hear the question.

—Minister, I would like to know if the GST would increase the cost of an average family law matter by $1,200. Would it increase the cost of an average workers compensation case by $3,500? Would the government exempt legal services from a GST or would it take any other measures to counteract the effect of a GST that would otherwise prevent many ordinary mums and dads from having their day in court? Or will the government continue to attack the right of ordinary Australians, as you have done through your slashing of legal aid, massive increases in court and tribunal fees and cuts to services designed to keep Australian families together? (Time expired)

—Senator McKiernan understands the point of the answer I gave him: that this government was honest with the Australian public last time about the initiatives it wanted to implement. We said we wanted to sell Telstra, we said we wanted to have a family tax package and a range of other initiatives, and we have done it. And we will do the same this time. We will go to the Australian people and tell them what we want to do, and they will decide. But, Senator McKiernan, if you keep displaying—by coming out with these spurious figures all over the place—that you have not the slightest concept of how any reform to the taxation system would work, you will not do yourself any good. Can I equally point out to you, Senator McKiernan, that the best legal advice keeps people out of their day in court.

subdebateinfo.title: Office of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I draw the minister's attention to a report today that the ATSIC board has passed a resolution calling for the winding up of the Office of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations. Is it a fact that the Office of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations is most important to overseeing expenditure of taxpayers' money in indigenous affairs? What is the government's re sponse to this threat to public accountability of funding through ATSIC?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I am aware that the board of ATSIC did pass a resolution calling for the registrar's office to be absorbed into the Office of Evaluation and Audit and calling for the termination of the registrar. I can assure the Senate that the Office of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations has my full confidence and, if any changes are to be made, they will be to further strengthen the office. The office does an outstanding job of ensuring proper accountability in indigenous affairs. I find it peculiar in the extreme that the ATSIC board would pass a motion calling for the winding-up of the office, particularly in light of the poor accountability record in indigenous affairs.

answer.para: We inherited that appalling record from Labor when we came to office, and we have taken strong steps to address it. I remind senators that this government put a special auditor into ATSIC when we first came to office, and I remind senators and ATSIC commissioners of what the special auditor found. The special auditor expressed serious reservations about 292 of the 1,200 ATSIC-funded organisations examined. In their last year of funding, these organisations received a total of $172.4 million and, with the help of the office of the registrar and the Office of Evaluation and Audit, we have taken concrete steps to clean up the problems of accountability that we inherited.

Over the past 2½ years, 56 matters involving indigenous funding have been referred to the Federal Police and eight to the state police. It has been important to do that to ensure maximum outcomes from expenditure in indigenous affairs. The poor accountability that existed under Labor not only cheated taxpayers but also cheated indigenous Australians, and I can assure ATSIC commissioners, indigenous Australians and all taxpayers—indigenous and non-indigenous—that this government will not be abolishing the Office of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations.

I also note that the same report includes objections by ATSIC commissioner Sugar Ray Robinson to the appointment of administrators to organisations that he controls. According to advice I have received, an audit of one of the organisations in question, the Goolburri Land Council, has revealed serious discrepancies. I am also advised that traditional elders in the area have signed a petition calling for the appointment of an administrator to the Goolburri Land Council and that staff were dismissed after they expressed concern that traditional owners were not being given proper recognition. Under those circumstances I believe the registrar would have failed in his duties if he did not appoint an administrator to the Goolburri Land Council.

The article also refers to attempts by the registrar to open the books of the National Aboriginal and Islanders Legal Service, NAILS, of which commissioner Robinson is chairman. I am advised that there have also been serious complaints relating to NAILS and I would pose the question: if NAILS has nothing to hide, why refuse to allow the registrar to look at the books?

I repeat that this government is committed to accountability, something Labor failed to do during its 13 years in office. Labor's failure was not only to taxpayers, but also to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders, who should have received better outcomes from that expenditure. I make no apologies for our determination to ensure proper accountability. I repeat that I have full confidence in the office of the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations.

I would recommend to the opposition that they take that into account whenever any questions are asked about these matters, as was done in the last two weeks. When the question was asked at that time, I said that I would bring further matters to the Senate to explain the implications of the question that was asked by the opposition two weeks ago. When further matters arise I will be happy to bring them to the Senate as these events unfold.

talk.start.para: —Minister, given the statement you have just made on the Goolburri Land Council and given ATSIC's view that they would like to shut down the Registrar of Aboriginal Corporations, does not this highlight once again the great commitment that and you and our government have to getting it right in the expenditure of money on ATSIC and our commitment to fair play and a fair go for ordinary Aboriginal people?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Heffernan for the supplementary question. I am sure everybody in the Senate believes that at all times the funds that go to Aboriginal affairs should go to the needy and not the greedy. That is the criterion that we have established in this portfolio. I know that the overwhelming number of Aboriginal people of this country and the Torres Strait Islanders support that contention. So at all times we will ensure that the very necessary funding that needs to go into Aboriginal health, housing, education and employment goes to the people who need it. We have an enormous backlog that must be taken up. We will do so in the shortest period of time available so that we can reach standards that are equal to those of the rest of Australians, which Aboriginal people expect to have.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .
—On 28 May I gave an answer to Senator McKiernan in relation to Jobs Network in Western Australia. There is a slight amendment which I table and which I seek leave to incorporate.

speech.para: Leave granted.

I refer to Senator McKiernan's question without notice on 28 May 1998 which related to employment assistance with Jobs Network in Western Australia. During the course of my answer, I referred to an interjection by Senator Evans in relation to these services as they applied to Karratha. I stated that there had not been any tenders received from Karratha.

I have since been advised that there were no successful tenders for the provision of Flex 1, 2 and 3 services in Karratha. There was however a successful tender from the WA Chamber of Commerce for a New Apprenticeship Centre in Karratha.
My answer however with respect to Karratha involving a fee for service arrangement remains correct.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Kemp) and the Minister for Schools, Vocational Education and Training (Senator Ellison) to questions without notice asked by Senators Bishop, Conroy, Jacinta Collins and McKiernan today, relating to a goods and services tax.

Senators will know that during the lead-up to the last election some famous words escaped the lips of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard). They are captured on television for the world to see. In regard to the question of a GST: `I will never ever introduce a GST.' We have now $36 million of Australian taxpayers' money being set aside in the current budget to prepare the Australian people for the introduction of a GST. The Prime Minister said, `Never ever'. The budget says $36 million of Australian taxpayers' money, $10 million of which is to run a television campaign to sell the GST to a reluctant Australian electorate.

When this government talks about tax reform, it means a GST. `Tax reform' is the nice language they use to coat the bitter pill of a goods and services tax in this country. In question time today, when posed several questions about what they mean, what they intend and when they will introduce such a formula, they ran scared.

It is appropriate, therefore, for the opposition to canvass some of the myths that the government has given birth to about a GST. One of the biggest myths is that those who avoid tax in Australia will be caught under a GST, that is to say, the black economy in Australia will be wiped out. We know the evidence. Of all of the 26 countries in the OECD, Australia's black economy is amongst the smallest. What is the distinguishing feature of the countries with large black economies? The distinguishing feature is that all of them have a GST. It does not follow that when you introduce a GST you wipe out wholesale tax avoidance in the black economy. In fact, tax avoiders who are able to save money and find smarter ways of avoiding tax have a way of doing so even with a GST regime. So put a cross against the idea that you overcome tax avoidance. In any case, we know that this government will not overcome the tax avoidance engaged in by Senator Parer because it will not introduce a law on trusts to do so.

What is the second big myth about a GST? The second big myth is that it will cut the costs of imports to exports and our export industry will be able to earn more dollars overseas. That is also a myth because we know that the exchange rate changes to correct the competitive advantage. The competitive advantage is nil. The competitive advantage to exporters becomes nil because of a variable floating exchange rate. We know that is to be a fact. So will there be more jobs under a GST? No, there will not be any more jobs under a GST. Why do we not go back to what Labor did when we supported manufacturing industry in this country? Manufacturing exports during the decade of Labor government grew by 15.7 per cent. What are they growing at now?—about three per cent. Who got it right on creating jobs through exports? We did. Who wants to get it wrong? You do. So let us cross off the list the idea that the GST will somehow improve Australia's competitive position.

Let us go to the other great myth about a GST. The government says they will introduce it and it will remain fixed—it will not increase. We know all about that one. Of the 23 countries in the OECD with a GST, 21 of them have increased it after it was introduced. We know that John Hewson, a former Liberal leader, shone the light of truth upon you lot when he said, `Unless the GST is at 15 per cent, no-one will believe it, and if it is at 15 per cent, that is the level it should be at. Anything less is not enough.' A former Liberal leader exposed the current Liberal government. Who believes the myth from John Howard—the man who said, `Never ever will I do this'—when he says, `But I won't increase it when I do'? So that is another myth.

Who wants a GST? The big end of town—the business community. They will pay the same tax as we will and as ordinary income earners in this country will. The rich pay the same tax as the middle and low income earners in this country. They say that is fair. Of course, it is fair for them, but it is not fair for the ordinary Australian because the ordinary Australian pays more out of their wage packet for housing, food and clothing than do wealthy Australians. They will all be taxed at the same level by a GST on the costs of food, clothing and housing. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on this subject as well because I think that we are about to see one of the most scurrilous campaigns launched yet again from people on the other side who so wrongly assumed office in 1993 on the basis that they said that they would introduce tax cuts to Australian people. They said that they would not just promise tax cuts; they would put them into law. What happened? The moment they were elected, they rescinded the l-a-w tax cuts.

speech.para: Prior to that election, they also promised that they would not increase taxes. What happened? They increased taxes. The 10 per cent rate went to 12 per cent, the 20 per cent rate went to 22 per cent and the 30 per cent rate went to 32 per cent—and on the list goes. Not only that, they increased a whole range of wholesale sales taxes. They increased the petrol excise, they increased the Medicare levy, they increased company tax, they increased fringe benefits tax and they increased departure tax. And here is a mob that is trying to be credible on tax!
Where in the world is the Labor tax policy? They have been in opposition for 2½ years. They have not released one single solitary policy.

talk.start.para: —What's yours?

—The government has brought down three budgets. You should be able to gather what is in the tax policy through three budgets. I feel sorry for people like Senator Jacinta Collins. She is so far out of left field, she does not understand anything to do with tax. The question that Senator Collins asked today just highlighted her gross and utter ignorance in the whole area of tax.

speech.para: Then you get other questions about exempt rates. They do not have a clue about exempt rates—the difference between exempt and zero rating. They do not have a clue about the way in which the whole system flows on. They do not have a clue about the way in which the whole system works. Yet the worst part about all of this is that the Labor Party are talking, supposedly, about someone else's policy that they have not seen. Why do they keep coming in here talking about a policy that they have not seen, much less understanding the principle behind it?

The only principle of tax that the Labor Party has ever understood is how to increase it. That is the basis on which they ran this country for 13 years. People only need to be reminded of their record. Their track record is crystal clear.

talk.start.para: —You should join One Nation.
—Unfortunately, nit-wits like Senator Collins were not here then.
—Order!
—Sorry, I withdraw that. People who lack total understanding of the tax system like Senator Collins—
—How would you know?
—Because I have had to listen to you, you dill. That is why.
—Senator Knowles, please withdraw that comment.

—If you want me to withdraw `dill', I withdraw `dill'. I am simply saying that people like Senator Collins should never be allowed to be let loose on this subject. The way in which the Labor Party are manipulating this whole story yet again is just a disgrace. These questions have been asked today from a wrong foundation. I thought Senator Bishop had more intelligence and more capability in this area, and yet the question that he asked of Senator Ellison was just breathtakingly silly.
—I asked Senator Kemp.

—Senator Kemp or whoever it was. It was just breathtakingly silly. It did not make sense. The problem is that we have now got this Labor Party yet again running a fear campaign based on total and utter misinformation. There is no respect for the truth. There never has been a respect for the truth in the way in which the Labor Party run this campaign. We saw it chapter and verse in 1993, and here we are seeing it again in 1998. I hope that the people of Australia will not be bluffed by a party that has not released one single solitary policy in 2½ years and has not given one hint of what their tax policy is going to be other than to do everything they did in 13 years in government.
—The GST is unfair and inequitable, and the Liberals want to pretend that it is not. That is what this debate is about.

speech.para: The Liberals claim the GST will increase jobs. It does not. There is not any country anywhere in the world where you can show that the introduction of a GST has led to more jobs. The Liberals want you to believe that the GST is going to end the black economy. Again, there is not one single country in the world that you can point to where this has been the outcome. In fact, Canada, which is the most recent country to have introduced this, has actually had a massive increase in its black economy. The Liberals want you to believe that the GST will fix national savings. Again, there is not one country in the world that you can go to where it can be demonstrated that there has been an increase in national savings because of the introduction of a GST. They are the three big claims.

It is particularly cruel of this government to walk around pretending that a GST is going to create jobs. The workers got sacked by Stan Wallis of Amcor last week in Burnie, Senator Watson—and you should be particularly concerned about this being a Tasmanian.

talk.start.para: —You know I am.

—Stan Wallis wants everybody to pay a GST: 10 per cent on food, 10 per cent on bread and 10 per cent on milk. He sacked those workers and he wants to run an advertising campaign in this country saying that the GST will get your job back, that the GST will create jobs for you. There is not one worker in Burnie who just lost their job who believes him.

speech.para: Business is about shifting the tax burden from themselves to the families and households. Stan Wallis, President of the Business Council of Australia, said on 27 May 1998:
The GST holds out the prospect of significant reductions in the indirect tax burden currently borne by business.

Where do you think that tax burden is going to go if it is not going to be borne by business? It is going to households. Ordinary Australians are going to be paying for their bread and their milk, they are going to be paying on education, and they are going to be paying on clothes and shoes.

talk.start.para: —You're in for a big surprise. What about the tax cuts?

—They are putting a hand in one pocket and they ae going to try to distract everybody with big, glossy advertising campaigns. They are going to dangle these tax cuts around, and they are going to be giving with one hand and taking back with the other. They are going to have their hand in your pocket every time you go down to the shop or to the footy or to the cinema or to McDonald's. They are all going up, and you have been putting them up.

speech.para: The real test here, as I said at the beginning, is whether this is going to be fair and equitable. There is one test in this country that we can easily apply to determine whether this package is going to be fair and equitable: is Senator Warwick Parer going to pay one cent extra in tax after this package is up?

talk.start.para: —The Parer test!

—The Parer test is what we will be calling it, after the man who avoids all his income tax by setting up a family trust. He does not pay income tax; he avoids income tax by distributing his income, passing it around in his family trust. Are you going to tax family trusts? Are the 18 of you over on that side who avoid your income tax obligations by putting your income into trusts going to be worse off? Are you going to be paying more tax once this package sees the light of day? There will not be much time for people to examine it, but that will be the key test. Is Warwick Parer going to pay more tax after the tax reforms that you claim are fair are implemented? I am willing to bet he is not.

speech.para: The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) told this country that `never ever' would he introduce a GST, then he tried to tell you that he is never ever going to put the rate up. I have a bridge in Sydney I want to sell to anyone who believes that. That is what John Hewson blew the whistle on. John Hewson stood up and said, `You have to put a GST up around 15 per cent because, if you do not, it will always go up.' That is what everybody knows. You can stand there and try to pretend that `never ever' is only three years. You can pretend that all you want, but ordinary Australians are not going to be fooled. No glossy advertising campaign about hidden taxes is going to wash when they know the rate is going to go up, because you cannot promise or guarantee that it will not. If you put it in your budget, if you make it a revenue bill, this opposition has always said we will pass the budget bills. That is how you will do it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —We all know that the Australian tax system is unfair. It distorts the decisions of business and consumers, it is complicated and, above all, it needs reform. This Liberal government has the guts to provide that mechanism for reform. We will see that result shortly.

speech.para: Unfortunately, we now have a system where there are six different wholesale tax rates which are applied to the wholesale price of goods but, of course, not to services. We now have a system where there are taxes on taxes. I need not remind the Senate that our tax system was designed for the 1930s and is outdated. It is dominated by a manufacturing sector, targeted at domestic consumption. Times have changed but our tax system has not.

The Labor Party, when they were in power, just imposed increases on an archaic system. What we propose is a complete reform of the tax system. What we propose is that, after Senator Conroy returns from the football or has spent his money on these sorts of activities, he will still have more money in his pocket because, as part of this tax reform, there will be significant income tax cuts that are going to be directed to those people—the middle income earners—who suffered too much under the Labor Party administration. These are the people who will be better off whether there is an indirect tax or not.

Those tax cuts are going to come from the accumulated surplus, from all the bracket creeps that you dishonestly, in 13 years of government, took away from ordinary workers. We will restore equity to the blue-collar workers' pay packet and to the battlers of Australia. At the end of the day, the middle income workers will have more money for discretionary spending and more money to put away as savings for their retirement, because more than 2.4 million workers face being stranded on the top tax rate unless the system is radically overhauled. We intend to radically overhaul that system to provide the tax cuts from the accumulated surplus of bracket creep and so on, but not from a GST or any sort of tax that could be introduced.

Let us look at the situation. By the year 2000, 36 per cent of taxpayers will be faced with a tax rate greater than 40 per cent. What hope, in such an environment, have the ordinary workers got? Each year, more and more Australians are being forced into paying higher tax rates, including more and more people moving into the top marginal rates.

A lot has been said about the GST. In Australia we have taxes cascading on taxes. The result is that if you compare two economies alone—ours and New Zealand's—with this cascading of tax and no zero rating on exports, we have a situation that, given two identical firms with equal efficiencies—one in Australia and one in New Zealand—in terms of export prices Australia's prices are up here and New Zealand's prices are well below it. What hope have Australian exporters in competing with a country such as New Zealand, which has such a GST. What chance have exporters?

What would be the result if Australia were to move to such a system? We would be competing on equal terms rather than being outpriced continuously. What does this mean? This means extra return to the exporters, extra jobs, higher prices for primary producers and higher prices for those who work in the industries. I put it to you: the only way that Australia is going to take a higher share of export trade is to improve our competitive system, and part of that reform is reviewing the tax situation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —After that performance, I would like to congratulate Senator Watson for at least an attempt to deal with some of the issues of substance in this debate about taxation, although I would have to say his contribution has been somewhat incredible, given his interpretation of the benefits of what the government is proposing to put forward. We still do not have significant light shed on precisely what tax reform means to this government.

speech.para: In my contribution to this debate, I would like to take a step back, partly in response to Senator Knowles's contribution, to the Fightback package because it seems that she has forgotten some of the issues that were dealt with during that period. If we reflect on the debate as it occurred some years ago, we see this government is overreacting to Fightback. Many commentators have suggested that the government learnt its lesson on Fightback in that it allowed far too much time for the public and the community to become aware of the implications of a GST, so this time they are holding back so that we will not be able to demonstrate the deficits in the government's tax reform package.

I think anyone observing the events as they stand now would support the proposition that the government is holding back on giving any decent amount of information, particularly after its performance in question time today. The overreaction is that they are being far too defensive and, judging by what Senator Vanstone pointed out today, far too dishonest. She highlighted the contribution of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) to the debate. Many of us in this debate have referred to the `never ever statement'. What I would like to highlight in my contribution is more than just the `never ever statement' but how incredible was the Prime Minister's claim that that was really in the context of never ever in this term.

If you look at the statements that he has made, you will see even that explanation does not hold up. Our Prime Minister's comments on this issue simply do not hold up. John Howard said in a media conference in the Tweed Heads civic centre on 2 May 1995:
. . . there's no way that a GST will ever be part of our policy.
The reporter said, `Never ever?' John Howard said:
Never ever. It's dead. It was killed by the voters in the last election.
In a media release on 2 May 1995, John Howard said:
A GST or anything resembling it is no longer Coalition policy. Nor will it be policy at any time in the future. It is completely off the political agenda. . .

Those comments do not stand up in the light of the Prime Minister's explanation that he really meant in the current term. They just do not stand up. He said, `Never ever.' He said it was no longer part of coalition policy, nor would it ever be in the future.

So how can Senator Knowles stand up today and say credibly, `You don't understand tax—you don't understand what we really mean,' when the Prime Minister says one thing one minute and something completely different the next? We know what you mean. What you mean is: business wants to pay less tax and we are a government which will shift it onto consumers. Who are those consumers? Those consumers are the battlers that John Howard convinced, to get elected, that he was going to make feel relaxed and comfortable. They are not relaxed and comfortable and they do not believe, and will not believe, that this government is about fair tax reform.

Fair tax reform is not a GST. Tax reform is broader than a GST. Because the Labor Party says we do not support a GST because it is unfair, that does not mean that the Labor Party opposes tax reform. Tax reform is much broader than a GST. The Labor Party has participated in tax reform over history since the 1930s, as Senator Sherry pointed out. Our system is not inevitably changing towards a GST. As pointed out in the media recently, the United States do not have a GST.

talk.start.para: —They have something pretty close to it.

—No, they have nothing close to a GST. Senator Watson, you do not understand tax if you think the US system is close to a GST. It is a retail tax, actually more similar to a wholesale tax. It is just applied at a different level. It is not a value added tax. Unless you understand that, you do not understand the tax debate. The retail tax applied in the United States is far more similar to the wholesale sales tax that we have in place here. (Time expired)
—Nothing exemplifies more the fact that Jacinta Collins—
—Senator, please!

—Senator Jacinta Collins is out of touch completely on this issue than her response to Senator Watson that he knows nothing about tax. No-one in this Senate would know more about tax issues than Senator Watson. That is the sort of nonsense we get from the Labor opposition.

speech.para: The opposition have also clearly confirmed again today in this debate that they are wreckers and not builders, that they are yet again embarking on a dishonest scare campaign against the urgent need for tax reform, and that is what every Australian needs to know. Australians know only too well the ramshackle nature of the tax system that we currently have in place and the urgent need for tax reform and that it is the Labor Party that is going to try to wreck this attempt at tax reform.

It is no wonder they want to do that. In stark contrast to Senator Watson's deep knowledge of taxation issues, the only thing the Labor Party know about tax is the way in which they can raise more tax. That is the only interest of the Labor Party. It was their only interest when they were in government. They were a tax and spend government. They spent the whole 13 years in office seeking ways to raise more and more tax to feed their rapacious levels of government spending.

talk.start.para: —Who were the sufferers?

—The sufferers were the average Australians. The average wage earners in this country were the sufferers under Labor. Not only did Labor increase a range of taxes but they also devised means of bringing forward tax revenue. Every year they sought to devise ways of bringing forward tax revenue that otherwise may have been collected further down the track, because they had this continual rapacious need to feed their spending habit.

speech.para: The most dishonest example of their increase in taxes was after the 1993 election. Having campaigned, as I said, in a false way against the coalition's proposals then for tax reform, they immediately, in that budget after the 1993 election, substantially increased wholesale sales tax. But that was not the only tax they increased during their term in office. They increased petrol excise to an enormous rate. When the last Liberal-National government left office, almost all of the money raised from fuel taxes was spent on roads. By the time Labor left office, a very small percentage was spent on roads. Something like 10 or 15 per cent of the fuel excise was spent on roads when Labor left office compared with nearly all of it when they came to office.

They increased the Medicare levy. They increased company tax. They introduced and increased fringe benefits taxes. And they increased the departure tax. In contrast to that, they failed completely to deliver their promised tax cuts—the l-a-w tax cuts. Remember those? They were promised by then Prime Minister Keating in the 1993 election—they were actually written into legislation. They came back after the 1993 election and repealed that legislation and reneged on those tax cuts. They had 13 years in office to provide a fairer tax system. All they ever did was increase revenue and spending.

What have we heard today from the opposition? We have heard reference to trusts. The Labor Party do not care about trusts. Trusts have been around for many years. They were certainly around during their 13 years in office and they did absolutely nothing about the issue of trusts. They only raise trusts now because of their vitriolic personal attack on Senator Parer. They are using trusts as a battering ram for their personal attack on Senator Parer and for nothing else. This government, while recognising that trusts do have a legitimate role as a business structure, has nevertheless acted to make illegal the inappropriate use of trusts. It is this government that has legislated to remove the capacity to trade in trust losses. It is this government that is introducing legislation to remove the capacity for dividend streaming. It is this government that has recognised that, where there are difficulties in regard to trusts, legislation is needed and it has introduced that.

What are the Labor Party going to do with trusts? They are going to legislate on trusts to introduce de facto death duties. Mr Beazley has announced that the next Labor government in office will legislate so that every time control of a trust changes it will be regarded as a disposal of assets and hence a capital gains tax will apply.

talk.start.para: —No, no, no.
—`No, no, no,' says Senator Cook. That is exactly what Mr Beazley has said. (Time expired) .
—The time allocated for this debate has expired.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —Before calling the clerk for petitions, I must say that I had great difficulty hearing Senator Chapman because of quite a lot of conversation from the advisers' boxes.
—You missed great pearls of wisdom.
—That is why I was disappointed, Senator Chapman. I recognise that it is necessary for advice to be given, but please be aware of how the noise travels.
—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.

The petition of certain citizens draws the attention of the Senate to the damaging impact of the Government's changes to post-secondary education. Upfront undergraduate fees; increased HECS fees and charges; cuts to student places; cuts to Austudy and Abstudy and decreased Commonwealth funding for universities are denying students fair access to university education. Your petitioners therefore ask the Senate to return post-secondary education to a system which is fair and accessible for Australians.

talk.start.para: Senator Calvert(from 80 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.

The Petition of the undersigned shows: That Australian citizens oppose social, legal and economic discrimination against people on the basis of their sexuality or transgender identity and that such discrimination is unacceptable in a democratic society.

Your petitioners request that the Senate should: pass the Australian Democrats Bill to make it unlawful to discriminate or vilify on the basis of sexuality or transgender identity so that such discrimination or vilification be open to redress at a national level.

talk.start.para: Senator Bartlett(from 53 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The Petition of the undersigned draws to the attention of the Senate, the deleterious effects of the Multilateral Agreement on Investment.
Your petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. Make available the draft text of the Agreement.
2. Make a public statement about its intentions with regard to the signing of the MAI, detailing the beneficiaries of the Agreement, and accountability measures for all corporations.
3. Not sign the MAI unless substantive amendment is made, including the observance of international agreements including environment, labour, health and safety and human rights standards.
4. Extend the deadline for signing the MAI to enable full and proper public consultations to be held.

talk.start.para: Senator Bourne(from 251 citizens)

petition.para: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate assembled in Parliament.
This petition of certain citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the House support of the undersigned for the establishment of radiotherapy services at Wagga Wagga and Albury/Wodonga.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the House will commend the establishment of radiotherapy services at Wagga Wagga and Albury/Wodonga to treat cancer patients residing in the southwest region of New South Wales and north eastern Victoria.
The House is advised that the Minister for Health, Dr Andrew Refshauge, MP has given `in principle' support to the proposed country-located "sister" clinics at Wagga Wagga and Albury/Wodonga.

We, therefore, respectfully request the House to call on the Federal Minister for Health, Dr Michael Wooldridge MP, to urgently approve the provision of these vital radiotherapy services for country cancer patients who are now disadvantaged by being forced to attend metropolitan based services for long periods of treatment.

talk.start.para: Senator Calvert(from 1,811 citizens)
—I give notice that, on 30 June 1998, I shall move:

speech.para: That the provisions of paragraphs (5) to (7) of standing order 111 not apply to the Wheat Marketing Legislation Amendment Bill 1998, allowing it to be considered during this period of sittings.
I indicate to the Senate that the statement of reasons justifying the need for this bill to be considered during these sittings has previously been tabled and incorporated in Hansard .

talk.start.para: —On behalf of Senator O'Chee and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, and pursuant to notice given on the last day of sitting, I withdraw business of the Senate notices of motion Nos 1 and 2 standing in Senator O'Chee's name for today for the disallowance of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission Rules 1998, as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 1 and the Health Insurance Commission Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1997 No. 332.
—At the request of Senator O'Chee, I give notice that, 15 sitting days after today, he will move:

speech.para: That the Migration Agents Regulations 1998, as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 53 and made under the Migration Act 1958 , be disallowed.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short summary of the matters raised by the committee.
Leave granted.
The summary read as follows—

The regulations provide for the registration of migration agents. The committee has a number of concerns with these regulations including unclear provisions; possible restrictive qualifications; wide discretion with no parliamentary oversight; sanctions with no indication whether they are subject to independent review; no apparent safeguard for the requirement to provide records; and no provision for a client's money to be kept in a trust account. The committee has written to the minister for advice.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, Senator Brown and I will move:

speech.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:

(i) the meeting of the World Heritage Bureau held in Paris on 23 June 1998 expressed alarm at the threats to the cultural and natural world heritage values of the Kakadu World Heritage site from the proposed Jabiluka uranium mine,

(ii) the bureau has decided to send a high-powered inspection team, which includes the Chairman of the World Heritage Committee, to investigate and report by December 1998 on the threats posed to the Kakadu World Heritage area, and
(iii) the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) has indicated that he is not concerned by this criticism;
(b) acknowledges the concerns expressed by the bureau; and

(c) calls on the Australian Government to immediately halt any construction activity at the site of the proposed Jabiluka mine and to take no further action until the bureau has completed its report and considered the matter at its next meeting in Kyoto in December 1998.

talk.start.para: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

speech.para: That the Senate—
(a) notes that:
(i) Visy Industries Pty Ltd is establishing a new pulp mill in New South Wales which will process plantation timber rather than virgin native timber,
(ii) the mill will recycle water, reduce chemical use and will not use chlorine in its operations,
(iii) this value-adding operation stands in stark contrast to the $400 million worth of unprocessed woodchips that Australia exports annually, and
(iv) companies such as Kimberley-Clark manufacture so-called recycled paper that actually includes content from virgin native forests and pre-consumer waste;

(b) congratulates Visy Industries Pty Ltd for persisting with efforts to produce genuine recycled paper in light of the Coalition's actions which have discouraged its production and consumption, for example, by rescinding the sales tax exemption for recycled paper; and

talk.start.para: —I seek leave to amend the motion and to speak briefly to the amendment.

speech.para: Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Omit all words after "That" insert: "the following matters be referred to the Joint Standing Committee on Public Accounts and Audit for inquiry and report by the last sitting day in December 1998:
(a) the equitable treatment of taxpayers by the Australian Taxation Office;
(b) the development of tax planning arrangements since 1985 and the adequacy of legislative and administrative responses since that time to tax planning techniques;

(c) the adequacy of Australia's existing taxation laws to deal with increasing sophistication in tax planning arrangements, first identified in reports to the previous government, including the 1985 Tax Reform White Paper and the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration Report, March 1991, Follow the Yellow Brick Road ; and
(d) the capacity of the Australian Taxation Office to ensure compliance of taxpayers under continued ad hoc changes to the tax system, compared to a program of fundamental reform to tax arrangements.

The amendment I have moved is currently being circulated in the chamber. Essentially the amendment refers the inquiry to the proper place—the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts and Audit—rather than the proposal that we have before us in this chamber.

If there is a serious desire to have an inquiry, that is the body which has the expertise, that is the body which has the standing, and that is the body which has already carried out a number of inquiries into issues related to the tax office. I would hope that the Senate would support that proposal by the government.

Let me make it clear that we do not see a need for this inquiry and we will oppose the motion moved by Senator Cook. On the other hand, we recognise—and this has been confirmed in my discussions with non-government senators—that there is a disposition to have an inquiry. If that is the case, then I believe that the amendment I have moved will deal with the issues that Senator Cook has raised and a number of other issues, but it will deal with them in a more expeditious fashion.

I had a feeling when I first saw this proposal that it was a political stunt. My views on this were confirmed when a journalist told me that the Labor Party is briefing the gallery to say that this will have the effect of drawing resources away—they said—from tax reform. It looks like a political stunt; it sort of smells like a political stunt. The evidence seems to be mounting already that it is a political stunt, particularly if the information that I have received is correct. Therefore, I can only draw the conclusion that this is precisely what it is. Therefore, it is not a serious inquiry to deal with serious issues. If it is a serious inquiry to deal with serious issues, the one place that it should go to is the Joint Standing Committee of Public Accounts and Audit.

The fact of the matter is that the ATO is already subject to substantial parliamentary and other external scrutiny. The tax office receives really quite extensive—almost immense—scrutiny from a very wide variety of bodies and range of forums. Senator Cook as a former minister with an interest in finance and tax matters should already know this. The tax office annual report has a whole chapter on the scrutiny of the ATO.

The ways in which the tax office is subject to scrutiny include the review by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit and the ATO reports quarterly to the JCPAA on the status of the implementation of the recommendations of the JCPAA's reports. An assessment of tax followed the committee's major inquiry into the operations of the tax office in 1993. There are various other committees which review the tax office and, of course, in particular the tax office is reviewed by the Senate estimates committee.

I might say it came as a great surprise to me when we had Mr Carmody and his officers recently before the Senate estimates committee that so comparatively little time was spent by the Labor Party asking questions in the tax area and following up on some of the issues which Senator Cook is obviously concerned about. It surprised me, because I would have thought it was an important priority for the Labor Party and it followed some media coverage of a variety of issues. There was very little interest from the Labor Party on this matter.

The Australian National Audit Office has conducted a number of reviews of various aspects of the tax office in recent years, including the ATO's tax debt collection processes, sales tax administration, client services provided to the public by individuals in the non-business line and the ATO's approach to client service and its risk management practices. These have all been covered, discussed and debated.

The tax office does not lack scrutiny. It is extensively scrutinised. If there is a disposition by the Senate to have an inquiry, let us make sure we do the inquiry properly. Let us put it to the body that has the expertise to deal with it. It sounds and looks like a political stunt, and if the information I have already received from the press gallery is correct, there is evidence of a political stunt. It seems to me that the Senate would be in a better position to make sure that this was done in a serious way by referring these issues to the relevant committee, which is the joint standing committee that I have referred to.

If the Senate believes there is a case for an inquiry, this is the vehicle that should carry out the inquiry. The JCPAA is unquestionably the most appropriate committee of the parliament for an inquiry of this type. I urge the Senate to accept the amendment to the proposal put by Senator Cook.

talk.start.para: —by leave—Two things have happened in the amendment. Firstly, the government have chosen to refer this matter to a joint parliamentary committee, a committee of the House of Representatives and the Senate, and to take it away from the Senate, which was my original motion. Secondly, they have changed the terms of reference. Our terms of reference are set out in the Senate notes.

speech.para: I have not seen the terms of reference before that the government has just now submitted, but in the few minutes available to me I have cast my eyes over them. Some of the things require a bit further study than what I can undertake at the moment. One of the notable exceptions that is not included in the government's terms of reference but which is included in the notice that I gave to the Senate yesterday is that I had a second clause which said that witnesses coming before the Senate inquiry would have extended to them parliamentary privilege in order to give evidence, so that they can give evidence freely without attack. I do not know what the government's position on that matter is. It is not clear from the terms of reference they have circulated. I regard that as being important.

Since knowledge of this move came to light, my office has been contacted and people have said that they would be willing under oath—but under parliamentary privilege—to give evidence, which they would not be prepared to do if parliamentary privilege did not extend to them. In terms of a public inquiry into a matter so fundamental as tax, anyone who has a viewpoint—particularly those who fear injury if they express it publicly—should be able to come to a parliamentary committee and be protected when they give their true information and opinions to that committee. I draw that defect in the government's position to the attention of the Senate.

The other point is that the minister has said in moving his amendment that we in the Labor Party were not very interested during the Senate estimates process of exercising scrutiny of the tax office and that this is the reason now why presumably we should be refused the opportunity to take the scrutiny of the tax office to the full blown level of a Senate inquiry. I do not understand that argument in logic. We did, of course, spend a fair amount of time inquiring of the tax office during the estimates procedure. In fact, the amount of time we spent caused us to believe that an inquiry such as this was necessary.

The third point that has been made by the minister is that this is a political stunt. Can I take a moment of the Senate to address that allegation? The government have said that tax reform is on the agenda. They have announced that in lights. They have written it in the sky. They have told all Australians and they have budgeted in this current budget $10 million of Australian taxpayers' money to `educate'—in their terms—the Australian community, through an advertising campaign, on their version of tax reform. They have put tax issues on the agenda.

If this is a political stunt in asking the tax office—which is the statutory authority that collects tax on behalf of the government—to come before a committee of this Senate for scrutiny at a time when tax is a central debate in the Australian economy, I think the minister ought to go back and re-examine his own motives. One can simply conclude that he makes that allegation against us as a slur and in an attempt to divert attention from the real issue.

What is fundamental to a debate on tax reform in Australia is the role, the significance, the procedures and the actions of the Australian Taxation Office. One of the things that Australians want to know about when it comes to a debate about tax reform is to what extent do wealthy Australians evade tax? How many ordinary Australians have to pay more tax because those who have the means to evade tax through family trust arrangements or whatever get away with it so that the tax take has to be imposed on the back of ordinary Australians at a greater level than is necessary? That is a fundamental question about tax reform. How effective the procedures of the tax office are in tracking down and bringing tax cheats to book is an important matter in this debate. That is not a stunt. That is a matter of sober national significance.

I now turn to the next argument raised by the minister: that is, there are a number of other bodies that scrutinise the tax office and, therefore, there is no reason for the Senate to do so. There are a number of bodies that scrutinise the tax office, but I think the Senate's interest is an important interest in looking at issues that, from a political point of view, from a legislative point of view and from a Senate point of view, ought to be examined by this chamber and not left to other bodies to do. To ask this chamber to forgo its rights and to delegate them to a joint committee is unfair.

The important distinction about a joint committee that one must remember is that, if as the pundits widely predict, after the end of next week's sitting the Prime Minister announces his tax package and then in the week after calls a federal election, the joint parliamentary committee goes out of existence automatically. That ends the inquiry. It ceases to exist. The other thing to remember is that a joint parliamentary committee would give the government control over the election of a chairman, the terms of reference of that committee and the timing of meetings of that committee. The third thing to remember about a joint parliamentary committee is that only those senators nominated by this chamber—and there is a limited number of them—can sit on the joint parliamentary committee. Yet as far as the Senate economics committee, which is the obvious vehicle to conduct this inquiry, is concerned those senators who are participating members—and there is a large number of them—can be engaged in this inquiry. To shift it out of this chamber, to put it between both chambers, is to deny this chamber the chance to fully investigate the issues of the Australian Taxation Office.

As I have said, the tax debate is upon us. A key issue in that debate is the role of the tax office. A big question in the tax debate is about tax avoidance. We would like to examine the Australian Taxation Office in terms of its high wealth individuals task force, how much money is being spent, how many of those high wealth individuals pay their full measure of tax, what other steps are necessary to ensure that they are made to pay their full measure. We would like to look at issues such as what leakage there is in tax collections. Do we collect our full measure of tax across the board? Where is the tax system haemorrhaging? What can be done about that? They are matters of inquiry.

It is also important to remember that recently the Channel 9 program Sunday ran a feature item on the tax office and made a number of allegations about the conduct of the tax office. One allegation it made was that there is a mates' rate network which operates at senior levels in the Australian Taxation Office. I do not know if that allegation is true. I hope it is not, but it is an allegation made by a serious independent investigative journalist program, and it deserves some examination in the context of this whole debate. It made other allegations too. I do not propose to go into them now. But there are issues of the high wealth individuals task force, the question of trusts and whether or not trusts are used to minimise the taxation by those wealthy enough to be able to afford high priced lawyers and smart accountants to get out of their full measure of tax which ordinary Australians cannot afford to do.

There is a question of salary repackaging to avoid the full measure of tax being paid and the implications of that in the wider economy and so forth. These are not stunt questions; these are important questions. In the context of the wider debate on taxation in Australia, they are vital questions and they go to the very heart of that debate. Governments can do a number of things to tighten up the tax system, as can the administrators of it. To have the view of the administrators under the scrutiny of a Senate committee is an appropriate decision of this chamber, and I would be very happy to move accordingly. I note that the government has submitted its proposed terms of reference. I am not sure that in every respect those terms of reference are the same. In any case, it would put such an inquiry outside this chamber when it rightfully belongs in it.

talk.start.para: —by leave—This inquiry is well overdue. The issue is about equity. People have been asked to look at new and supposedly more equitable tax systems. It is only fair that they have confidence in the system in place. I believe that the original wording from Senator Cook is far more appropriate than the proposal for the amendment by Senator Kemp. Therefore, I signal that I will be prepared to support the original proposed inquiry by Senator Cook and not the amendment by Senator Kemp.

—by leave—I am a member of both the JCPAA and the economics committee, so I talk with reference to both those committees. I am also the Democrats finance and taxation spokesperson, so these are issues that matter to me. I did view both the programs on Channel 9 which I gather have prompted this inquiry. My view is that the ATO is bound to include some sinners and will not be composed of saints, but I doubt that as an organisation it is any more or less a body of integrity than any other government department.

speech.para: What concerns me is that the nature of a media documentary such as that does not enable the department itself to respond fully and in detail to the allegations made and to illustrate in full its procedures and how it deals with matters. Accordingly, the Australian Democrats do not prejudge the issue at hand but believe that the public's confidence in the integrity of the ATO has been sufficiently damaged by those allegations to warrant an inquiry which should be speedily wrapped up and would give all the relevant parties the opportunity to respond appropriately, both those making the complaints and those defending themselves.

I then have to move to the question of the committee at hand. It is my opinion, as I have so advised both the government and the Labor Party, that the JCPAA is the better committee on a number of grounds; namely, that it has continuity in terms of its audit process and its understanding of the issues—and I have checked with the JCPAA as to its ongoing oversight in this area. Secondly, it has the experience.

There is, however, both a virtue and a weakness in the JCPAA. The virtue is that it tries to arrive at a common position. Minority reports are unknown. That gives it great weight and authority because it speaks with one voice. But I suspect that on this issue minorities may well be a possibility and that, therefore, the JCPAA would be a difficult forum.

However, I did advise both the government and the Labor Party that it is my view that, if it is the Labor Party's motion, that party is entitled to nominate any committee of its choosing. What is more, the committee of its choosing is a Senate committee of considerable reputation. Therefore, on behalf of my party, I would not oppose that committee, even though I indicate to the Senate my belief that the JCPAA would be the better committee.

The third issue is that of timing. My view is that, in view of the seriousness of the allegations which have been made concerning the ATO, it would be desirable to have as early a reporting date as possible to be found, and that is not for me to dictate to the Labor Party, the government or the Senate. If indeed other matters were to arise out of the inquiry, it would be preferable for a further inquiry to be held after that event. But I think an immediate and early response to the serious allegations should be made.

To some extent I think that puts to rest the government's fears that this is a stunt. I do not regard it as a stunt because the issues were not raised by the Labor Party; they were raised externally in the public interest. Therefore, it is appropriate for the Senate to respond in the manner that the Labor Party have laid out. Accordingly, in these respects, I hope my remarks will assist the Senate in guiding it to a conclusion.
