debateinfo.title: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (LANDCARE AND WATER FACILITY TAX OFFSET) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—

The Taxation Laws Amendment (Landcare and Water Facility Tax Offset) Amendment Bill 1998 contains provisions which give effect to commitments in the Government's election statement, Reviving the Heartland , to "give farmers a choice between accelerated deductions for Landcare works under subdivisions 387-A and 387-B of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (the act) or a tax rebate/credit set at the marginal tax rate of 34 cents in the dollar for qualifying expenditure".

This is a significant initiative as part of the $1.25 billion Natural Heritage Trust to deliver the Government's objective of repairing past land and water degradation and achieving a faster, more effective shift to sustainable agriculture in Australia. Importantly, it provides an incentive for landholders to invest in works which are needed to ensure their future in agriculture and rehabilitate Australia's natural environment.

The Government's policy objective in implementing the landcare and water conserving and conveying facility rebate is to assist low income farmers who, because of their low incomes, are most in need of assistance to invest in landcare works.

Subdivisions 387-A and 387-B of the act contain provisions which allow certain taxpayers to claim income tax deductions for landcare expenditure and for expenditure on conserving and conveying of water respectively. Low income farmers who have a low effective tax rate have a much smaller incentive to invest in such works compared with higher income farmers who are likely to have a higher effective tax rate.

This bill introduces an alternative tax rebate for low income farmers so as to improve their incentive to invest in landcare works. Taxpayers with taxable incomes of up to $20,700 a year will have the alternative of claiming a tax rebate in relation to eligible expenditure incurred from the start of the 1997-98 income year. There is a maximum rebate of $1,700 (based on expenditure of $5,000) for expenditure in a particular year that would otherwise be tax deductible under each of subdivisions 387-A and 387-B. This means the rebate can be claimed for up to $10,000 of eligible expenditure in any year if there is expenditure of $5,000 under each subdivision.

The rebate for landcare expenditure is claimable in full in the year of the expenditure. This matches the treatment of the income tax deduction for such expenditure available under Subdivision 387-A. The rebate for expenditure on facilities for water conservation and conveyance is claimable equally over the three years beginning with the year of the expenditure. This matches the treatment of the income tax deduction for such expenditure available under Subdivision 387-B. In circumstances where taxpayers have chosen to take the rebate but have an insufficient income tax liability with which to absorb it, they will be able to carry forward the unused portion of their rebate.

No taxpayers will be adversely affected by this measure. This proposed rebate provides an incentive for those taxpayers whose low taxable incomes would reduce the benefit of deductions to undertake new landcare and water conserving and conveying works. The economic benefit they can derive from the rebate reducing their tax liability can substantially exceed the benefit of taking income tax deductions at their marginal tax rate.

The Government has set aside funding of $80 million over 4 years for the rebate. This funding will come from the Natural Heritage Trust Fund. There will be no additional compliance costs imposed on those taxpayers who wish to claim the rebate instead of the deductions otherwise available to them. They will simply have to maintain records of expenditure in the same manner as for the deductions.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT (COUNTRY OF ORIGIN REPRESENTATIONS) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Ian Campbell) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: —I table a replacement explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Trade Practices Amendment (Country of Origin Representations) Bill is designed to restore public confidence in country of origin labelling claims.

Persistent public complaints that many labels are misleading or dishonest have given consumers good reason to be sceptical about origin labelling claims. At the same time, recent court decisions have created confusion about the meaning of such commonly used terms as `Made in Australia' and `Product/Produce of Australia'. As a result, the market value of Australian origin claims has been eroded, to the point that producers and manufacturers are wary of making claims and many consumers are losing confidence in labelling altogether.

The fundamental problem is obvious. Consumers want simple, clear and credible labels, based on consistent and reliable standards. Unfortunately, the Trade Practices Act 1974 does not provide such standards, only a general prohibition against false or misleading representations. The result has been shifting legal interpretations and general uncertainty. This legislation will address these problems and at last deliver clarity and confidence to labelling.

The Trade Practices Act will be amended to establish, for the first time, a clear general test for country of origin labelling claims. This test will apply to all representations that goods are `Made in' a particular country. A separate, higher standard will be set for goods carrying the premium `Product/Produce of' label.

To qualify for the `Made in Australia' label, a product will have to be substantially transformed in Australia and at least 50 per cent of the cost of producing or manufacturing the product must have occurred in Australia. The same test will, of course, apply to imported goods.
These will be the minimum standards for goods to carry an unqualified claim of origin.

The use of the substantial transformation test will align Australian law with international practice. Setting the threshold at 50 per cent will ensure that all goods labelled as `Made in Australia' will have the majority of their costs incurred in Australia.

Some people may argue for a higher threshold but this would disadvantage many local industries always considered to be producing Australian products. These firms employ Australians and invest in Australia's future.

Who would tell a person working at General Motors Holden or Ford that the cars they are making are not Australian, just because some of their components are imported ? Our trading partners do not hesitate to recognise these products as Australian; nor should we.

A 50 per cent threshold recognises the integration of Australia into the global economy, and the realities of modern manufacturing. The test compares favourably with the regimes applied by other developed nations such as Canada, the United Kingdom and Japan. Indeed, Canada uses the same combination of a substantial transformation test supported by a content or value-added test.
The Government recognises that consumers and producers also want to identify goods which are totally Australian or as near to it as possible.

This legislation will restrict the application of `product of / produce of' labels to goods in which all significant ingredients or components, and all or virtually all production processes, have occurred in the country of origin.

Local citrus growers, pork producers and other primary producers will be able to proudly label their products as `Product/Produce of Australia'. They will also know that products using a significant imported ingredient will not be entitled to the premium `Product of Australia' label.

These statutory definitions underpinning the use of `Made in Australia' and `Product/Produce of Australia' claims are the core of the new policy framework for regulating country of origin labelling. However, these definitions alone will not always provide certainty or an outcome consistent with public expectations. In the past, efforts at reform have failed because the standards proposed have been rigid. An effective regulatory regime must be flexible as well as clear in its fundamental principles.

Within the framework set by the legislation, the Government has made provision for further regulation in specific sectors if this is required. This flexibility does not compromise the strength of the fundamental standards being set for `Made in' and `Product/Produce of' claims. Further regulation will need to be consistent with the standards set by the Trade Practices Act. However, the framework will allow, where necessary, additional regulations to address circumstances in specific sectors. The food industry is an obvious case. Consumers often seek additional information on food products. The seasonal availability of ingredients, and the fact that some ingredients cannot be produced in Australia for climatic or other reasons, are distinctive characteristics of the industry. In light of these factors, the Government has asked the Australian New Zealand Food Authority to consider the need for such regulation in the food industry.

Madam President, it is necessary to give the labelling regime the flexibility to address any irregularities which may arise. To protect the integrity of the regime, the Government has developed mechanisms which will allow key aspects of the general tests to be amplified by regulation. The method for calculating production or manufacturing costs, and the processes which may be included in the definition of a substantial transformation, could be refined through these provisions. In some cases, regulation could be used to confirm that unrealistic costs cannot be used to inflate Australian content levels. As it is not intended that unsophisticated processes, such as the conversion of concentrate to fruit juice, should qualify as a substantial transformation, the bill will allow for such processes to be excluded from the definition of substantial transformation. Appropriate public consultations will be required before such action is taken.

Past proposals often sought to limit the range of permissible origin claims. This bill welcomes innovative marketing and will encourage the positive promotion of Australian content. One of its first effects will be to reinvigorate the well known and respected Australian Made logo which has fallen into disuse because of legal uncertainties and confusion generally about `Made in Australia' claims. This will deliver a real benefit to many Australian firms which, in the past, have relied on the logo to enhance their profile in the marketplace. The bill also includes provisions supporting new industry-based logos, encouraging further innovation.

The changes proposed by the Government are significant and offer the only credible approach to a lasting solution of the issue. As an indication of its commitment, the Government has decided to implement a major public education and awareness campaign, supported by funding of $1.2 million in 1998/1999.

The bill contains a number of miscellaneous amendments. Two of these amendments deliver major reforms promised in the Government's New Deal: Fair Deal package. One amendment will extend the ability of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to take representative actions on behalf of small business. The second amendment will provide for the appointment of a full time commissioner with a background in small business. Both amendments will enhance the capacity of the ACCC to assist small business.

In conclusion, with this bill the Government is proposing an effective labelling scheme—a scheme which will set a realistic threshold for unqualified claims while supporting premium claims and industry specific marketing initiatives.
Consumers will be able to buy Australian with confidence, knowing exactly what is meant by country of origin claims.
Firms will be able to label with confidence, knowing exactly what tests they must satisfy to claim origin.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Chris Evans) adjourned.

subdebate.1.para: Consideration resumed.

talk.start.para: —We were in the situation where Democrats amendments 6 and 10, on sheet 951 revised, were deferred. My understanding is that the nature of the Labor Party's amendments are different in material respects to our own. Therefore my suggestion to the parliamentary secretary is that we move straight away to a vote on amendments 6 and 10. We can later consider the Labor Party amendments, which I think are a better position than the government's present bill, if my amendments go down. Parliamentary Secretary, perhaps you could react to that proposition.

—That is my understanding. We had indicated that, with a slight bit of rewording, we would be in the position of not opposing the Labor amendment. Just to recap for the benefit of Senator Cook and his team: you will recall that before the debate on matters of public interest was called on we had indicated, as the government, that we would not be opposing your amendment, in a slightly revised form, and that that would be preferable to the Democrats amendment, which is currently under consideration by the committee of the whole. Senator Murray has indicated that we should perhaps proceed straight to the vote on his amendments, which I do not think he has high hopes for. He has also indicated he would be either supporting or not opposing the amendment you propose. I think that is the appropriate way to go. Senator Cook, your amendment would be the next one up should this amendment of the Democrats be defeated.

—For the benefit of Senator Cook, who has just come into the chamber, we are talking about items 6 and 10, on sheet 951 revised, to which I have spoken and to which we now wish to put the vote. Those particular amendments deal with the question of directors calling meetings.
—Thank you for indulging me for my latecoming. My understanding is that we were going to move an amendment relating to the same subject as Democrats amendments 6 and 10.

speech.para: Amendments not agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 4, page 81 (after line 24), after section 249C, insert:

para.inline: 249CA Calling of meetings of members of a listed company by a director

speech.para: (1) A director may call a meeting of the company's members.
(2) This section applies only to a company that is:
(a) incorporated in Australia; and
(b) included in an official list of the Exchange.
(3) This section applies despite anything in the company's constitution.
The difference between my amendment and the bill is that my amendment covers public companies incorporated in Australia and listed on the official stock exchange.

talk.start.para: —For the record, whilst this is a lesser version of ours—because ours attacked private companies as well as public companies—it is an improvement on the government bill and, accordingly, we support it.

speech.para: Amendment agreed to.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: (11) Schedule 1, item 4, page 84 (line 4), omit "21", substitute "28".
This amendment relates to whether the notice of meetings should be 21 days or 28 days. We commend the government's decision to increase it from 14 to 21; now the battle is whether it should be 28.

There has been a long battle between those with a managerial philosophy who want decision making facilitated and those with a shareholder perspective who want time to consider the impact of board and management recommendations. Quite frankly, there are arguments on both sides, as the parliamentary secretary knows well.

As a general rule, one would expect that, in any conflict between the two, it is investors and owners whose views should carry greater weight. The majority report summarised the arguments concerning section 249HL of the bill, which raised the required notice to be given for meetings from 14 to 21 days. The joint committee had previously recommended 28 days, which is an important point to note. Shareholder and investor groups continue to support the 28 days approach and the Australian Democrats see no reason to vary their support for 28 days.

talk.start.para: —I think Senator Murray is quite right: there is a debate about this matter. When I first had to turn my mind to it, I had a number of conflicting views put to me. Some managers and directors are not overly opposed to 28 days because there are benefits in some respects. But a number of shareholders and shareholder groups are opposed to 28 days if they are trying to take action against a company and against directors and are trying to get something resolved. For example, if control of a company has passed and a group of dissident directors are quickly trying to organise an extraordinary general meeting, they want to move quickly. I know that, even under the current law, some groups of directors who have approached me believe that it is very hard to take action against directors who they believe are acting against the interests of shareholders.

speech.para: So if shareholders who believe that directors are acting against the interests of the company want to call an extraordinary general meeting, they have to go through the process of getting together enough minority shareholders to petition for an extraordinary general meeting and then have to wait 14 days. I think it is 14 days, but for the sake of the argument it does not really matter. The argument is that this is not a provision that is protecting directors from a meeting and that shorter periods are better for directors. Shorter periods are, for many minority shareholders, not a bad idea. They allow them to take action and get that action.

I know that Senator Murray and people like Shann Turnbull—who try to promote shareholder activism, as I and the government do—would see that having to wait 28 days to have an extraordinary general meeting because of this new notice provision would be an eternity. I would like to put to bed the argument that having long notice periods is pro-shareholders and directors are opposed to it because it hurts them. Long notice periods can be quite harmful to shareholders trying to take action.

The main source of support for 28 days is actually international funds. The push comes from people in Florida, and I am not saying this in a derogatory, xenophobic way. It comes from large international fund managers who would prefer to have 28 days because they are further away. I have put it to them—my friends from Florida, San Francisco and other places—that, with modern telecommunications and with the facilitation of electronic commerce that is in this bill and in the CLERP bills, the requirement for it is reducing as time goes by; it is not increasing.

As with a number of these other matters, this does deserve further focus. Again, this was one of the amendments that was supported by the joint parliamentary committee in its initial inquiry. As you say, Senator Murray, the existing requirement is for 14 days. The government has extended it to 21 days. We thought that for the domestic mums and dads—which is the cliche of the 1990s—the mum and dad investors, who are the great bulk of shareholders in Australia, and even for institutions in Australia, so Australian institutional investors, 21 days is a 33 per cent increase on what they have at the moment. It is a long time for an institution, with all of their expert advisers on these matters, to make up its mind about how it is going to vote at an EGM or an AGM.

But really the benefit you are trying to deliver is to foreign shareholders, and that is where I struck the balance. Twenty-one days is what we regard as a nice balance. Again, it is not something that I would seek to die in a ditch about or fight for the rest of my political life about. The government will oppose this. This is not one of the ones that we regard as a bit here or there. We do think that moving out to 28 days is quite a significant change: you are doubling the notice period. It is quite a significant change. The government at this stage remains opposed to 28 days.

What I am prepared to say, however, is that I would be very pleased to see a bigger debate amongst the general corporate law community about 21 days versus 28 days. I have really not seen a lot of argument that favours 28 days. As for shareholder groups like the ACA and the Australian Shareholders Association, you cannot strongly oppose something like 28 days versus 21, but I know that the push for this comes from overseas because they want a bit of extra time in which to consider these things. That is a legitimate concern.

When I try to balance these things, my general approach is to weight it in favour of the great bulk of shareholders in Australia and Australian institutions, who are not really worked up about whether it is 21 days or 28.

There is a downside, Senator Murray, as you have suggested. The downside is it takes longer to get things done. I will reassert for the third time that it is a detriment to small shareholders who are trying to take action against directors who they believe are not acting in the interests of the shareholders. A case I have had put before me at least half a dozen times in Western Australia while I have been in this portfolio has been where a hundred shareholders want to get together and call an EGM because they think the directors are selling off company assets.

Small shareholders come to me saying, `We are trying to get this EGM together; we want to stop these directors selling this mine'—or prospect or whatever—`but they are going to flog it off to someone else before we get to the EGM. Once we get to the EGM it is too late.' This is in a 14 day scenario. They have to get their petition together and organise the EGM and in the meantime these directors, they believe, are acting in this way. Longer notice periods can be to the significant detriment of small shareholders. I think we have found a balance. I am convinced about it, but it is something that could constructively be considered by the committee of which you are a member.

talk.start.para: —Parliamentary Secretary, you do indeed put the case very well, because there genuinely is an alternative case. For the assistance of the committee I will quote from the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities' November 1996 unanimous recommendation. This is what they said on notice of meetings:

speech.para: The bill proposes to increase the general notice period from the current 14 days to 21 days. Arguments were put that the period ought to be further extended to 28 days to enable overseas investors to cast a more fully informed vote. A 28-day notice period would seem to involve little additional inconvenience for the management of listed companies while providing shareholders, particularly foreign investors who, it was suggested, now own or manage 60 per cent of Australian equities, with a more realistic period of time to arrange for the casting of their votes.

Senator Campbell properly puts the alternative argument. We heard this debate again at the second committee hearing in March. I thought it appropriate therefore to put it before the Senate as an issue of concern in view of the substantial number of significant public companies which are foreign owned and which have such a material impact on our stock exchange and our society. I would be interested to hear the views of the opposition.

talk.start.para: —Let me accommodate Senator Murray and, hopefully, the chamber with the opposition's views. In my speech in the second reading debate I emphasised that I thought the 28 day period was the appropriate period and referred to the unanimous cross-party recommendation of the original joint parliamentary committee review, to which Senator Andrew Murray has now referred. Democrat amendment No. 25 refers to the election of directors. I will briefly put the case, if I may. The existing method of electing company directors on a limited re-election pattern has been severely criticised for being undemocratic and unrepresentative and for denying the appropriate representation of minority interests. The current system of electing directors facilitates the dominance of control groups and lessens the possibility of support being expressed for particular directors. The result of this is that, for minority interests to be held, minorities must often rely on expensive and problematic remedies such as recourse to the legal system, the ASX rules and ASIC which reduces the attractiveness of investing, reduces genuine shareholder participation and facilitates fairly domineering managerial or board control.

In order to avoid this situation, Shann Turnbull, who has been referred to before in this debate, and others propose a system of preferential voting, also described as cumulative voting, in listed companies for the election of directors in which all directors would be elected annually with each share obtaining as many votes as there are vacancies. In the United States this procedure is mandated as best practice by federal law for banks and for corporations in some states.

To mandate this type of preferential voting for directors of listed companies the law would need to specify that the number of directors to be elected will be determined by the company's constitution, all directors would retire each year, each share will obtain as many votes as there were board vacancies and each shareholder could distribute as they thought fit all or some of the votes available to them from their shareholding to any number of those nominated as directors. The consequence of this optional preferential method is that shareholders can ascribe their votes to indicate their preference for a director or directors.

Although the Australian Democrats believe that this system is desirable for all listed companies, we appreciate it may not be appropriate to require existing companies to change their constitutions. Accordingly, this recommendation applies to only newly listed companies, which we suggest should adopt this system. We also suggest that existing listed companies should be required to allow their shareholders to assess the new system and to vote on whether they wish to convert to it.

This is another part of our governance proposals. This concerns a democratisation of companies. We believe this advances the corporate governance envelope. I anticipate the parliamentary secretary's response and I suggest to him, in view of his likely response, that, if this suggestion goes down, it could be referred to the committee as an appropriate matter to be considered and, what is more, considered with your blessing, not necessarily your support, but certainly your view that it should be viewed with concern.

talk.start.para: —I indicate that this is, undoubtedly as Senator Murray will admit, a very significant change in the voting method for directors, although it is well worthy of consideration. It would go forward to the joint parliamentary committee with my full blessing.

It says that details of the entity's performance in relation to environmental regulation should be included. I draw to the attention of the Senate two documents which are relevant. The first is Hugh Morgan's recent environmental progress report. Mr Morgan is Managing Director of WMC Ltd. It is a very commendable exercise by one of our major corporations to try to respond in a businesslike, practical and responsible manner to the very serious environmental issues which affect his company. He has produced this report voluntarily.

There is another publication which I want to refer the Senate to. It is published by the chartered accountants in Australia. This is not some radical group; this is a very careful body. The publication is called Leadership. It is a discussion paper which was issued in January 1998, so it is current. It talks about the impact of environmental matters on the accountancy profession. It said, however, that 64 per cent of users would support an approach to have environmental matters included in annual reports.

In summary, that is the intention of amendment 37. It is very particular. It says that if the entity's operations are subject to any particular and significant environmental regulation under a law of the Commonwealth or of a state or territory, details of the entity's performance should be included in the report. Given the nature of our environment, we think that is an important one to include.

All those points I have laid out there will improve the nature of reporting which materially affects the value of shareholders' interests in companies and they have been carefully considered by a number of authorities and bodies. We therefore commend the amendments to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —As I understand it, we are dealing with amendments Nos 35 to 39 and amendment No. 41. Amendments Nos 35 and 36 are to do with foreign disclosure. These are matters I referred to in my closing of the second reading debate. They do add significant compliance costs to companies, but, most importantly, as I said in that speech, they do throw away sovereignty from Australia. Basically, if the SEC says `Thou shalt do this,' to the handful of Australian companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange—roughly 2,000 or thereabouts—then they would be required to report to their shareholders in Australia, information which may be entirely irrelevant to their shareholders.

speech.para: The reality is that the information that is required to be placed before shareholders on a foreign bourse is usually readily available thorough their databases. Certainly the information that is required to be disclosed to the New York Stock Exchange and to the SEC in the United States is available to anyone who wants to access it via the New York Stock Exchange's database—which has got an interesting acronym: it is called EDGAR—which is regarded as one of the most elaborate, accessible, successful information databases on the globe, I am told by the Americans who designed it.

talk.start.para: —Did they invent `EDGAR' and then fit the words to it?

—I do not know. I am sure means something like electronic data gathering and retrieval—how does that sound? Anyway, the Yanks say that it is a very good database. I am sure that the Australian Securities Commission would argue that theirs is even better, I am sure that the information technology industry thinks that they could come up with something better if you could pay them a few million dollars, and I am sure that, with the year 2000 approaching, EDGAR will have to be reinvented and improved for the new millennium.

speech.para: That is the problem with foreign disclosure. I think that the broad concept is not such a bad one, except that it does create unnecessary paperwork. It is not as simple, as Senator Conroy said this morning, as basically folding an envelope and sticking a stamp on some letters to some Australian shareholders. If you have to report something, you are actually requiring that information to be put in the annual reports. Of course, the information that is available through EDGAR or through the foreign bourses' data information and retrieval systems, be it in Europe or in the Unites States—the two main places where Australian companies list—or in Canada, for example, that is available instantaneously if you need it.

The requirement of this amendment, as I understand it, is that it be put in the annual report. That would mean that the Australian shareholders would get that information up to eight months after the event occurred or after that disclosure was made, whereas, if they accessed it through the Internet or other electronic means, they could get it instantaneously. So we think that is the concern. The government is strongly opposed to this amendment. On the environmental law, I simply say that we believe strongly that the requirements of compliance with environmental law should be in environmental laws and not in the Corporations Law.

In relation to the management discussion and analysis, again, I focused on that in the second reading debate, and I suggest that the approach that has been agreed by the Australian Stock Exchange be allowed to work. I do not know whether they have written to all people contributing to this debate, but I would be very happy, with the leave of the Senate, to incorporate in the Hansard letters that I have received, including one from the Managing Director of the Stock Exchange, Richard Humphry, who has outlined how they will be going about bringing in MD&A.

I might just quote from that letter. It says that a working group has already been established. In fact, prior to the government's discussions on this matter, a working group was established with members of the Group of 100—for the information of the Senate, that is a group made up of the financial controllers and directors of the top 100 companies in Australia. The Group of 100 has been the strongest advocate of MD&As. It is on this working group, as is the ASX, the Institute of Company Directors, the Business Council, both of the accounting bodies, and the Securities Institute. The working group is working on a best practice guide, to be completed by the end of September, which will be incorporated under ASX listing rule 4.10.3.

The letter goes on in some detail. They were going to do an annual review of that. I suggested to Mr Humphry and to others interested in this that it would be good to do a detailed and open public examination and report on the level of compliance with this best practice under listing rule 4.10.3 and to make a public report. I would be very happy if it were possible to get the agreement of the Senate to keep the MD&A out of federal law and allow it to operate through the self-regulatory organisational level of the Stock Exchange to ensure that that report was made at least to the Treasurer and that the Treasurer would undertake to table that report—not that I can commit the Treasurer to do that, but I would be certain that the Treasurer would not be opposed to doing that.

I will therefore seek leave to incorporate that letter from Richard Humphry; a letter from IFSA, the Investment and Financial Services Association, again, strong proponents of MD&As who are pleased to see it going into the ASX rules rather than federal law; a letter from Bryce Denison, the National President of the Group of 100, saying that they are working constructively with the ASX to develop the best practice guide and that they see this as the appropriate way to proceed as opposed to seeking that it be put in the law; and, finally, the letter which has been quoted from extensively by Senator Sherry and others from the Securities Institute of Australia, which is making it quite clear that they would like to see it in the listing rules but would like to see it reviewed.

The government would like to see it reviewed. We want to see it reported on. We would like to see a report from the Stock Exchange on compliance. We would like to see it as a matter of national debate. The threat hangs over these organisations that, if they do not make MD&As work through a self-regulatory way, the threat of federal legislation hangs over them. I think very few people in industry, particularly shareholder groups, would regard that the way that it is being proceeded with through the Stock Exchange mechanism is far more desirable than that proposed by the Democrat amendment. I seek leave to incorporate those documents in Hansard.
Leave granted.

Management Discussion and Analysis

I refer to our discussion regarding a possible Listing Rule being introduced by the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX) to provide for listed companies to report to shareholders through management discussion and analysis (MD&A) under the corporate governance reporting requirements currently contained in those Listing Rules. We understand that the ASX proposes to introduce such an amendment at the earliest opportunity following finalisation of a Statement of Best Practice in September and that you will support this approach.

The Securities Institute of Australia has long been a supporter of the requirement for listed companies to report to their shareholders through an MD&A requirement. We are satisfied that the introduction of this requirement into the Listing Rules with your agreement will be an advance on current reporting requirements and should be supported. By having an express requirement, companies will be on notice that the market will be assessing the quality of their reporting in this area and factoring that in to their assessment of those companies.

With this in mind, if the Listing Rules provide for MD&A, we do not believe it is necessary at this stage to include a legislative requirement in the Corporations Law. However, we believe the record of compliance by listed companies with the requirement should be reviewed within two years of its introduction. Of course, if the review shows a poor record of compliance, the need for a legislative requirement would need to be revisited.

The Group of 100 is concerned about the delays in the passage of the Company Law Review Bill 1997, particularly as it applies to concise reports and equity accounting.

We believe that the delays, particularly in respect of concise reports, will seriously disadvantage companies because these proposals promise significant cost savings to companies and their shareholders while enhancing the communication process. The Group of l00 has lobbied the Australian Accounting Standards Board to give a high priority to the preparation of an Accounting Standard to expedite implementation as soon as practicable after the proposals become law.

We have previously written to you and the Joint Parliamentary Committee regarding the directors' report—discussion and analysis to express support for its inclusion in the Bill. The Group of 100 initiated Working Party is presently finalising a Statement of Best Practice and expect that it will be endorsed by the participating organisations, including the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX). We are also hopeful that the ASX will incorporate a reference to the Statement in the Corporate Governance section of its listing rules. We currently see this as a positive outcome of co-regulation.

Chief Executive Officer

talk.start.para: —I want to make the point that the usual courtesy is to exchange correspondence. It has not happened; I am not going to complain about it. But I make that point in case someone wants to hold my colleagues to ransom on this matter later.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, it seems to me that amendment 39 should sit with amendment 40. Might I suggest that amendments 39 and 40 be dealt with together so that we look at 35 to 38.

—Senator Murray, you seek to postpone 39 to be dealt with 40 and you want to deal with 35 to 38 and 41 together. As I understand it, there is a request from Senator Harradine with regard to putting 41 as separately. I propose to put the question on that amendment separately.

—I ask whether the mover would consider dealing with 35 and 36 together, and 37 separately and perhaps 38 separately. As I understand it, amendment 38 seeks to insert a new subsection 299(1A), which adds a further requirement for the directors' annual report to include a full report of the financial affairs of the company. This is a question to both government and Senator Murray: is it not a fact that this sort of information is what one would normally expect to find in a company's audit report and/or the shareholder's prospectus in any event? There is some doubt as to whether the provision is really necessary.

speech.para: I am wondering what the government is proposing to do on this particular matter. Does it feel that this is necessary, or is it going along with this amendment? I am just wondering under those circumstances, frankly, in the government's view and in Senator Murray's view, whether it is really necessary since it would be the ordinary case that this information would be available in the audit report or the shareholder's prospectus.

talk.start.para: —The concept of a management discussion and analysis is a narrative report on the prospects of the company, which many successful Australian companies already put in annual reports but many do not. A lot of corporate governance experts believe it is a very useful guide to shareholders about the future prospects of a company. The proposal here is to make it a mandatory requirement for all large Australian companies. By `large' I do not mean big listed companies; I mean virtually everyone who has more than 50 members. I think that is the small/large test. This would apply to basically every reporting entity. Everyone who has to write an annual report would be required to put this in. So it would affect a lot of small and medium sized businesses.

speech.para: I think the Labor amendment, from memory, might restrict it to listed companies, which is obviously better. But the approach that we have pursued—firstly, in my rhetoric and, secondly, in the policy statements I have made on behalf of the government—is that the industry should be pushing these.

We should have groups, such as the Group of 100, company directors and the IFSA, preceded by AIMA, encouraging the use of MD&As. The Stock Exchange, in response to that encouragement some months ago, Senator Harradine—through you, Mr Chairman—pulled together a working group of those sorts of groups that I have mentioned, with a view to forming a set of best practice guidelines to be incorporated under one of the ASX listing rules; 4(10)(iii) is the specific listing rule.

Subsequent to forming that working group, the ASX has made a commitment to me in writing—which I have just incorporated in the Hansard—stating that it will incorporate this best practice guide and it will be reviewing it. I have asked the ASX, and it has agreed, to undertake an inquiry and make a report on the level of compliance with the requirement to do an MD&A and the effectiveness of it. In other words, is it actually improving corporate governance, is it helping shareholders make decisions and is it helping with the governance of our corporations? The ASX has stated that it will make that report, and make it a public report after two years of operation. We think that is a very commendable approach.

There is no doubt that out there in the ether there is this strong threat of federal imposition of MD&A, and the reality of that is that we are sitting here in the Senate, talking about it right now—and they are cognisant of that. So there is a strong incentive for them to make it work, and there is a strong incentive for companies to have a serious look at making MD&As a part of their normal reporting process.

The value of having it done through listing rules and having groups like the G100, the accounting bodies and the Securities Institute—who, again, are very strong supporters of an MD&A—oversighting it is that they can adjust the requirement in the listing rules. If after the first year of annual reports it is proved that the way the listing rule is framed it is not producing the results or that people are confused about it, then the flexibility exists for this working group to alter the listing rule to make it more sensible, make it more understandable, make it more effective. That is the benefit of it—it could be changed every six months, it could be changed every three months. We think that is a much more effective way to travel on MD&As.

talk.start.para: —I would respond to Senator Harradine. The management discussion and analysis section of annual reports has been around as an issue for quite some time. It was the second Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1996 report from the joint committee which recommended that there should be an MD&A, as it is called, of the matters that members need to be informed on if they are to understand the overall financial position of the company.

speech.para: The parliamentary secretary is quite right in indicating that things have moved on, and the ASX is now in a position to present and to recommend a listing section. However, it is not true that there is universal acceptance of ASX's proposal, even though that is strongly advocated by it and strongly supported by some bodies. We did, in the most recent hearing, have a number of organisations—including the Australian Accounting Research Foundation—which felt that the MD&A was necessary in the bill; in particular, they felt it was necessary because it is a characteristic of major capital markets, such as the United States, the United Kingdom and Canada.

The point that the parliamentary secretary is making is that the professional bodies all do agree that there should be an MD&A, and so does the ASX, but they want it to be voluntary. As I understand it, the ASX has made it clear that it is not a requirement to include MD&A, but its listings guide would be a matter of guidance. That is what concerns me, because it is my belief that an MD&A should be obligatory. It is vital that shareholders receive a minimum checklist of information required. That laid out in my amendment item 38, Senator Harradine, comes out of the deliberations of the joint committee—it is not something I have invented—and has wide support.

If the bill had said, `Look, either you must have an MD&A of this kind, or you must do the ASX's listing,' I would have been more inclined to the parliamentary secretary's view. But it does not do that; it leaves it open, unless the ASX listing is abided with by the company. Where Senator Cook's amendment goes is to limit the MD&A only to publicly listed companies, whereas the MD&A requirement we have put is to a company of a certain size and up.

That is a legitimate debate, but I have never understood why corporate entities of 50 or more should not still have to provide fundamental material, such as results of operations, key strategic initiatives and major commitments to their shareholders—even if it is 50 people. So, if you like, I take a fairly maximalist view, the Labor Party takes a view in between and the government takes a fairly flexible and open market view.

Once again, it is a case of there being good arguments on a number of sides. But, at this juncture, I am not persuaded that the lack of an MD&A would not result in some problems for shareholders in the nature of reporting.

talk.start.para: —The question is that amendments 35 and 36 be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —I now propose that we consider Democrats amendment No. 37.

—I have been sitting here listening to the ebb and flow of this discussion, but it is about time I came out of the closet and declared where I stand on some of these things. We did not support amendments 35 and 36 moved by the Democrats because we have got our own amendment No. 7 which we think covers that situation. We share with Senator Harradine, who raised the question about Democrat amendment 37 being dealt with separately, agreement that it should be dealt with separately. But on Democrat amendment No. 37 I would like to hear a little more argument, if I may.

speech.para: Let me indicate our view. In principle we can accept that amendment, but I am not sure that I understand the practical application of it. It is on the point of how practically it would operate that I would appreciate a little more background. It might be that we would therefore want to more explicitly word the amendment. Let me tell you what my problem is. Firstly, the idea of companies reporting about significant environmental regulation in their reports is an appropriate thing, we think. It would seem to me that what is being required here relates to a significant or a particular environmental regulation. I am not quite sure how you define `significant', though I am pretty sure how you might define `particular'. Leaving that aside for the moment, the details of the company's performance in relation to that regulation would be set out. This is self-assessment, I assume, in that they would set out in their report what the regulation was and describe in the first person for themselves how they believe they have performed up against that regulation.

talk.start.para: —What happens if they don't?
—Senator Campbell, you can ask your question when it is your turn.

—Let me take the interjection, through you, Mr Temporary Chairman, because it does help the debate. What happens if they do not do that or if they do not do that adequately, given all the MD&A emphasis we have put on this debate thus far. My problem is that I do not disagree with the idea but I am still looking for how it will actually work effectively. That is what I would appreciate some more words on. Moving to amendment 38—
—Mr Temporary Chairman, we have three minutes left. Is that correct?
—That is correct.
—Perhaps we should just deal with No. 37 and clear that out of the way. We can come to No. 38 tomorrow when we resume the debate, if that is satisfactory with you, Senator Cook.
—Yes.

—I was informed primarily in my approach to this matter by the document I outlined earlier to the Senate, which is a very good document by the chartered accountants in Australia on the impact of environmental matters on the accountancy profession. Simply put, modern environmental law, where it is significant and material—I do not mean specifications to do with a scrubber and a stack—can result in substantial consequences to corporations. We think it is appropriate, and so do the accountants, that it is reported on. You picked up the words `particular' and `significant'. I too had that debate with the draftsperson who put this together. There are some difficulties with it. Again I would suggest, with the support of the parliamentary secretary, that if this was to go down this element should be referred to the committee for examination. I do not believe it has been examined fully before.

—I indicate that I would be happy for the parliamentary committee to examine it. In principle, I would have thought that if there is an environmental regulator you would need to be responsible to that regulator.

speech.para: Progress reported.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —The decision by Labor and the Greens to block the proposed Wesley Vale pulp mill in my home state of Tasmania approximately a decade ago is now having horrendous social, environmental and economic consequences. The cheap political strategy of the time by Labor, in concert with the myopic Green movement, those 10 long years ago is unfortunately just a blur in the corporate memory of my fellow Tasmanians. But, as we consider the opportunities of the magnesite mine in Tasmania and other issues facing this nation, we need to reflect on and learn from the Wesley Vale experience.

speech.para: As a direct result of the actions of Labor's environment minister, Senator Graham Richardson, and the Greens' Christine Milne, we have had in Canberra this week a delegation of workers struggling to keep their jobs—they and 200-plus of their fellow workers now face unemployment. What happened those 10 years ago? A proposal to build a world-class paper pulp mill at a cost of $1 billion was announced. Christine Milne, now the Leader of the Greens, made her public debut and launched her political career fighting the proposal. Aided and abetted by Labor, she won.
Senator Murphy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Murphy seems to be proud of Labor's achievement in scuttling the Wesley Vale mill. I simply ask, at what price?

speech.para: There are two devastating costs of this Labor-Greens victory. Firstly, environment ally, the decision was a disaster. The mill would have processed timber from a sustainable and environmentally friendly source. Further, the mill would have been a state-of-the-art plant, emitting minimal waste—less waste than all other comparable mills in the world. Remember the Greens' slogan? `Think globally, act locally'. They thought politically and acted selfishly, because by their actions they ensured the ongoing success of the mill elsewhere in the world, belching out its pollution. They preferred that to the clean mill which was proposed; they were hardly thinking globally. Further, the timber supply for other world pulp producers does not necessarily hail from a forest industry culture as meticulous and concerned about sustainable environmental practices as is Tasmania's.

The Burnie pulp mill has been struggling for a long time. It needed new plant and equipment. Amcor, unfortunately, have not seen their way clear to provide that necessary investment, and they have therefore decided to close the mill. I trust they will change their mind. If we had had Wesley Vale up and running we would at least be using Tasmanian product and manufactured pulp in Burnie for the production of paper. Instead, we now face the very real prospect that the Burnie paper mill will be using pulp made from the rainforests of Indonesia—where there is no forest practices code or regional forest agreement, where there is not 40 per cent of the land mass set aside for reserves, and where there are not comprehensive and adequate reserves as there are in Tasmania; not to mention reafforestation.

The Greens' actions will lead to extra market opportunities for Indonesia's rainforests and, ultimately, to their destruction. That is not a good environmental outcome, let alone a commonsense outcome. The Greens' lack of vision has allowed an old polluting mill to be favoured over a clean mill. Their lack of vision will now favour product from the unsustainable harvest of Indonesian rainforest over product from Tasmania's sustainable and well-regulated forests. Their actions are as environmentally destructive as they are socially and economically destructive. That is the second great cost of that politically motivated and short-sighted decision of Labor and the Greens taken all those years ago.

For a small population of less than half a million people, a $1 billion investment would have been huge—in anyone's language. The benefits for jobs in construction, maintenance and supply would have had an ongoing, beneficial flow-through effect for our Tasmanian economy. The presence of such a mill would have been a great confidence boost to the people investing in the forest industry but, more importantly, it would have provided opportunities and security for the workers and their families and for local timber communities and towns. The potential benefits of all those jobs and of downstream processing were denied to our fellow Tasmanians. Their wellbeing was sacrificed on the altar of political expediency.

Instead of having a world-class pulp mill, we are watching the demise of Burnie's pulp mill and, more importantly, the loss of many jobs, which will undoubtedly have the devastating flow-on social consequences of bankruptcy, mortgagee sales and family breakdowns. What is tragic is that people like Christine Milne and Graham Richardson built their so-called political careers and notoriety on the back of a decision which they must have known would have this devastating social impact. The so-called victory was cheap; the cost was very expensive indeed. That type of irresponsible, short-term politicking has devastating long-term consequences.

I hope and pray that Tasmania will not be subjected to a similar campaign by Labor and the Greens on the proposed magnesite mine development in north-west Tasmania. The proposal is exciting and promises employment in a range of fields, together with real potential for downstream processing. Reject this magnesite mine proposal and you reject the aspirations of hundreds of Tasmanian workers and their families who desperately need employment opportunities. Reject this and you deny the state government desperately needed revenue for the provision of services to Tasmanians. Reject this and the prospect of another major development will be denied for another decade—with all the devastating consequences that involves.

The effective and hardworking member for Braddon, Chris Miles, needs to be congratulated on his effective leadership on jobs. Under the previous Labor government, Amcor shed hundreds of jobs from its Burnie operations. Tioxide closed, with a loss of 200 jobs. What was Labor's response? Absolutely nothing. In stark contrast, after the recent announcement of job losses at Burnie's pulp mill, what did Chris Miles and the Liberal government do? Within 48 hours a cabinet subcommittee was in the city of Burnie, listening to the workers' and the community's concerns and aspirations. They are now preparing an assistance package—a response.

For the magnesite mine proposal, Chris Miles initiated a visit by Senator Parer, Minister for Resources and Energy, and organised a public meeting to form a support group for this exciting development. That sort of proactive, pro-jobs initiative of Chris Miles and this government is what government should be all about: helping workers, families and communities. In the Mersey-Lyell region, which covers the electorate of Braddon, the employment trend collapsed by 11 per cent under Labor between 1989 and 1996. It is now rebuilding at six per cent and that is a substantial rate, but Chris Miles, our Tasmanian colleagues and I realise it needs to be increased.

As the Tasmanian delegation which is here fights for jobs and a future—a fight which I fully support—it is important to cast a backward glance and remind ourselves what necessitated their visit. I trust the workers, their families and communities will understand that today's problems are the product of the Labor and Greens collusion those 10 years ago.

Could I invite the workers and their families to help Labor and the Greens to understand their rejection of those tactics by rejecting Labor and the Greens at the next election? Job opportunities are the top priority for me, as they are for Chris Miles and my Liberal colleagues. Yet the alternative government hardly raises the issue of employment in question time or in public debate. Their record is appalling. After two years in opposition they find themselves without a jobs policy.

On the other hand, the Liberal government is unapologetically pro-jobs. Our regret is that we predicted the social and economic consequences of the scuttling of the Wesley Vale mill and, unfortunately, we were unable to save it. Nevertheless, we will stand shoulder-to-shoulder with those who face the loss of jobs. Having said that, we are looking forward to, and will actively promote, the saving of jobs and the creation of new opportunities that the magnasite mine proposal provides.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on a very positive note in relation to forests. At the end of my short presentation I will be seeking leave to table the Western Australian Forest Alliance proposal for a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest conservation reserve system and sustainable timber production in Western Australia. The proposal will lead to a sustainable tourism industry, will provide a secure resource for that and will create an extra 1,250 jobs in that industry. The proposal adds to the three approaches that were released today by the Western Australian Regional Forest Agreement Steering Committee.

speech.para: The key elements are: increased regional employment and investment centred around an expanded plantation based timber industry and tourism; a sustainable timber industry based on plantations and the appropriate use of native forest timbers; a comprehensive, adequate and representative forest conservation reserve system to protect old growth and other conservation value forests; ecologically sustainable forest management based on clearly spelt out principles; structural adjustment funding to shift the timber industry onto a sustainable footing; the splitting of CALM, Conservation and Land Management, to remove the present conflicts of interest; and recognition of Aboriginal native title over crown forests.

`Increased regional employment' looks at a net increase in timber industry employment of between 6,200 and 8,300 jobs, including the development of a pulp and paper industry, and an increase in tourism employment, as I mentioned, of 1,250 jobs. The `comprehensive, adequate and representative forest conservation system' looks at the addition of about 500,000 hectares of old growth and other high conservation value forest to the existing inadequate reserve system. It looks at increasing reserves by between 19 and 38 per cent. It involves ecologically sustainable forest management. Wouldn't that be nice for Western Australia? The components of ecologically sustainable management for both conservation and sustainable timber extraction are set out in the Western Australian Forest Alliance proposal.

The proposal looks at a sustainable timber industry, low volume, high value added industry—a large timber industry based on the use of existing plantation resources employing 9,500 people. Far from shutting down the timber industry, it would lead to a larger and more sustainable industry and a future for that industry. Most importantly, it looks at structural adjustment funding, which has been left out of the proposals. Structural adjustment has been promised and is available, as demonstrated in other states finalising regional forest agreements.

The Western Australia Forest Alliance proposal highlights the need for Commonwealth structural adjustment funds to be used to ensure a CAR reserve system and a shift to sustainable timber industry to assist those workers who need assistance in that adjustment. The splitting of Conservation and Land Management to remove conflicts of interest would lead to its replacement by a nature conservation agency and a sustainable wood production agency.

What a relief this has been produced. It is a very positive outcome. It is more than has been produced so far in the official RFA process, which is seen by many to be a sham. I commend this proposal to the Senate and seek leave to table the Western Australian Forest Alliance proposal.
Leave granted.

talk.start.para: —The quality of democracy in any particular society is seen in its adherence to the rule of law, in the importance it places on human rights, in the ability of each person within it to have his or her interests given due consideration, and in government being exercised by those for whom the people have voted.

speech.para: Free speech is fundamental to democracy. Rancour, ridicule and rapacity inform much of the public debate in Australia. This is an unhappy fact, but is in accordance with the rights which prevail in a free society. Yet a community at its best will address great issues through exchanges which are fair, temperate, inclusive and enlightened. Debates are not fair, inclusive or enlightened if they are carried out in language which seems remote and arrogant through being technical, cryptic or in-house.

Some economists claiming great authority speak in words calculated to exclude the general public from an effective part in determining the future of Australia. In doing so they turn lay people towards other persuaders. This at times leads good men and women to heed those who have simplistic, false and ugly solutions to the nation's problems.

The member for Oxley, Pauline Hanson, has answers to the great problems of our country which will not resolve them but which will encourage envy, fear, hatred and turmoil. Yet the wellbeing of the community is best served not by belittling her, but by planning our future through sane, measured and reasonable debate. Public and unfettered exchanges between a range of parties proposing various policies is a sign of a healthy democracy, but life for Australians will be at its optimum where all groups, no matter how diverse otherwise, accept as fundamental the right of every person to be respected as a member of a universal humanity, to a fair opportunity to advance his or her health, wealth, beliefs and culture within a good society, to equality before the law, to due protection for his or her social wellbeing and to the assurance that his or her family and neighbours will enjoy the same entitlements.

The best communities are those where there is a variety of views given public airing by their proponents, where there is keen and sustained debate, where there is freedom of expression, and where all this happens within a community informed by integrity, reason and a due regard by each of its members for all the others. A true community will ensure that no force within it can exercise arbitrary power. It will look to its institutions and to the people who administer them to secure for all its members a fair, decent, enlightened and safe life. The legislature, the executive and the judiciary can be despotic; so can the Public Service. Private enterprise can be autocratic; so can non-profit organisations. Associations, parties, clubs and movements can be dictatorial; so can individuals. Criminals can be tyrannical; so can police. The temptation to autocracy is a powerful one.

Over the centuries, different societies have looked to a variety of measures to keep their members safe from arbitrary power. Generally, these arise from a common concept that there are fundamental principles which should forever prevail over the power held by any force within the community. The Ten Commandments, the Sermon on the Mount, the Bill of Rights, the constitution of the United States of America and the Universal Declaration of Human Rights are examples of this concept made manifest. Adherence to these principles will ensure that all within Australia live as they are entitled to do in a fair, enlightened and inclusive society.

talk.start.para: —I would like to take the opportunity this evening to welcome to the Senate my new Territory colleague, Labor Senator Trish Crossin. She was sworn in on Monday of this week and today in this place made her first speech which, as we came to know, was not without controversy and certainly created interest in the various issues she brings from the Territory.

speech.para: I acknowledge that Senator Crossin is the first female to represent the Northern Territory in federal parliament, and this is an important precedent. I have a preselected running mate this year in Maisie Austin, who I am sure at the next federal election will give Senator Crossin a very tough and hard fight in that election campaign.

I noticed Senator Crossin's identification with the many complex and difficult issues and sociology of the Northern Territory. Particularly there is the ethnic mix of the Northern Territory, where Aboriginal Territorians and the migrants—I say that quite openly—from other Australian states and from overseas countries now clearly comprise the majority of Territorians.

It is indeed a pity that the Australian Labor Party processes in selecting Senator Crossin reflected an extreme weakness. It took five months for her to replace the able and hardworking Bob Collins. It took five months—19 weeks—to make that change in this place, so the Northern Territory was unrepresented for that period. I think that that is indicative of the very serious internal problems in a Labor socialist party that is racked with tension, controversy and the inability to identify with what is a very unique Northern Territory community. Despite the attempted ALP federal intervention to install an Aboriginal senator into the parliament part way through that preselection process, the factions obviously came into play and the left triumphed over Bob Collins's previously moderate right-wing position. I humorously say to Senator Crossin that she is obviously well- placed here now because the exhaustive and thorough preselection process took so long, and it must have been an extreme test for her.

From her first speech, it is obvious that Senator Crossin will be concentrating on social justice, the indigenous and radical and trade union oriented issues. I sincerely hope that she can reconcile these priorities against the very different Northern Territory demands which will be made of her by Territorians. I acknowledge that there were important parts in her speech, but the omissions are equally important. To me, they were patently obvious and reflect both her background and her interests. For example, probably the first and major issue that was omitted was the pioneering ventures by the Northern Territory for jobs and employment related to the important Asian and trade relationships that have been created and built up out of the Northern Territory.

The second issue that I felt was an omission was the fact that Senator Crossin did not refer to the underpinning of Australia by our focus, very properly, on defence issues. The build-up of defence in northern Australia is vital, not only for security reasons in what is an unstable regional environment but also because of the economic importance of issues such as capital works, the employment of thousands of personnel who are now Territorians, and the social integration of defence as part of the Northern Territory. Defence were equally involved in the civilian community of the Northern Territory this year in the issue of the Katherine floods trauma. I think that was a major issue that ought always to be acknowledged.

The third omission was the important and underpinning Northern Territory industry of tourism and its major impact on employment and the economy. Transport did not rate much of an interest in the speech Senator Crossin gave. Senator Crossin tabled some of her speech that she was not able to give and I know that, in those parts of her speech that were tabled, there is recognition of the railway initiatives being taken for a Darwin to Adelaide railway which reflect the other transport needs of the region.

I was also astounded that Senator Crossin made no reference to important issues of tax reform or interest rates. Both are vitally important for Territory families. There have been family tax initiatives in the last two years which have benefited the Northern Territory and, as we know, the coming tax reforms will benefit the Territory even further. The five reductions in interest rates in two years has provided the business community of the Northern Territory with a major stimulus. Every home buyer and every home owner that has built in the last two years has gained a tremendous advantage.

It is also concerning that a new senator would cut off the lifeline to jobs and industry in the Northern Territory by lining up with senators like Senator Brown and Senator Margetts against uranium mining. Uranium has been successfully mined and exported from the Territory for decades, and now promises to produce, in the next 20 years, $6 billion in income to the Northern Territory and $200 million in royalties for Aboriginal Territorians.

It is also important that I rebut Senator Crossin's criticisms of the CLP government in the Northern Territory and the Howard government's support for the Northern Territory. No government can continually be so overwhelmingly endorsed by the electorate if the results are not on the table and the social needs are not being met. The history of a proud and vibrant community such as the Territory can only reflect on good government that is in touch with its electorate. The Northern Territory government does not deserve to be criticised in a blatantly political manner without reference to the credits that certainly are reflected.

I would also remind Senator Crossin that, while she identified a number of changes made by the Howard government in public administration, in all of these functional areas of activity the government's support has, in effect, been better carried out by other departments and agencies of both the federal government and the Northern Territory government—a very significant change and move of resources. No-one can argue that development or services have, in any way, been impeded in the Northern Territory.

The federal member for the Northern Territory, Nick Dondas, and I are very proud that the federal government budget, across some 55 Commonwealth departments and agencies, has increased by more than 10 per cent in each of the last Howard budgets in the Northern Territory at a time when national budgeting has necessarily had to be severely constrained because of the past delinquency and profligacy of the Hawke and Keating Labor administrations, which produced such disastrous economic underpinning of the Northern Territory. Young people, Northern Territory families, businesses and industry can rely on the efforts of the Country Liberal Party in the Northern Territory and the Liberal and National Party polices that have been and are being implemented nationally that impact on the Northern Territory.
I am pleased to welcome Senator Crossin to this place. I look forward to engaging with her in lively debate in the interests of all our constituents.

(2) What proportion of advertising placed by the department or portfolio agencies since March 1996 has been for: (a) print media; (b) radio; (c) television; or (d) other, and give details of other forms of advertising used.

(2) All advertising funds described above were spent on print media.

(b) AMSA—Direct/TMP Worldwide/Adcorp; COM—Direct to publishers; OEA—3% direct to publishers; Department:—TMP Worldwide/Davies Brothers Limited/Newsletter Information Services/Executive Media/direct to publishers.
It should be noted that TMP Worldwide is the approved central placement agency under the OGIA tendering process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 23 April 1998:

question.para: (1) What is the number of non-graduate positions advertised by Recruitment Services Australia for the Commonwealth public service and other Commonwealth public sector agencies over the past 12 months.
(2) How many of these positions have required applicants to pass tests.
(3) How many applicants sat tests in that period.
(4) (a) How many new non-graduate appointments have been made in the same period; and (b) in which agencies.
(5) What are the average and the lowest test ratings accepted in the appointments which were made.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Recruitment Services Australia (RSA) does not advertise specific numbers of positions. It gives Australian citizens and permanent residents reasonable opportunity to enter the Australian Public Service (APS) by advertising recruitment cam paigns at regular intervals, usually annually, for people interested in gaining traineeship, base level clerical and graduate trainee positions through the Public Sector Recruitment Test (PSRT) and Public Sector Recruitment Questionnaire (PSRQ). It also advertises Aboriginal Recruitment Test (ART) campaigns for Indigenous Australians interested in traineeship and base level clerical positions designated for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.
Applicants gaining the required scores on tests are then eligible for referral to vacancies as they arise.

(2) Public Service and Merit Protection Commission regulations require all applicants referred by RSA to permanent entry level positions to have gained at least minimum qualifying scores on the appropriate test instrument.
(3) In the 12 months to 23 April 1998, a total of 26,723 people attempted the Public Sector Recruitment Test/Public Sector Recruitment Questionnaire and 888 sat the Aboriginal Recruitment Test.
(4) (a) Over this period a total of 507 people have been appointed to permanent, non-graduate entry level positions in the Australian Public Service.

(b) These appointments were made in the following agencies: Department of Defence, Industrial Patents Australia, Department of Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, Centrelink, Department of Tourism and Regional Development, Attorney General's Department, Department of Social Security, Australian Taxation Office, Australian Customs Service, Refugees Review Tribunal, Australian Bureau of Statistics, Department of Health and Family Services, Australian Protective Services and the Australian Industrial Registry.

(5) For the Aboriginal Recruitment Test, applicants are referred based on their total standardised score and the application of additional selection criteria. The average total standardised score of applicants appointed through the Aboriginal Recruitment Test was 221 and the lowest was 193.

The Public Sector Recruitment Test and Public Sector Recruitment Questionnaire together assess ten skills and attributes. Applicants are assigned ratings from 1 to 10 for each of these attributes and are referred to positions based on the minimum ratings agencies require for each one. Total standardised scores are only a consideration in selecting applicants for referral when there are more applicants meeting a position profile than it is possible to refer.

The average test and questionnaire ratings accepted in the appointments that were made were: Working with Words—8; Working with Numbers—7; Problem Solving—7; General Ability—8; Goal Orientation—7; Team Work—8; Customer Service—8; Resourcefulness—7; Leadership—7; Workplace Learning/Adaptability—8.

The lowest test and questionnaire ratings accepted in the appointments that were made were: Working with Words—5; Working with Numbers—5; Problem Solving—5; General Ability—5; Goal Orientation—5; Team Work—5; Customer Service—5; Resourcefulness—5; Leadership—5; Workplace Learning/Adaptability—5.

The Public Sector Recruitment Test was introduced in 1997 so, during the period in question a total of 70 applicants were placed in permanent, non-graduate entry level positions on the basis of an earlier test instrument, the Administrative Service Test. For this test, applicants were referred based on their total standardised score and the application of additional selection criteria. The average total standardised score of applicants appointed through the Administrative Service Test was 320 and the lowest was 315.
